story:
About My Project (And Me!)

My experience at TIDE

            This Project began in Dec 2012. I came to TIDE to get work experience in conservation and my experience has exceeded every expectation I had prior to coming to Belize. This project, to me, is fascinating. It has challenged me to learn faster than I ever thought imaginable and exposed me to methodologies that I would never have thought I could even comprehend, let alone implement. It has inspired me to put all of the information I've been devouring for the last seven months to use by not just stating the obvious, that something needs to be done to improve solid waste management in many developing countries, but using my study to actually make a difference.

What I’m doing:

           The purpose of my research is to find out if this immense open dump site (one of the largest in the country), located in the middle of a wetland jungle, is impacting the nearby Rio Grande river (also one of the largest in the country) and the species within. Five species that are  accessible at all my sites on the river, known to bioaccumulate, and are a common food source to humans and so may pose a health risk, will be tested for the following contaminants:                                         Organic pollutants: Nitrogen: In the form of ammonia ((NH3-), ammonium  (NH4+), nitrite (NO2− ), nitrate Phosphate  (PO3-4). Heavy metals: Zinc (Zn), Iron (Fe), Nickel (Ni), Manganese (Mn) Cadmium (Cd), Lead (Pb), Copper  (Cu), Chromium (Cr), Mercury (Hg). Persistent Organic Pollutants (POP’s): Polychlorinated Biphenyl (PCB’s), Phenols. 

And finally, stable isotope analysis of nitrogen (δ15N) and carbon (δ13C), tested on the same species, will prove that any contaminants found are from the dump site and not outside sources (see my video for a fun explanation of this! or, if your truly interested in the science, see my project summary!)

So what!? Outcomes of this Research:

Results from this project will be used:

- By the Solid Waste Management Authority of Belize to advocate for relocation of this dump site to a more suitable location and to inform appropriate restoration strategies.

- By local environmental and social organizations to develop initiatives to reduce municipal waste in the first place by composting and UpCycling.

 ‘Something From Nothing’: I’ve been called a gypsy many times in my life by close friends. I am resourceful, artistic, and I have an inert ability to create ‘Something From Nothing’. For Every 300$ Donated to This Project  I will do just that, take a dent out of the mountains of plastic bottles that are cast away at the Rio Grande dump site, and UpCycle them into bottle bins to be placed around town, providing an alternative to current practices of disposing of waste in old fridges, cardboard boxes, in bags on the sides of the street, or in the ocean.  (See my creation below!)

I also plan on attempting a bottle couch as well as a bottle greenhouse to compliment the tire planter garden and composting program that is just now becoming a reality at TIDE. The hope is that demonstrations of these UpCycling projects, and spreading results from conclusive research, will begin to change the way people dispose of solid waste in Belize.

: Made of  115 Coca Cola Bottles, Wire from burnt tires, Sand, and Painted rocks = 100% UpCycled

What I need:  

UpCycling is Cheap: the whole point is to use what would have been garbage to make something of practical purpose. Very little is required, and I am actually excited to look for donations of materials around town; it’s a great way for me to make the connections I need to make these big ideas a reality. Lab analysis: not so much. There is no lab with the mass spectrometer I need in all of Central America. Samples will be shipped to Canada to be analyzed at Trent University, Ontario.

Stable Isotope Analysis:                                     CA$ 2290

Contaminant Analysis:                                        CA$ 590

Shipping Samples to Canada (Including permits):  CA$ 120

                                                                                        = CA$ 3,000

Even if you can’t donate, you can still help

Even if you can’t donate please help me by reposting the link to my campaign or by talking to friends and family that you think might support my cause. If people don’t repost it, the momentum will die within days, along with my dreams. ( Ooo guilted you into it didn’t I ?! ).

If you can Donate: along with my love you will get:

 

Select a Perk:

20$

A Postcard from the Rio Grande, good karma, and a virtual hug

50$

A postcard from the Rio Grande, good Karma, Belizean chocolate from locally grown Cacao And a huge virtual hug

100$

A postcard from the Rio Grande, a tonne of good Karma, Belizean chocolate from locally grown Cacao, A huge virtual hug, And a T-Shirt saying how UnBelizable you are.

200$

A postcard from the Rio Grande, copious amounts of good Karma, Belizean chocolate from locally grown Cacao, A T-Shirt saying how UnBelizable you are, A Bottle Bin built in your honor, and my everlasting gratitude.

500$

A postcard from the Rio Grande, and a lifetime of good Karma (sent by yours truly), Belizean chocolate from locally grown Cacao, A T-Shirt saying how UnBelizable you are, Two Bottle Bins built in your honor and my everlasting gratitude.

Thank you So Much!

story:
Short Summary

My campaign and why it’s important to me:

https://www.facebook.com/events/319093024814772/365268263530581/?ref=notif&notif_t=plan_mall_activity

3rd Annual Tar Sands Healing Walk

Here is another link about the Tar Sands Healing walk that has newly been established:

http://www.healingwalk.org/

 


$1.00 is all I ask.

I'd like ... LOVE...to be a part of this. Would you be willing to sponsor me? If you are unable to, is there anyone you know who has a small business/local company that wants to be advertised as being a part of positive CHANGE that would be willing to sponsor me? I can get it covered on film with images & videos, blog updates, and with luck and stealth manners, perhaps even broadcasted on the news and radio.

Below is a list of any expenditures involved. Perhaps you know enough people in your network that have a minimal amount to give, the faith that I can make a difference through this movement, and the desire to be involved without having the time. I wish to be a vessel for all of you that care, to be the messenger, to be the puppet that can speak to an audience, while most of you are hindered by your careers and priorities. Let me be your catalyst. Give me your words, thoughts, and opinions...Consider me your voice.

One dollar from each of you, could well send me on my way to walking within the realms of the Tar Sands' corruption. This healing walk will enable me to grasp a clearer picture, first hand, of the detrimental effects this pit in Canada has produced. It will guide my energy toward healing the TarSands Pipeline Project. This Tar Sand pit has already damaged many water reservoirs, ruined ecosystems for an indeterminable time, damaged the food chain affecting not only humans but thousands of wild species as well, and is on the way to polluting not just the wildlife in Canada, but much of the soil and water systems in America as well. The repercussions go much farther than that, and I am ready to give resources as well as layman's terms and/or answers to any questions you have regarding this issue.

ONE DOLLAR. It is worth nothing to you today. Perhaps an item made in China at the Dollar Store...perhaps a roll of toilet paper...perhaps, if you're lucky, a convenient beverage...But to me...to me it is worth an invaluable amount. Were I to receive this amount from each of you, just imagine the difference I could make for you...I IMPLORE you to imagine! With a life story behind me that shows nothing of ill promise, I survived. I am here for ALL of you. To do do the work of every one of you who is incapable of the time, the money, the passion, the resistance to society which so many of you feel in your heart, but are afraid to act upon. 1 dollar. $1.00 can set you free and make a world of difference.

Will you help me to help us all?

 

A little more about me:

My name is Diana April, I'm 33 years old and a single mother of a 12 year old son. Both my son and I have been part of numerous campaigns...including, but not limited to, the iMatter March, Green-Up Day Vermont (multiple times!), 350VT & 350.org movements, as well as Vermont Workers' Rights campaigns.

Beyond the spotlighted events, we live a lifestyle that most would bawk at (feel free to use some of these ideas if you wish!):

~we do our laundry in the tub and hang it to dry in the kitchen, saving gallons of water, and kilowatts of electricity, not to mention money...

~without a lawn to plant a garden, we've collected upcycled containers to plant our own lush garden in on our three-season porch, including using cleaned out containers from food purchases, such as soup and coffee cans, strawberry containers, old wooden crates, and even hummus containers.

~we buy our (as much as we can) non-GMO organic food in bulk, bake our own bread, and store the bulk food in old glass containers - such as pickle and baby food jars.

~almost every peice of furniture in our home has been a used item before we acquired them. Each peice was either gifted to us in exchange for labor, found via thrift stores, or things we've put together ourselves with a little elbow grease and some screws.

~we both ride bicycles in exchange for having a car. This does cause us many challenges regarding visiting relatives and friends, but we decided that renting or borrowing a friend's car and visiting far less often not only saves carbon emissions and money, but also makes the time we do spend with our loved ones that much more incredible.
 
~we no longer purchase plastic products and are slowly seeding them out of our lifestyle (which is no way easy and is taking a LOT of time!), but what we do already have in house, such as plastic baggies, we wash and re-use when we need to -which really isn't that often...
 
~we've switched to cleaning products that are either environmentally friendly (such as Seventh Generation dishwashing liquid) or made from staples in our kitchen - baking soda as toothpaste, although it can be abrasive so we only use it every other day, as a facial and hair cleanser, and vinegar as a hair rinse, household cleaner, and fruit fly attractant.
 
~instead of purchasing many household items, we scour the internet for inspiration on how to create our own, instead of feeding the consumerism. Some examples? -We needed a toilet paper holder, and didn't want to buy a plastic one (which was the most affordable version), so we upcycled a wire clothing hanger into a holder that holds up to three rolls at a time! -We were at odds with how to hold our spice containers without a rack, but found an old CD holder at a thrift shop and refashioned it to hold the bottles of spices. Many more examples, but I won't bore you!
 
~we make all of our gifts. They may not be the flat screen TV my son wanted for Christmas, nor were they brand-name clothes, but in making our gifts, we find the real meaning of gifting, we save the stress of holiday crowds, recycle paper goods, and find that the recipients find them ever more precious than the impersonal gift certificate.
 
~we've even opted for green shipping - we reuse any scrap paper as packing material, pack our mailings in re-used junk mail envelopes and cardboard cereal or tea boxes, and any wrapping is done with paper bags from the supermarket.
 
~some nights, the two of us unplug everything, shut off all the lights, and play board games by candle light (unfortunately, our conversations usually end up involving hunger, though, so we do make some stovetop popcorn for those nights beforehand ;P)
 
~we also have kept to the standard "CFLs, recycling, keeping the heat lower, unplugging unused electronics, adjusting the temperature in the fridge to use less power, etc etc"
 

A Little More Personal

I grew up knowing that something wasn't panning out right with the earth; that one day we were going to have to deal with things that we'd been turning the other cheek to for a long long time. I doubt that I was ever "educated" formally on the topic of climate change; a lot of it I learned through lectures, reading, and speaking with others who shared the same ideas that the earth was in trouble. I reached my twenties that I began looking into nutrition and the engineering of food and pesticide use...I went to the market one day to find an apple as big as a grapefruit and it clicked with me that, "Oh, my...this just isn't right!" The issues with fruits and vegetables led me to the knowledge of factory farming and what animals were being subjected to within them. Once I had a grasp on that, the repercussions of the altered food chain led me to the environmental issues. I researched on my own, absorbing so much information I literally made myself sick. I remember crying over it all...feeling hopeless, helpless, incapable and also part of the problem. I'd express these feelings to my loved ones who would look at me and say, "You can't take this on your shoulders, Diana, you are just one person! This is just the way it is." 
 
But I had a son. A very young son at the time, and I was determined to make sure he was aware of the world he was going to be faced with if we all just sat back and said, "this is just the way it is." And in no way was I going to prepare him for these problems without setting an example for him on how to take small steps to fixing, or at least slowing down the acceleration of, climate change.

What I Need & What You Get

The amount of funding I'm looking for will be ongoing. There are many climate-related projects that call for activism upcoming this year, as well as further into the future, especially as the climate situation gets worse. My funding needs are specifically for travel and lodging expenses, and for each venture, an itinerary of expenditures will be listed. I can handle my own nourishment, and all other necessities, as I have a tent, backpack, and sleeping bag if the funds for a hostel room or cheap motel do not become available in time. I'm not afraid to sleep outside but if that's the case, it would be nice to have some funding in order to wash up at a local YMCA or similar establishment. Any questions will be answered as fully as possible. Right now, I imagine that lodging per night will cost between $50-$100 per night, depending on the location of the project. Please, keep in mind, that if a campground is nearby, I will choose that option first, and assume that the lodging expense for that will be under the above predicted amount. Travel expenses vary with each venture, as ideally, carpooling or traveling via bus or train is the most logical route. Train tickets can cost upwards of $100 one way, depending on the destination, and bus fare can be cheaper if bought in advance (anywhere from $10 to $200 - one way OR round trip). Carpooling would require that I find another activist with a spare seat, and would require gas money (again, that would vary depending on the destination), or renting an economy size vehicle and packing in as many other folks who want to be a part of it as well. Renting can be efficient, although there may be stipulations regarding mileage and insurance rates. Currently, I can rent from Enterprise for about $60 a day, including the necessary insurance and unlimited miles. I do have a membership with them and they have been very good about giving me discounts as I earn points.

Access to a power supply is obviously pertinent to this cause, as I intend to keep you all up to date with blogs and photos as soon as time permits. If internet access is available via a free wifi site, that will be my first choice (such as a coffee shop or local library), but there is a chance that I will have to pay for a connection to upload photos and publish blogs during the travels and usually this cost is about $5-15 an hour. I have my own laptop and camera, as well as a memory card and extra bettery, so I do not expect to use any money towards that endeavor. 

If I could sum up an estimated amount for each venture, I would say a minimum of $150 to a maximum of $600 for each activism project.

While on these ventures, I encourage you to read the blogs I'll be posting during each project. I have extensive writing skills and experience, and hope to keep you informed as well as entertained to the best of my abilities. Please note that some of these activism ventures can be quite emotional, and often there are little dramas that add to the intensity of the story. Upon returning home from each traverse, a reflective and conclusive post will be published as well.

Any funds that have been collected over my goal will be placed aside for future activist projects. If any goals are not met, I will still try to meet the end goal and pay out of pocket in order to be a catalyst for change. If the money simply isn't available, the funds will be rolled over into the next activism endeavor's fundraising effort, and you will be notified as to wha that endeavor is, in order for you to be refunded if you do not supprt it, or (hopefully) continue to have it remain in the fund for the upcoming activism.

By reading the "perks", you can find what each perk's amount is worth in return to you. Even by donating a dollar, you will be able to share these adventures with me virtually through my blogs and photos. You can also expect an email from me, personally thanking you for your assistance. The more you can donate, the more I can give back. If you donate more than once to each cause, and the total of your donations adds up to a certain perk amount, you will receive that perk's decription. :)

 

The Impact

I wish to be a vessel for all of you that care, to be the messenger, to be the puppet that can speak to an audience, while all of you can only sit back and watch due to your careers and priorities. Let me be your catalyst. Give me your words, thought, opinions...Consider me your voice.

Each and every project I've ever been a part of has given me more faith in the human race, as with each venture, I've seen positive change and progress towards awareness, reaching out to people who may not have known about the issues surrounding the Tar Sands and other climate-change related issues, as well as political decision-making that has monumentally altered original plans that would've had a negative effect on the climate change crisis.

Involving children in these protests, rallies, sit-ins, and healing walks has proven to give them the confidence that even their tiny voices can be heard and make a difference! During a 40 mile bike trek from Central Vermont to the capital city of Montpelier, I witnessed some twenty kids changing their thought processes in front of me, as they beat the odds and biked almost all of those 40 miles. They asked questions, gained interest in things that they were ignorant to beforehand, and began showing an awareness of the world around them in ways I'd never seen before. These changes happened within ONE movement. Imagine what three or more a year could do to our younger generations, and how many people they have the ability to share and capture the attention of!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that we are all in a time of economic challenge and it's hard to just give out money of any amount. Rest assured, there are other things you can do - so long as you do not feel guilty about being unable to financially assist me -

~Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Send your friends to my Indiegogo campaign page, here, and feel free to ask me for print-outs which you can post in your office, around your neighborhood, or on community bulletin boards.

~Use the Indiegogo share tools!

~Feel free to donate your time. Perhaps you'd like to be a part of this alongside me and become an activist yourself? Maybe you'd like to learn wat you can do in your own life to make small changes that can really add up? I'm here to help you, as that's what I do. :)

~make suggestions, think out of the box, pretend there IS no box...help me with your own intuitive, creative and beautiful minds to share any ideas you are holding that could make my activism more successful.

And thank you in advance!

~we also have kept to the standard "CFLs, recycling, keeping the heat lower, unplugging unused electronics, adjusting the temperature in the fridge to use less power, etc etc"
 
A Little More Personal
I grew up knowing that something wasn't panning out right with the earth; that one day we were going to have to deal with things that we'd been turning the other cheek to for a long long time. I doubt that I was ever "educated" formally on the topic of climate change; a lot of it I learned through lectures, reading, and speaking with others who shared the same ideas that the earth was in trouble. I reached my twenties that I began looking into nutrition and the engineering of food and pesticide use...I went to the market one day to find an apple as big as a grapefruit and it clicked with me that, "Oh, my...this just isn't right!" The issues with fruits and vegetables led me to the knowledge of factory farming and what animals were being subjected to within them. Once I had a grasp on that, the repercussions of the altered food chain led me to the environmental issues. I researched on my own, absorbing so much information I literally made myself sick. I remember crying over it all...feeling hopeless, helpless, incapable and also part of the problem. I'd express these feelings to my loved ones who would look at me and say, "You can't take this on your shoulders, Diana, you are just one person! This is just the way it is." 
 
But I had a son. A very young son at the time, and I was determined to make sure he was aware of the world he was going to be faced with if we all just sat back and said, "this is just the way it is." And in no way was I going to prepare him for these problems without setting an example for him on how to take small steps to fixing, or at least slowing down the acceleration of, climate change.

What I Need & What You Get
The amount of funding I'm looking for will be ongoing. There are many climate-related projects that call for activism upcoming this year, as well as further into the future, especially as the climate situation gets worse. My funding needs are specifically for travel and lodging expenses, and for each venture, an itinerary of expenditures will be listed. I can handle my own nourishment, and all other necessities, as I have a tent, backpack, and sleeping bag if the funds for a hostel room or cheap motel do not become available in time. I'm not afraid to sleep outside but if that's the case, it would be nice to have some funding in order to wash up at a local YMCA or similar establishment. Any questions will be answered as fully as possible. Right now, I imagine that lodging per night will cost between $50-$100 per night, depending on the location of the project. Please, keep in mind, that if a campground is nearby, I will choose that option first, and assume that the lodging expense for that will be under the above predicted amount. Travel expenses vary with each venture, as ideally, carpooling or traveling via bus or train is the most logical route. Train tickets can cost upwards of $100 one way, depending on the destination, and bus fare can be cheaper if bought in advance (anywhere from $10 to $200 - one way OR round trip). Carpooling would require that I find another activist with a spare seat, and would require gas money (again, that would vary depending on the destination), or renting an economy size vehicle and packing in as many other folks who want to be a part of it as well. Renting can be efficient, although there may be stipulations regarding mileage and insurance rates. Currently, I can rent from Enterprise for about $60 a day, including the necessary insurance and unlimited miles. I do have a membership with them and they have been very good about giving me discounts as I earn points.
Access to a power supply is obviously pertinent to this cause, as I intend to keep you all up to date with blogs and photos as soon as time permits. If internet access is available via a free wifi site, that will be my first choice (such as a coffee shop or local library), but there is a chance that I will have to pay for a connection to upload photos and publish blogs during the travels and usually this cost is about $5-15 an hour. I have my own laptop and camera, as well as a memory card and extra bettery, so I do not expect to use any money towards that endeavor. 
If I could sum up an estimated amount for each venture, I would say a minimum of $150 to a maximum of $600 for each activism project.
While on these ventures, I encourage you to read the blogs I'll be posting during each project. I have extensive writing skills and experience, and hope to keep you informed as well as entertained to the best of my abilities. Please note that some of these activism ventures can be quite emotional, and often there are little dramas that add to the intensity of the story. Upon returning home from each traverse, a reflective and conclusive post will be published as well.
Any funds that have been collected over my goal will be placed aside for future activist projects. If any goals are not met, I will still try to meet the end goal and pay out of pocket in order to be a catalyst for change. If the money simply isn't available, the funds will be rolled over into the next activism endeavor's fundraising effort, and you will be notified as to wha that endeavor is, in order for you to be refunded if you do not supprt it, or (hopefully) continue to have it remain in the fund for the upcoming activism.
By reading the "perks", you can find what each perk's amount is worth in return to you. Even by donating a dollar, you will be able to share these adventures with me virtually through my blogs and photos. You can also expect an email from me, personally thanking you for your assistance. The more you can donate, the more I can give back. If you donate more than once to each cause, and the total of your donations adds up to a certain perk amount, you will receive that perk's decription. :)
 


The Impact
I wish to be a vessel for all of you that care, to be the messenger, to be the puppet that can speak to an audience, while all of you can only sit back and watch due to your careers and priorities. Let me be your catalyst. Give me your words, thought, opinions...Consider me your voice.
Each and every project I've ever been a part of has given me more faith in the human race, as with each venture, I've seen positive change and progress towards awareness, reaching out to people who may not have known about the issues surrounding the Tar Sands and other climate-change related issues, as well as political decision-making that has monumentally altered original plans that would've had a negative effect on the climate change crisis.
Involving children in these protests, rallies, sit-ins, and healing walks has proven to give them the confidence that even their tiny voices can be heard and make a difference! During a 40 mile bike trek from Central Vermont to the capital city of Montpelier, I witnessed some twenty kids changing their thought processes in front of me, as they beat the odds and biked almost all of those 40 miles. They asked questions, gained interest in things that they were ignorant to beforehand, and began showing an awareness of the world around them in ways I'd never seen before. These changes happened within ONE movement. Imagine what three or more a year could do to our younger generations, and how many people they have the ability to share and capture the attention of!
 


Other Ways You Can Help
I understand that we are all in a time of economic challenge and it's hard to just give out money of any amount. Rest assured, there are other things you can do - so long as you do not feel guilty about being unable to financially assist me -
~Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Send your friends to my Indiegogo campaign page, here, and feel free to ask me for print-outs which you can post in your office, around your neighborhood, or on community bulletin boards.
~Use the Indiegogo share tools!
~Feel free to donate your time. Perhaps you'd like to be a part of this alongside me and become an activist yourself? Maybe you'd like to learn wat you can do in your own life to make small changes that can really add up? I'm here to help you, as that's what I do. :)
~make suggestions, think out of the box, pretend there IS no box...help me with your own intuitive, creative and beautiful minds to share any ideas you are holding that could make my activism more successful.

And thank you in advance!

story:
Sustainable Environmental & Economic Development (SEED) Park is a verified nonprofit who is assisting with this project because of the efficient solution to retaining a business under drought conditions. SEED’s mission is to assist business development in a sustainable way through conservation, shared resources and achieving zero waste. The draining of the Ogallala Aquifer, the high soil water evaporation and the deep-water percolation are the main problems that face the agriculture industry in our region.

High Plains Gardens, a nursery in Lubbock County, TX, specializes in xeric and native plants. The greenhouse, located on the 35-year homestead of David and Nancy Hubbard (3211 County Road 5800), uses water from a 185-ft deep well drawing from rock formations in the Ogallala Aquifer. The static water level of the Ogallala in this area has been dropping about 1 ft. per year for the past 30 years. For 2011, it was reported by the High Plains Underground Water District that the average drop in the Ogallala had been 2.9 ft.


 During the irrigation season for cotton, the water table drops below the 185 ft. level, leaving this well and the wells of area neighbors, high and dry. In December 2012, watering of winter wheat has also taken place. Drilling a deeper well will allow the individual with the “longest straw” to withdraw water long after the more shallow wells of neighbors have been pulled dry.
The Ogallala Aquifer is being drained at an alarming rate, and as a result, we feel it is imperative to become totally independent of ground water and are working with SEED Parks International toward that end. The solution: collect rain water.


High Plains Gardens is located on a parcel of land northwest of a playa lake basin at an elevation of 3,284 ft. at the highest point and dropping to 3,278 ft. at the lowest point in the southeast corner. During rainfall events, the runoff from approximately 1 section of land (640 acres) flows down the road and ditch, with a large portion spilling across the Hubbard’s property. At times following a heavy rainfall, standing water on the Hubbard property has been at least 2 ft. deep.


 The Hubbard property has nine completed buildings, two additional greenhouses under construction and the proposed construction of sheds for housing water storage tanks for a total of 10,766 sq. ft. as a footprint for collecting water. According to the Texas Water Development Board (2006) (TWDB), Lubbock rooftops could yield 16,000 to 20,000 gallons per year from a 2,000 sq. ft. roof. Therefore, the buildings on the Hubbard property could yield about 75,000 to 100,000 gallons of collected rainwater per year.
Help us maintain this long time business with an efficient collection and use of rain water. 

To view the full proposal:http://highplainsgardens.com/pdf/Sustainable%20... Funds received will go toward the purchase of water storage tanks, construction of sheds to cover those tanks, gutters, water filters, pumps, and a liner for a pond designed to catch runoff water. Your donation will be greatly appreciated!

story:
Battle for Bogton

Firstly thank you for taking the time to read about our project and hopefully donate to our fight to keep Common Good Land exactly that.... Common (for the use of EVERYONE and beautiful) as well as protecting our High Streets and Town Centre from further out of town developments. We are grateful for your interest and need your help.

The Battle for Bogton Group are mainly residents of Forres, as well as a few good folk who care deeply about our town centres and the protection of Common Good Land. It would be wrong of me to pick out one or two individuals as everyone is playing an important roll in fighting Redco Milne (the wealthy property developer). But you can get to know them better by joining our facebook group.


We now have a dedicated website which you can view here...

The Battle for Bogton Official Website

Please take a look here to see what a beautiful town Forres is.

My name is Joni Phippin. I am passionate about protecting independent local business and our town centres, I believe green spaces in towns keep us sane (even if you don't go on them the very sight of it is nurturing) I am not from Forres but I am supporting B.O.B because I believe we have enough dead high streets, enough massive super markets, enough ugly buildings all over the land and can visit them anytime. I don't think we have many unique high streets, enough green spaces, enough money staying local, enough wonderful small towns. Soon you won't be able to visit them anytime as they will be gone. You can't put it back either. No changing your mind 10 yrs down the line.

   

Where will our children play ?

If we don't support our neighbors when they need us who will support us?

We want to claim Bogton Common Land for a day.

We want to claim the Common Good Land for the whole community by staging an event on the land for EVERYONE. We have planned live music, games, crafts, stalls with supporting local groups.

  • We want to attract the lovely people of Forres to Bogton Park to see for themselves the scale and impact of the Redco plans
  • To encourage community. Different groups in Forres meeting and working together
  • to have FUN.

We want it to be accessible to all - which means free. To do this we need to raise money to pay for the legal stuff. Lots of us are already funding different aspects of the day, but we can't stretch to this last bit.

We want to show that protest can be positive, happy and peaceful.

  • We need £1000 - This will pay for the main stage and toilets. It has to be safe in all weather conditions (this is Scotland) and so we need to hire a professional rig.
  • Even if we can't reach our £1000 target every penny will go toward the bill... I don't know if you can imagine the difference even just £200 will make. All Accounts will be openly published on pour facegroup page for scrutiny and any surplus will be donated to our Community Council to pay for further legal defence, Freedom of Information requests and title deed searches.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t donate, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • I know money is tight and that's OK. Please don't feel you need to give what you can ill afford. You're time is valuable to us....you can share this as much as you can... Facebook, email and over a cuppa in the cafe. You can come along on the day and show support shoulder to shoulder and you can join in the debate - Battle For Bogton Facebook
  • Remember you can use the share buttons on this page too.

Thank you

Joni

story:
Our cause in detail

The world ocean is the biggest contributor to life on Earth. It is where everything has begun and will go back into, in one form or another. The Black Sea is a small piece of the Blue Planet, but a big part of our life.

 

Three tons of plastic are entering the Black Sea on a daily basis from land and the in-flowing rivers. A study, conducted in August 2017 by the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences and the Laboratory for Marine Ecology, concluded that the Black Sea is just as polluted with micro plastics as every other ocean. 90% of the total solid waste in the Black Sea are industrial polymer products.

 

 

The study showed that the largest amount of waste in the Black Sea area between Cape Kaliakra and the city of Burgas, are plastic particles larger than 2.5 cm -  mainly fishing nets, plastic bottles, packages, sacks and plastic bags.

 

Marine ecologists Dimitar Berov and Stefania Klein conducted their research during Greenpeace’s “Free of Plastic” campaign, on board the Rainbow Warrior vessel. This is one of the few partial monitorings done on the Black Sea waters.

More research is needed to understand the overall condition of the water and work towards solutions.

 

 

What we will do

  • During the WIND2WIN Challenge, in the assisting boats, there will be a team of a marine ecologist and a marine biologist - Dimitar Berov and Velizara Stoilova. They will collect water samples, do visual monitoring for marine litter and make marine mammal observation throughout the 300 km route along the whole Eastern Bulgarian Black Sea border. The new data will be added to help establish the ecological status of the Black Sea.

 

 

  • Filming a documentary to follow the WIND2WIN Challenge and the PLASTIC FREE BLACK SEA cause. The film is our attempt to raise awareness of the increasing plastic pollution and to inspire the young generation to switch to a more environmentally conscious life. The documentary is a powerful way to reach more people by exposing the issue on world and national film festivals and TV channels.

 

  • In 2019, our team will organize a cleaning event on a beach along the Black Sea coast. This event will gather a community that will help battle this problem. 

 

 

Who we are - the WIND2WIN team 

Iliyana Stoilova -  former Bulgarian windsurf competitor and national champion among women. She started surfing at the age of 6 and years later began competitive training.

Yoan Kolev - former Olympic contestant and a Balkan champion in windsurfing class RS:X racing. He started his professional sports career at the age of 10.

Dimitar Berov - marine ecologist working at the Laboratory of Marine Ecology at IBER-BAS. For ten years he has been studying the Black Sea ecosystems along the Bulgarian coast.

Velizara Stoilova - marine biologist who has a Master degree in Animal Behavior at Queens University, Belfast. She has worked on numerous projects exploring whale and dolphin behavior. 

Remove Remove Productions - a film production company, based in Sofia, Bulgaria. Super passionate about filmmaking and creating astonishing audio-visual products. They get inspired by nature, awesome people and causes.

 

 

Yavor Kolev - the captain of the crew and will be in charge of the main safety vessel during the WIND2WIN Challenge. Sailor with many years of experience, former sailing national coach, leading coach of the Bulgarian sailing Olympic team.

Akasha Surf School - the main organizer of the 300 km maritime challenge. Akasha Surf started in 2014 on the Black Sea shore, in order to promote all water sports in Bulgaria. The teachers in the different disciplines are athletes and professionals with many years of practice.

Surfrider Foundation Sofia - part of the international non-governmental organization Surfrider Foundation Europe. Their activities are dedicated to the protection of oceans, seas, beaches, and people who love them.

Maya Ivanova - WIND2WIN's graphic designer. Captured by the magic of flying, she is a passionate paragliding pilot. A Master student of the Polytechnic University in Milan – specialty Product Service System Design program.

 

What we need

Making the Black Sea cleaner is not an easy task and is connected with a lot of expenses and a huge team of professionals. We've already gathered a super-crew, but we still lack enough resources to complete our goals.

 

 

Any donations gathered through our Indiegogo campaign will be dedicated to filmmaking, organizing and doing the WIND2WIN Challenge and the study along the coast.

The key points that would require funding in this project are:

  • Getting high-quality filming equipment, water-safety camera gear and covering post-production costs - 45%;
  • Other expenses, such as: sports and safety equipment, fuel for boats, food, accommodation, etc. - 30%;
  • Covering expenses for conducting the water study - 20%
  • Expenses for the beach cleaning event- 5%.

A documentary film is a pretty powerful way to raise awareness of the issue and to promote a more sustainable lifestyle. We want to spread the WIND2WIN movie and its cause across local and foreign film festivals, TV channels and online.

Your contribution to the cause will help kick out the plastics off the oceans and the seas!

A PLASTIC FREE BLACK SEA is possible and it's up to all of us.

 

Other ways you can help

If you are unable to make a donation, just sharing this message will be truly smashing! 

Now, let's get to the beach!

 

Partners

 

                                                                      

 

            

 

  

 

Official website: http://wind2win.com/

Facebook: @wind2win

Instagram: wind2win_challenge 

Twitter: @wind2w

story:
Who Is Talking About Us 

 

See What Supporters Are Saying

“Every American woman is speaking for many women around the world who have no voice at all. Particularly with the way Christina Tobin is standing up with Free & Equal...” - MARIANNE WILLIAMSON

“I salute Christina Tobin of Free & Equal for what she and the Foundation are doing to reform our electoral process.” - LARRY KING

“ I am impressed by the work of the Free & Equal Elections Foundation, and commend them for their leadership on this issue.” - RON PAUL

“I am very appreciative of the leadership, integrity and understanding Free & Equal has of the flaws within the system and feel they’re ready to challenge those flaws and turn the system so it works with the people.”​  - DENNIS KUCINICH​

“I support the Free and Equal Elections Foundation and the important work they are accomplishing in making our society more open and free.”​ - DAVID BRONNER

"Free and Equal Rocks!”​ - BEN COHEN & JERRY GREENFIELD 

 

 

United We Stand Festival

A Socially Conscious Festival For Humankind

In the wake of Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma and Hurricane Maria, Free & Equal Elections Foundation needs your help to raise $15,000 for our 4th Annual United We Stand Fest at the University of Houston in December.

Because of your support, you've helped us raise over 100% of our campaign goals for the past three years in a row, taking the United We Stand Fest across the country!

Christina Tobin and members of Free and Equal Elections Foundation have roots in Houston, TX and made it a priority to bring the United We Stand Fest home to help -  at a time when Americans are more divided than ever. 

 

 

A Small Group of Freedom Seekers With
a Track Record of Making Change Happen

Free and Equal Elections Foundation 501(c)(3) non-profit, non-partisan organization whose mission is to broaden electoral choices with education and direct positive action from people just like you.

Free and Equal Elections Foundation was founded in 2008 by Christina Tobin, an American activist and leader in the election reform and protecting your right to vote.

Free and Equal hosted the 2012 Presidential Debate moderated by Larry King and received global media coverage with over 20+ million people who have watched Free & Equal's debates. 

We are proud to share with you that we hosted the first-ever US Presidential Debates in 2008, 2012, and 2016.

There's no other organization that has ever opened a public forum to ALL major candidates running for President. 

 

 

How You Can Make A Difference For Hurricane Victims

You may have been searching for the best way you can help the victims in Houston and beyond....

You may have already donated to a relief fund, but feel there's still so much more you can do...

You may have already attended one of our festivals and felt the incredible energy around you...

And even though our past festivals have been incredible successes - bringing in thousands of attendees who drove cross-country to attend - this is all about improving the quality of life for residents of Houston and Hurricane affected areas. 

With your contribution, you will help lead the charge for Houston relief efforts and unite together.

But that's not all:

  • You Will Help Open Donation Booths Ready to Accept Donations
  • You Will Help Send Needed Supplies and Goods to Hurricane Victims in Need
  • You Will Lift the Spirits of Residents with Conscious Musicians and Influencers
  • You Can Stream the United We Stand Fest LIVE Online to Reach More People

You can lock arms with us during this time of humanitarian need and crisis.

 

 

Here's How Your Funds Will Be Spent

The University of Houston’s campus received damages from Hurricane Harvey. While the faculty and staff are working diligently to host the United We Stand Fest, we've estimated $10,507 of contributions will be used for the production expenses at Cullen Performance Hall. 

Here's the breakdown for you:

  1. RENT - $2,000.00
  2. SECURITY - $360.00
  3. LABOR - $5,110.00
  4. PRODUCTION - $1,910.00
  5. TICKETING - $250.00
  6. EQUIPMENT - $99.00

TOTAL: $9,729.00
ADMIN FEE (8%) $778.32
EXPENSES: $10,507.32

Total costs estimated to run the event are $15,000.

The remaining funds you help us raise will be donated to directly impact the lives affected by these record-breaking natural disasters.

You can help make this campaign the success it needs to be by donating today so that we can provide humanitarian aid to thousands of people who need it.

 

 

100% of Net Profit Proceeds Will Be Used for
Hurricane Harvey, Irma, and Maria Relief Efforts 

This campaign will be ran until the week after the festival to allow you enough time to donate to a worthy cause.  Free and Equal Elections Foundation members are already on the ground in Houston doing what they can to help, and we encourage you to do the same!  

As you have seen, the aftermath of these storms forced people out of their homes, caused them to lose their jobs, and ultimately their lives. 

You will help give thousands of victims hope for a better tomorrow, contributing to Houstonian's ongoing needs and uniting for one beautiful cause in the heart of Houston. 

Each day will be a challenge to rebuild lives, homes, and infrastructure that's been lost. But when you unite with us, you will be helping us help the victims of these disasters on the ground.

Your contribution will also help us raise money towards Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma, and Hurricane Maria victims in a way that will also lift their spirit. 

 

 

How You Can Get Involved Now

You can get involved by pledging to our campaign, spreading the word by sharing this movement within your networks, or by volunteering in a community devastated by these natural disasters. 

Every effort you make counts towards the well-being of others in dire need, for today it is us and tomorrow it could be you. 

You can help us make the United We Stand Fest for Hurricane Harvey, Irma, and Maria in Houston a huge success - one that you can stand for and be proud of!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, we are Seth Quansah and Nathan Pritzker, co-Founders of Alchemy Alternative Energy (AAE). After a number of business experience years in Ghana, we were struck by the environmental conditions that severely affects the nation and most importantly the people of Ghana. After thorough research and studies, we realized the amount of plastic wastes in Ghana will reach a point where it will become a national threat and its devastating contributions towards health crises such as malaria and cholera. We only have one goal and one goal only! Our goal is to minimize the massive plastic wastes in Ghana through an environmental sound way.

We believe that incentivizing the people of Ghana to pick up plastics in their neighborhoods, schools, communities, churches, businesses etc. will reduce the number of plastic wastes and will produce the guaranteed, expected result. The problem in most communities is that no one is readily motivated to get rid of these plastics, and even if they do such plastics are not processed in the most environmentally sound/efficient manner. Most, if not all, are burned in the open air.

Simply put: 

  • Your contributions will help motivate more plastic wastes pick up
  • Our ask amount will ensure more than 200 tons of plastics to be picked from the environment to be processed by our company into reusable energy

With more than 50% of Ghanaians living in the urban settings, you will be touching millions with your contributions. We are confident that with your help, we can begin to change lives and eventually a nation of 25 million as a whole!

What We Need & What You Get

We need your financial contribution to spark our Plastic Purchasing Program. Anywhere from $10 to $10,000. All monies will be used to pay locals who pick up a required amount of plastic wastes. An equivalent of $50 can purchase about a ton of plastic wastes. Even if we do not meet our entire goal, we will be happy to use the amount to get as much plastic wastes as possible.

Been to a subsaharan West African country with rich history and culture yet?Contributors will receive unique, local Ghanaian artifacts, trinkets, and textiles up to a free round trip and a fully-guided tour in Ghana (based on the amount given).

The Impact

Have you ever experienced flooding after a few inches of rain? Or been to a country where malaria and cholera are among the top categories of mortality rate? Perhaps, in the developed world this may sound quite strange; however, this is the reality in a place like Ghana. We are an organization trying to respond to an evolving problem in one of the fastest growing economies in Africa. In the past, we have helped employ young women and men through our hair salon and construction ventures. This time around, we are not only employing 100s of people but also keeping the environment cleaner, healthier, and minimizing the risk factors for malaria and cholera. You contribution will incredibly impact lives and we are happy you will be part of this groundbreaking effort.

Risks & Challenges

Our only risk in this project is perhaps not being able to pay entirely for the innumerable plastic wastes in the environment. We have worked really hard to secure high plastic wastes centers in an effort to purchase such plastics once we receive funding. We have great relationships with the local people and hope to generate a social movement of removing plastics from the environment among the people of Ghana. Overall, we have minimized our risks to almost nothing because we understand the importance of placing value for the money given for this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot assist AAE financially at this time, PLEASE spread the word. We want other people to know about what we are doing to support our efforts. Share on your Facebook page, Twitter, Tumblr, College sites, Organizations among others. The indiegogo share tools are available for your use! Thank you!

AAE Team

story:
Soon a free-flowing river integral to the way of life for 14 percent of Peru's population will be dammed.[1] There are more than 8 mega dams planned for the Marañón River, which runs through 10 distinct regions of Peru, including the homes of Andean peasants, indigenous Amazon peoples, riparian populations and urban communities. At least 100,000 "ribereños" (river people) rely on its water and land resources for food and income. Another 600,000 Peruvians live nearby. [2]

The Chadin II Dam, the most advanced of the dams proposed, would flood 20 towns and displace close to 1,000 people. These communities grow papayas, bananas, oranges, lemons, mangoes and coca leaf, which they transport on mules to sell in bigger towns in the Province of Cajamarca.[3]

These dams are being built in the "national interest.” Much of the electricity will be used for mining operations to the southwest, like the Conga mine in the Cajamarca region. Some of the electricity will be sold to Brazil. [4]

These dams will no doubt generate income for the Peruvian government. But at what cost?

Why Should You Help?

Peruvians living in the high Andes along the river, where Chadin II will be located, have a good life. They have abundant food, enough money to send their children to school, and plenty of free time to enjoy the river. Some own property, and if they’re forced off their lands, they will at least get compensated. But many don’t own land, and Chadin II will affect these people the most, forcing many to move into the cities where they will be driven into a life of poverty.

Damming the headwaters of the Andean Amazon to provide electricity and secure water for large mining companies is just not worth the cost. For the people, and for the environment as well. The region is home to over 64 bird species of “conservation importance,” 24 endemic to the region. [5]  The free-flowing Marañón carries nutrient-rich waters to lowland areas, providing lush habitats for birds, plants, fish, and water and land species. Gray and pink dolphins, Amazonian manatees, giant river otters, black caimans and giant South American river turtles are all at risk if these dams get built.  Land species at risk include jaguars, capuchin monkeys and spider monkeys.[2] 

So What Am I Going To Do About It?

Well, go rafting of course! The Marañón canyon is not only one of the most biodiverse regions on Earth. It also happens to be one of the best locations in the world for rafting. In May, I’m volunteering with Paddling with Purpose to take a group of ten young Peruvians from the dam-affected villages of Tupen Grande, Mendan and Balsas on a 19-day rafting expedition down the Marañón. 

We hope participants in this expedition will become local ambassadors for the recreational use of the river and take "leave no trace" ideas back to their own communities. For those interested, we will begin teaching the skills needed to become a river guide. This informal training is the first step in opening up pathways and opportunities to professional work if they desire to pursue it.

Ultimately, the main project goals are to:

-  Create stronger networks between effected communities, the rest of Peru & growing tourism on this river

- Share an understanding of the larger environmental impacts of these dams

-  Create pathways for locals to become involved in tourism

This expedition is part of a larger growing movement to bring awareness and expand the conversation about the impacts of damming in this area. Our purpose is not to fight the battle, but to assist however we can. 

Paddling with Purpose projects are being completed under the umbrella of Conservamos por Naturaleza (CNX), an initiative of the Peruvian NGO, "Peruvian Society for Environmental Law," that seeks to inspire Peruvians to explore and protect Peru. We also have a partnership with US based non profit Sierra Rios. If you would like to make a tax exempt donation, please enquire how.

What We Need & What It's Used For

I am part of a small team of volunteers donating our time and energy to this expedition. By eating simple meals, using volunteer guides and gear donated (generously!) from Sierra Rios, we have greatly reduced the cost of this expedition.  However, we still need your help! Each of us will be paying our own fare to Peru, so every dollar donated on this site goes to the actual funding of the expedition.

Cost Breakdown:

Equipment Hire

$4,000

Transport

$3,000

Food

$2,000

My personal goal is to raise $3,000. If any of us falls short of our fundraising goals, we will have to cut our expedition down to 12 days or invite a smaller group of participants. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, share my campaign on facebook or like and share the facebook pages of Paddling with Purpose and Conservamos por Naturaleza. Go on a rafting trip in the US and learn how dams affect the ecosystems of the United States or even go and visit the Marañón yourself! 

Thank you for your help and your support!

[1] http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10....

[2] http://www.internationalrivers.org/campaigns/mara%C3%B1%C3%B3n-river

[3] http://www.internationalrivers.org/resources/8331

[4] http://lab.org.uk/peru-el-maranon-the-environment-communities-and-rivers-be-damned

[5]http://www.abcbirds.org/newsandreports/special_...

story: Our trip was cut out of our plans. We need the money to help fund it again. When we found out we couldn't go on the trip, due to tragic personal problems, our mental states went awry. We needed this trip as an outlet. Us four best friends whom have never met each other really need this trip to make up for all of the bad times in our lives.

story:
I have been accepted to join the Opwall 2015 expedition to Guyana to study the regeneration of the forest, surveying and monitoring the immense diversity of flora and fauna in the sustainable use areas, protected primary rainforest and river tributaries that make up most of the land mass of this small South American country in the heart of the Guiana Shield. The data collected on this expedition will be used to protect the rainforest and the livelihoods of the local Guyanese people in a sustainable way. 


Operation Wallacea or Opwall  run conservation management and biological research programmes in some of the most inaccessible locations on Earth. From identifying areas in need of urgent protection to the implementation of management schemes, the organisation is involved in all aspects of environmental conservation. Opwall have published a plethora of scientific papers in peer reviewed journals and are responsible for the discovery of many exciting new species records and even new species to science, of these include an incredible 30 new vertebrates and the rediscovery of 3 species previously believed to be extinct!


I am currently studying Zoology at The University of Sheffield and will use this expedition to better understand the dynamics of this hyperdiverse ecosystem and gain invaluable skills in data collection and tropical forest research methods such as mist netting for birds and bats, point counting for herpetofauna and setting up remote research camps that will be implemented in further projects whilst in study and in my career.

Money raised for this cause will be used for tuition fees, accommodation, food, on ground transport costs, field equipment and flights to and from Guyana. Without your help this would not be a possibility and I am truly grateful for any of your donations!

Thank-you for your time,

Daniel O'Neill

From Opwall:

Dear Sir/Madam

Volunteer ID: 160362  Name: Daniel O’Neill Expedition: Guyana 2015

This is to confirm that Daniel O’Neill has been accepted to join an Operation Wallacea expedition in 2015. Our volunteers are encouraged to fundraise to cover the costs of this expedition, which includes field support staff, local accommodation, food and transport costs, field equipment and flights. In order to raise sufficient funds they will be undertaking specific fundraising activities and any support or help you could offer would be extremely welcome.

Operation Wallacea is a biodiversity and conservation management research organisation running projects in Indonesia, Honduras, Cuba, South Africa, Madagascar, Romania, Peru, Guyana, and Mexico. The research is carried out in conjunction with academics from many European and North American Universities with over 200 academic staff in the field each survey season. Whilst Operation Wallacea provides the research data the Operation Wallacea Trust (charity number 1078362) then uses this data to implement conservation management programmes.

Amongst the recent achievements of Operation Wallacea and the Operation Wallacea Trust are:

· Used the existing data sets gathered from Honduras, Madagascar and South Africa to correlate species distributions with habitat and satellite derived environmental variables to then predict distributions across much larger areas. This collaboration is being carried out with the Oxford University Biodiversity Research Centre to then develop biodiversity performance criteria for the UN REDD scheme which is designed to make payments to governments and communities to prevent deforestation.

· Discovered 30 new species of vertebrates to science and 3 species previously thought to have been extinct.

· Funded 26 PhD studentships covering differing aspects of biodiversity and conservation management research.

· Established marine research centres in each of the major oceans including one in the Indo-Pacific which is the most productive in terms of published research in SE Asia.

· Introduced standardised stereo video monitoring of reef fish communities and video transects of benthic communities in marine sites in the Indo-Pacific, Indian and Caribbean Oceans.

· Developed a sustainable reef fishery management project in Indonesia that is designed to work by buying out surplus fishing effort on the reefs by offering shares in a business in exchange for surrendering reef fishing licences. The business being developed to fund the buy outs is the extraction of carrageenan from the seaweed farming activities that already exist.

· Packaged real-life data sets from Operation Wallacea expeditions for use in the classroom in order to develop understanding of biodiversity science issues amongst young people around the world. This project, called the Wallace Resource Library, is now in use in over 500 schools around the world.

It is only with the continued participation of students such as Daniel that we will be able to develop and advance our work. Daniel is being given a unique opportunity to take part in this experience of a lifetime whilst undertaking vital conservation work for Operation Wallacea and the local community and I can only ask once again that you would consider supporting such an important project. If you have any questions or queries about any aspect of Operation Wallacea and would like some additional information, please do not hesitate to contact us at the Operation Wallacea office or check out our website at www.opwall.com.

Yours faithfully

Pippa Disney

Operation Wallacea
story_txt: I have been accepted to join the Opwall 2015 expedition to Guyana to study the regeneration of the forest, surveying and monitoring the immense diversity of flora and fauna in the sustainable use areas, protected primary rainforest and river tributaries that make up most of the land mass of this small South American country in the heart of the Guiana Shield. The data collected on this expedition will be used to protect the rainforest and the livelihoods of the local Guyanese people in a sustainable way. Operation Wallacea or Opwall  run conservation management and biological research programmes in some of the most inaccessible locations on Earth. From identifying areas in need of urgent protection to the implementation of management schemes, the organisation is involved in all aspects of environmental conservation. Opwall have published a plethora of scientific papers in peer reviewed journals and are responsible for the discovery of many exciting new species records and even new species to science, of these include an incredible 30 new vertebrates and the rediscovery of 3 species previously believed to be extinct!I am currently studying Zoology at The University of Sheffield and will use this expedition to better understand the dynamics of this hyperdiverse ecosystem and gain invaluable skills in data collection and tropical forest research methods such as mist netting for birds and bats, point counting for herpetofauna and setting up remote research camps that will be implemented in further projects whilst in study and in my career.Money raised for this cause will be used for tuition fees, accommodation, food, on ground transport costs, field equipment and flights to and from Guyana. Without your help this would not be a possibility and I am truly grateful for any of your donations!Thank-you for your time,Daniel O'NeillFrom Opwall:Dear Sir/MadamVolunteer ID: 160362  Name: Daniel O’Neill Expedition: Guyana 2015This is to confirm that Daniel O’Neill has been accepted to join an Operation Wallacea expedition in 2015. Our volunteers are encouraged to fundraise to cover the costs of this expedition, which includes field support staff, local accommodation, food and transport costs, field equipment and flights. In order to raise sufficient funds they will be undertaking specific fundraising activities and any support or help you could offer would be extremely welcome.Operation Wallacea is a biodiversity and conservation management research organisation running projects in Indonesia, Honduras, Cuba, South Africa, Madagascar, Romania, Peru, Guyana, and Mexico. The research is carried out in conjunction with academics from many European and North American Universities with over 200 academic staff in the field each survey season. Whilst Operation Wallacea provides the research data the Operation Wallacea Trust (charity number 1078362) then uses this data to implement conservation management programmes.Amongst the recent achievements of Operation Wallacea and the Operation Wallacea Trust are:· Used the existing data sets gathered from Honduras, Madagascar and South Africa to correlate species distributions with habitat and satellite derived environmental variables to then predict distributions across much larger areas.
