story:
In A Nutshell

An estimated 14 billion pounds of trash is dumped into the ocean each year worldwide. That's about 38 million pounds per day! To say trash is an epic global problem is an understatement, and it's NOT just a coastal issue. The trash is coming from everywhere and every one. In the US alone, 246 million pounds of plastic is consumed on a daily basis. About 24 million pounds of that ends up in the ocean each day! H2O Trash Patrol was founded with the mission to reduce the amount of trash in the waterways and oceans through actively cleaning up waterways and spreading awareness of this overwhelming man-made problem. That's why we're setting out Summer 2014 on a national marine debris awareness campaign called the 50-50-50 State Challenge, where we will be doing 50 waterway cleanups in 50 states in 50 days! And the awareness doesn't stop there! We are also making a documentary of the entire trip to show that there is marine trash in every state and that you don't need to live near the ocean to be affected by it. That way the message can reach tens of thousands more people. And by spreading the awareness, we can make an even bigger impact on reducing the amount of trash that makes it into the oceans each year.

The Impact

The oceans are vitally important to all life on Earth, by providing over 70% of the oxygen we breathe and formulating our atmosphere. We also depend on the ocean for seaweed, fish, sea salt, minerals, and carrageenan (a byproduct of algae to thicken our toothpastes and ice creams), just to name a few. The mission of the 50-50-50 Challenge is to raise the awareness of marine debris, how much trash we make per household, and how making one simple change in our daily lives, we can make a huge impact on reducing the amount of trash that makes it into our waterways and oceans.

We have had lots of local success with the marine debris removal as well as the educational awareness program in local schools. And we know this Challenge will be a huge success too!

Our film crew is ready to take on the challenge of documenting all of our travels and developing the documentary DVD. And the H2O Trash Patrol crew is dedicated, gearing up, and really excited for the intense adventure of traveling to all 50 states, conducting 50 waterway cleanups, all in 50 days! We invite everyone to meet up with us on our travels, which will be trackable daily on our Tumblr blog.

What We Need & What You Get

Although this is our first national campaign, currently we have the product support of national companies like Boardworks Surf, GoPro, Body Glove, Nutrex BioAstin, and Quiksilver. And now we are looking for the financial support through campaigns like this Indiegogo campaign, because toilet paper and gas isn't free. :) Seriously though, to make this a success, there are things we really need money for: transportation, gas, food, airfare, hotel, film production costs, and DVD replication. Product sponsors are welcome for those items, for sure! In the meantime, here's the breakdown of the estimated budget:

$50,000 Recreational Vehicle (sleeps min. 5-6) to drive through the lower 48 States, rental or purchase;

$20,000 worth of gasoline;

$10,000 roundtrip airfare and hotels to fly The Challenge crew to Alaska and Hawaii to complete the final two waterway cleanups;

$ 5,000 food, cleanup gear, and incidentals; and

$20,000 film production and DVD creation/replication.

And as a HUGE THANK YOU! We've added some great, fun perks! We have things like the finished DVD with YOUR name in the credits, SUP Lessons and Board Rentals, a One Simple Change reusable bag from Chico Bags filled with all kinds of reusable and eco-friendly goodies to help you reduce your trash output, and one amazing limited edition signed Wyland Lithograph! And imagine...all this AND it's tax-deductible!!! As perks run out or more sponsors come on board, we will add more Thank You perks, so please check back often and donate more!

You can stay updated by our full progress on our Tumblr blog. And should we not meet our entire budget on this particular campaign, you can feel safe in knowing that we will be undertaking this Challenge one way or another. And your donation will still go toward making it all happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can’t contribute, doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Share this with your friends and help us get the word out.

  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

The health of our oceans and our Earth depends on you. And that’s all there is to it.
story_txt:
In A NutshellAn estimated 14 billion pounds of trash is dumped into the ocean each year worldwide. That's about 38 million pounds per day! To say trash is an epic global problem is an understatement, and it's NOT just a coastal issue. The trash is coming from everywhere and every one. In the US alone, 246 million pounds of plastic is consumed on a daily basis. About 24 million pounds of that ends up in the ocean each day! H2O Trash Patrol was founded with the mission to reduce the amount of trash in the waterways and oceans through actively cleaning up waterways and spreading awareness of this overwhelming man-made problem. story:
SourceURL:file:///Crowdriser.doc

Swim for Sharks is a non profit shark protection campaign using a short film aimed at limiting shark finning and the shark fin trade. The funding used to complete an effective film to promote shark awareness and save sharks from extinction. The film will help us reach a broad audience through promotion at film festivals, schools and on social media to promote shark and ocean awareness.

Help Shark Stewards Campaign to ban the Shark Fin Trade.

The campaign will continue with a second Swim for Sharks around Alcatraz Island as a fundraiser and awareness event in October 2013 and a joint Swim For Sharks in Hong Kong.

Fine Cut Receives Acclaim at San Francisco International Ocean Film Festival!

Shot, produced and directed by award winning shark conservationists and filmmakers David McGuire and Christina Choate, this HD film will be widely distributed and used to advance ourshark fin trade campaigns in the USA and abroad.

Why Swim for Sharks?

A new study suggests as many as 100 MILLION sharks are killed for their fins  each year to supply the shark fin trade for the delicacy shark fin soup. The rate of fishing is unsustainable and shark populations are plummeting worldwide. Over one hundred species of sharks are threatened with extinction by overfishing and the shark fin trade. Sharks need our help. Watch the Trailer and learn more.

Where Does the Money Go?

Funding will be used to purchase rights to stock footage, images and music rights and compensate our editor  Additionally funds will help us finalize and market the film at events such as our Texas and East Coast campaigns and Hong Kong this year.

See the film at  our annual Sharktober celebration in October 2013.

If that doesn’t float your boat, contributors to this film will help promote ocean health by protecting sharks. Help us continue building on our successes stopping the shark fin trade in California and other US States, by taking the message to Hong Kong, where over half of shark fins are traded.

If we don’t make our goal  we will swim for sharks again next Octtober. 

If You Can’t Swim, Shout out for Sharks

Spreading the word on social media with links and share with your friends.   Please, build on our campaign victories and award winning documentaries to influence policy and the world to protect sharks.

story:
What is Plantagon?

PLANTAGON is a new and modern kind of company with maximum competitiveness, building on good corporate citizenship, transparency and democratic values. It is comprised of two different legal entities in one organization working for the same cause: One profit-driven, commercial organization (PLANTAGON International AB) and one non-profit organization (PLANTAGON Non-profit Association). The company, for the time being, focuses on the Plantagon® greenhouse that will dramatically change the way we produce ecological and functional food. It allows us to produce ecologically with clean air and water inside urban environments, even major cities, cutting costs and environmental damage by eliminating transportation, delivering food daily and directly to consumers. The non-profit organization owns 10% of the company and nominates 50% of its board members. Membership of the non-profit organization is open to everyone who supports its objectives, and the company has no influence over it.


What is the Plantagon Member Project?

The Plantagon Member Project is an opportunity to reward actively engaged members in creating and managing their own projects (SEE: Sepher's system for Bak Choi and Tilapia) in relation to Plantagon's mission and vision. By participating in this campaign, newly recruited members will have the chance to compete for internships, externships, or become Certified Plantagon Ambassadors. Sponsors will get exclusive trainings in the latest in Corporate Social Responsibility tools and metrics. A select number of participants will be able to travel to Stockholm, Sweden or other locations internationally in the execution of their activities.

The Impact 

This may be the first time in the business sector that social responsibility, transparency and sharing are demonstrably valued at the same level as financial engagement. This may be the first opportunity to influence a large company from the inside without being an employee, a manager or an investor, but by being socially engaged in supporting its mission. This may be the first organization to show that sharing rather than greed leads to financial success in the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Join the conversation today: 

Plantagon Facebook Twitter Linkedin Pinterest Instagram 

For more info check out plantagon.com, feedingthecity.com, or contact: 

 Yusuf Abdul-Qadir: yusuf.abdul-qadir@plantagon.com

Justine Clerc: justine.clerc@plantagon.com

Elizabeth Mariani: elizabeth.mariani@plantagon.com

story:
Short Summary

The Sea Turtle Incubation Greenhouse in Todos Santos is the only one of its kind! It is used to Incubate critically endangered Leatherback nests in Todos Santos Mexico, where cold sand temperatures create very low hatch rates.  Without our project thousands of Leatherback eggs would just rot on the beach here. 

Our team is committed to making this project a success, but we lack the funding to do it correctly.  The cost of Gasoline for running patrols alone is $3,000 each season. That is what we are trying to raise here.   

There is also the expense of ATV maintenance, educational supplies, temperature sensors, beach signs, communications, and field tools.  We are depending on donations to make this project a reality. Any amount you can give is extremely appreciated!

Thank you.

The Impact!

The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on our planet.  Without balance in the Pacific, eco-systems suffer and colapse.  Eventually this suffering is passed on to us when we eat seafood, play in the ocean, take our children to the beach, or consume any ocean derived product. 

Fishing methods have wiped out 90% of the Pacific Leatherback population.  Without this top predator in the ocean, sea jelly populations explode, killing smaller fish and fish eggs. Remove the Leatherback from the Pacific and fish populations will follow.  the Pacific will become a jellyfish/invertebrate/plastic mush.  What will happen to us? This project actually benefits mankind as balancing the Pacific is essential to our health and survival.

What else?

Our education programs empower youth by including them in the development and implementation of programs that protect nesting habitat, maximize hatching, and reduce the amount of plastic and other pollutants that are ending up in the ocean.  The future is in the hands of our children and we are dedicated to empowering them!

Other Ways You Can Help!

Buy line caught fish, nets kill sea turtles.  Support local economies in sea turtle nesting communities to reduce the need for poaching meat and eggs.  Never pour motor oil down storm drains, it ends up in the ocean.  Buy organic produce, pesticide runoff ends up in the ocean and harms marine life.  Pass this info on!

Reduce your use of plastics because they are ending up in the ocean! Use stainless steel water bottles, and filter your own water!  Refuse plastic bags at check out, refuse styrofoam containers as take out containers, keep your own food containers or paper bags in you car for leftovers or take out.  

At home, use paper lunch bags in bathroom waste baskets, compost your orgainc kitchen waste.  Don't buy plastic bags to bag up your organic lawn waste! Try making it into a compost which is very useful for your garden!

Please post this on your facebook, tweeter, or website, or share the link with your friends and family.

Please Help if You Can!

story:
KEF's Story

The Kentucky Environmental Foundation (KEF) is a non-profit organization, which for 20 years has promoted positive solutions to the health, safety and environmental problems we all face, by working for community consensus and direct involvement in government decision making. 

The Impact

The Kentucky Environmental Foundation is well-known in many communities throughout Kentucky. We are the non-profit organization that in 2002 achieved an unprecedented victory by defeating Army plans to burn the chemical weapons stored at the Blue Grass Army Depot in Madison County. Instead, a safer, more controlled neutralization facility to destroy the weapons is currently under construction. 

More recently in 2010, KEF was instrumental in defeating plans to build a dirty coal-fired power plant in Clark County KY. With that victory came a unique collaboration between community organizations and KY energy cooperatives, working together to find safe and effective alternatives to burning coal.

Without the ongoing efforts of this small non-profit organization located in Berea KY, the health and safety of Kentucky's environment and our communities would be more greatly compromised.  

What We Need & What You Get

The $3000 KEF will raise through our IndieGoGo Campaign will help us fund the following projects:

  • new educational materials for Kentucky parents on creating safe and healthy toxic-free homes and communities $800;
  • research into the health impacts of the continued use of coal-fired power plants in Kentucky in order to produce a health impact statement $1200;
  • increased advocacy for state and federal policies that encourage energy efficiency & the use of safe, energy sources $500; and
  • increased community participation in the environmental and economic decisions surrounding the chemical weapons neutralization process at the Blue Grass Army Depot $500.
For your generous donation to this unique and vital organization you will receive the following.
  • All donors will get a link to KY author Silas House reading his latest short story.
  • $35 donation -- a stainless steel water bottle.
  • $50 donation -- a water bottle and your name put into a raffle for a package of autographed books by notable KY authors including Silas House, Nikky Finney, Maurice Manning, C.E. Morgan and Erik Reese.
  • $100 donation -- a water bottle, a book by internationally renowned KY author Wendell Berry and a music CD by KY cellist Ben Sollee. 

Other Ways You Can Help

KEF is always looking for volunteers. Call us at 859-986-0868 or visit us in Berea at 128 Main Street and we will gladly find ways in which you can participate in our projects. You can write letters, you can make phone calls, you can do research.

story:
Who I am

I’m Dr. Jordan Peterson, a professor at the University of Toronto, in Ontario, Canada, a clinical psychologist, and an essayist, panelist and lecturer for TVO. You can find out more about what I do, if you like, at www.mapsofmeaning.com. Over the last year, I have had the privilege to work with an international committee that is trying to chart a course to a better future, and we are trying to figure out exactly how to do that.

We believe that we have to start with projects that are clearly possible, do not require too many simultaneous participants, have important short, medium and long-term benefits, and will be supported, from the bottom up, by large numbers of committed citizens. Pushing from the top down does not seem to work particularly well, as the somewhat limited successes of the recent Rio conference and the previous Copenhagen Climate Change conference demonstrate.

Obviously, there are a number of problems, of global significance, that confront us. We have been making decent progress on some of them. A far smaller percentage of people live in absolute poverty now than ten years ago; many more people have access to fresh water. Many tyrants have fallen, and AIDS has been brought under some control. Organizations such as the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation are working hard to eradicate the worst remaining diseases. We don’t really know how to solve some of the remaining problems, but we have pretty good models for others. Ocean management falls into the latter category, and it’s a truly important problem.

The Problem

The oceans are being exhausted at an extraordinary rate. We are rapidly fishing down the ecological chain, from large fish to small, using the most potent modern technology. We have already been reduced to harvesting jellyfish, which have become more numerous as the fish disappear. It is obvious to everyone that this is not smart and cannot continue. Some countries have already done something about it. The best example is Australia, which has already conserved about 20% of its total oceanic territory, and has promised, credibly, to preserve at least 20% more. This is a very difficult task, but the Australians have evidently mastered it. 

Canada, which has a very long coastline, like Australia, and which is similar, culturally, to Australia, has also promised to put aside 20% of its oceanic territory. We made this promise, in writing, before an international audience, in 1992, and 2002, and 2003, and 2005, but we still haven’t done anything about it.

Some Background

When the Europeans first arrived in Canada (or anywhere else in the West Hemisphere, for that matter), they encountered a near-miraculous bounty of oceanic and other natural life. We could have that back, if we wanted it – and why not? The oceans recover pretty quickly if you give them a chance. The North Sea fisheries recovered in the early 1940's, for example, because no one was fishing during the war. I have nothing against fisherman: to the contrary, I would love to see them back at work, pulling fish in like mad! But that isn’t going to happen, if we keep doing what we are doing.

The Proposition

It seems clear that the oceanic management problem is important and pressing. It also seems obvious that Canada should keep its promises. Finally, it appears that the Australians have already demonstrated that such promises can be kept (and rather quickly). In consequence, I want to start a PR campaign, to publicize Canada's lack of progress. I also want to invite the Australians to Canada for a conference so that they can tell us what they did, and how we could do it. Then I want to get it done -- with your help.

It has become obvious to everyone that National Parks on land are an excellent idea. What has become self-evident for terrestrial management should be self-evident for aquatic environments. Help me show that many people want this, and I will push as hard as I can to encourage the Canadian government to do the right thing – and quickly (and my friends on the committee I mentioned will help). But we can’t do it without the proper demonstration of public support, national and international (as the Australians recently demonstrated: http://bit.ly/OjoEnX

If you want to help restore the magnificent, beautiful and bountiful coastal and oceanic environments of North America, help us raise some money, and help us publicize the campaign, in whatever way you see fit. 

We would like the world to be a better place, and we are going to start here – if the public demand is there. I have started the campaign with a donation of a thousand dollars, with the support of my wife and my two children. I’m telling you this so you know that I am putting my money where my mouth is.

We will spend every cent we gather – every cent – to further this cause.  

Please also see: http://bit.ly/QfQp68, our Avaaz campaign, and add your signature.

A far smaller percentage of people live in absolute poverty now than ten years ago; many more people have access to fresh water. Many tyrants have fallen, and AIDS has been brought under some control. Organizations such as the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation are working hard to eradicate the worst remaining diseases. We don’t really know how to solve some of the remaining problems, but we have pretty good models for others. Ocean management falls into the latter category, and it’s a truly important problem.
The Problem
The oceans are being exhausted at an extraordinary rate. We are rapidly fishing down the ecological chain, from large fish to small, using the most potent modern technology. We have already been reduced to harvesting jellyfish, which have become more numerous as the fish disappear. It is obvious to everyone that this is not smart and cannot continue. Some countries have already done something about it. The best example is Australia, which has already conserved about 20% of its total oceanic territory, and has promised, credibly, to preserve at least 20% more. This is a very difficult task, but the Australians have evidently mastered it. 
Canada, which has a very long coastline, like Australia, and which is similar, culturally, to Australia, has also promised to put aside 20% of its oceanic territory. We made this promise, in writing, before an international audience, in 1992, and 2002, and 2003, and 2005, but we still haven’t done anything about it.
Some Background
When the Europeans first arrived in Canada (or anywhere else in the West Hemisphere, for that matter), they encountered a near-miraculous bounty of oceanic and other natural life. We could have that back, if we wanted it – and why not? The oceans recover pretty quickly if you give them a chance. The North Sea fisheries recovered in the early 1940's, for example, because no one was fishing during the war. I have nothing against fisherman: to the contrary, I would love to see them back at work, pulling fish in like mad! But that isn’t going to happen, if we keep doing what we are doing.
The Proposition
It seems clear that the oceanic management problem is important and pressing. It also seems obvious that Canada should keep its promises. Finally, it appears that the Australians have already demonstrated that such promises can be kept (and rather quickly). In consequence, I want to start a PR campaign, to publicize Canada's lack of progress. I also want to invite the Australians to Canada for a conference so that they can tell us what they did, and how we could do it. Then I want to get it done -- with your help.
It has become obvious to everyone that National Parks on land are an excellent idea. What has become self-evident for terrestrial management should be self-evident for aquatic environments. Help me show that many people want this, and I will push as hard as I can to encourage the Canadian government to do the right thing – and quickly (and my friends on the committee I mentioned will help). But we can’t do it without the proper demonstration of public support, national and international (as the Australians recently demonstrated: http://bit.ly/OjoEnX
If you want to help restore the magnificent, beautiful and bountiful coastal and oceanic environments of North America, help us raise some money, and help us publicize the campaign, in whatever way you see fit. 
We would like the world to be a better place, and we are going to start here – if the public demand is there. I have started the campaign with a donation of a thousand dollars, with the support of my wife and my two children. I’m telling you this so you know that I am putting my money where my mouth is.
We will spend every cent we gather – every cent – to further this cause.  
Please also see: http://bit.ly/QfQp68, our Avaaz campaign, and add your signature.

story:
Our Story

Any kind of plastic is hazardous to our environment. Nearly everybody may meanwhile know the 5 gigantic gyres of plastic bags, bottles and other items in our oceans. Most of them are made of polyesters. Polyester fibre is also extensively used to produce clothing. But most people are not aware that with each washing cycle hundreds of polyester fibres are entering the wast water. There are no filters to avoid that all these plastic fibres are washed into the oceans where fishes eat them, and so these fibres get into the food chain and are finally eaten by humans.

The challenge is to replace at least some of these synthetic fibres by natural fibres. One of the most valuable, soft, degradable and amazing fibre is produced by alpacas.

The textile industry needs tons of such fibres to make industrial production of yarns and fabrics meaningful. Unfortunately, simply not enough alpacas live on earth to produce this quality of fibre in sufficient quantity. One alpaca produces approximately 1.5 kg of this extremely fine fibre per year, and a female gives only birth to one baby alpaca, called cria, per year.

We, Wendy and Alfons, have a plan to increase the number of required animals substantially in just a few years - we intend to apply ET (Embryo Transfer).

And that is where we need your help. Funding an embryo transfer program is quite expensive, and we are in need of your support.

What are Alpacas?

For those who don’t know alpacas, alpacas (Vicugna pacos) are very cute animals originating from the Andes Mountains in South America, namely Peru, Bolivia and Chile. The animals live in high altitudes of more than 4,000 meters and have been domesticated already 4,000 - 5,000 years back by the indigenous population. Alpacas are herd animals and are very environmentally friendly. Alpacas are very undemanding: a green pasture in summer or some hay and grain in winter will be sufficient. They don’t destroy the grass by pulling the roots out, but they cut the grass. The soft feet pads don’t destroy the ground like hooves.

Alpacas have to be shorn once a year before the hot season and each “donates” 6 to 10 pounds of fleece. The best quality comes from the back and the sides. This is called the blanket and counts for three to four pounds.

The finest alpaca fibres are very valuable. Alpacas producing this extraordinary fibres are called VILYA (Vicuna-Like-Yarn-Alpaca).

In the 1990s the first alpacas in considerable numbers had been imported to Australia, New Zealand, America and later to Europe as well.

Alpaca Fibre

Because of extraordinary properties the wool or fleece has been used to weave or knit clothing for centuries. In Peru in ancient times only royals and clerics were allowed to wear clothing made of the finest fibres. They called it “The Fibre of God”.

Alpaca fibre is known for its softness. The very low diameter, slightly above 20 micron on average, of the fibre and the surface structure are responsible for the softness. It is hypoallergenic, so it is also suitable for people which are allergic to wool. It has excellent thermoregulatory properties due to the unique structure of the fibre. That makes it a perfect insulator. This means that the material is comfortable to wear in winter as well as in heat.

Alpaca wool is the second finest fibre on the planet, just second to Vicuna. It is finer than cashmere or merino, lighter and warmer than sheep's wool.

The fibre comes in 22 natural colours from white over various browns to grey and black. It can also be dyed easily and has a natural shine.

The Challenge

For very fine and soft yarn and fabrics we need alpaca fibres close to the diameter of vicuna fibre which is 12.5 micron on average. This alpaca wool doesn’t exist in sufficient amount to make industrial manufacturing meaningful. There are just not enough animals that produce the required fibre quality. The natural reproduction of such animals would take too long because of the low birth rate. A female alpaca will give birth to one cria, that’s how the baby-alpaca is called, per year.

The challenge is to build a herd of alpacas producing extraordinary fine fibres in short time to enable the textile industry to make very fine yarns and clothing.

Our Solution

We, Wendy and Alfons, tried to find a solution to narrow the gap between demand and supply and grow a big herd in just a few years. The solution is embryo transfer to improve the quality of our alpaca herd and multiply the birth rate.

At the age of  14 - 16 months a female alpaca is mature to get mated and become pregnant. Usually the pregnancy lasts for 11.5 months. Alpacas don’t have a hormonal cycle like women, but they have hormonal waves, which enable them to become pregnant again just two weeks after giving birth. 

Applying embryo transfer will improve the fertility rate substantially. Embryo transfer is well known from other species and is proven to work for alpacas as well.

The procedure is used to get many embryos from one very valuable female within one year. These embryos are transferred into a surrogate mother, while the biological or donor mother is ready to become pregnant again before the baby is even born. Instead of just one cria per year each donor alpaca will have 6 or 8 or even more crias year by year.

A female alpaca may give birth to six crias in one year by the help of surrogate mothers. If the baby is a female alpaca it will be ready to get pregnant after a little bit more than a year, and applying embryo transfer to this daughter will lead to another six crias again one year later. So if we apply ET to one female in summer 2018 this female will be the mother of six crias a year later. Usually three will be females, By 2019 we will have 4 females, 1 mature and 3 female cries. With the same procedure we will have (1 + 3) = 4 mature and 3 female crias in 2020 and 7 mature females and 12 female crias in 2021. Each of these female alpaca babies can be mated one year later, and another year later it will become the biological mother of 3 females. Year by year our number will increase exponentially.

Details of our ET program

Although, theoretically, ET is possible every 2 to 3 weeks, we plan to apply the procedure once a month not to demand too much of the donor animal. We will apply ET between May and September, expecting to collect at least one embryo per procedure. Our expectation is a success rate of 50% which will give us one live cria per two embryo transfers.

The procedures will be performed by an experienced veterinarian.

How we use your donations

We already purchased six extremely good animals, three females, and three males.

To start the project we are aiming for the following funding:

Budget (in US$)

1. Phase (2018/2019)

1,500        7 %        set up of a small lab

12,600    57 %        21 ET procedures in 2018 and 2019, $ 600/per ET

2,000        9 %        buy 10 surrogates

4,000       18 %       maintenance of animals, $ 200 per animal/year

2,000        9 %        insurance of donor animals/year

———-

22,100            total demand for the project

 

4,000                perks, incentives

1,400                5% IndieGoGo 

840                     3% payment processing fee

————

28,340            funding goal

 

Risks of the project

Dealing with animals and calculating success rates is always a challenge. In our project we might not be able to harvest the expected number of embryos per cycle. Even if we collect and transfer them, some may not be embedded into the womb of the surrogate mother and are not able to grow. Later during the progression of the pregnancy a miscarriage may occur. And even if crias are born and healthy the gender distribution of an individual donor may be different from 50/50 and effects the number of potential female donors a year later.

What qualifies us to run this project?

We, Wendy Niklaus and Dr. Alfons Grabosch, both have a professional medical background (nurse and surgeon) which helps us to care for the animals. Looking at the ET program, we can transfer a lot of knowledge from human medicine to alpacas. We did a lot of research during the last years.

Alfons has years of experience in management in addition. Working in the top management of  an insurance company he learned and could prove that he is able to manage complex projects.

Dr. Brian McOnie is not only an experienced veterinarian, who has his clinic near the ranch, but he is also familiar with embryo transfer programs. He is the former Vice-President of the Canadian Embryo Transfer Society.

Why should you support this project?

This is an environmentally friendly project! Alpacas are not only cute but absolutely environmentally friendly. They are producers of one of the finest natural fibres on earth. These fibres can replace at least a small portion of the environmentally hazardous polyester fibre used for clothing nowadays. The supply of this fibre is not sufficient to make industrial manufacturing meaningful. This project aims to start narrowing the gap between demand and current supply.

As a backer you support the development of a herd of environmentally friendly animals in a relatively short time. You help to build the foundation of a sound source of natural fibre. This is a “green” project!

As a backer you will join a community of people which express their interest and support of a healthy sustainable environment. You will get our newsletter with updates of the project and at least one article about alpacas, alpaca fibre and related topics monthly. 

FAQ

How does embryo transfer work? 

A female alpaca is mated naturally when a follicle is mature in the ovary. Alpacas are “induced ovulators", which means that the mating itself induces the release of an egg, or oocyst, out of the follicle. This egg will be fertilised on its way to the womb, the uterus, and an embryo evolves. An embryo is a mass of a few cells which can be seen under a microscope and will grow to become a baby.

A few days later the uterus is flushed with a solution and the embryo is collected or harvested - hopefully! The procedure is done when the animal gets a drug to sleep not to harm it. This embryo is then transferred into the womb of another female alpaca, again while the animal sleeps, and this alpaca will serve as a surrogate mother, becomes pregnant and will deliver the cria after 11.5 months. Meanwhile the biological mother is ready to become pregnant again after at least two weeks and can produce the next embryo, and so on.

How will the alpaca herd grow with ET over the next years?

We will start with 3 females and one top male in 2018. The breeding season starts in July and we decided to breed till September. Then the next year all cries will be born in summer making it more likely that they survive. Theoretically a donor female can be mated every 2 weeks. We plan to perform 6 ET procedures this year and 5 ETs per donor in the coming years. Based on a success rate of 50% and a gender distribution of 50/50 we can perform 15 ET procedures in 2019 and 30 in 2020 if we don’t add more donors to the herd. 

This will result in 12 alpacas in 2019, 19 alpacas in 2020, 34  in 2021  and  56 in 2022 out of the ET program. In 2023 we expect to have 104 high value animal.

The numbers are growing exponentially, and the numbers mentioned above are related to the animals out of the ET program. Of course we have to grow the number of surrogate mothers in parallel by buying them.

How do you care for the animals?

Most importantly, we love and respect our alpacas. They are not just fibre producers, but they are part of our lifestyle. We feed them every day and clean their pastures, and our medical background helps us to care for their health and wellbeing professionally.

Dr. Brian McOnie helps as a professional vet whenever necessary.

What happens if you don’t reach your target?

In case we don’t reach our target we can scale down the program at any time. The donations will not be lost.

What is your final target?

Our final goal is to build a herd of 500+ alpacas producing super fine fibres.

Perks we offer

To thank you for your donation we offer some perks all related to our project. All alpaca fleece items are handmade by ourselves. They are quite unique. This is why we ask you to be a little bit patient to get them. Depending on the demand we will make them and ship it to you.

We hope you support our campaign. If you have any further questions or comments don't hesitate to contact us: cokalranch.ca@gmail.com

story:
Eumelia is a sustainable organic agrotourism farm and guesthouse. It is located in the south of Greece, in the region of Laconia, near the village of Gouves. Eumelia was founded a few years back with great love both for nature and humans, with the aim to bring them again closer to their roots.

Our project, the Five Elements Ecological Pond aims to introduce water, the element of life in the whole region by creating a natural lake. Natural lakes are built by humans, however in such a respectful manner for environment that they require minimum intervention and maintenance once their ecosystem is fully developed. The Five Elements Ecological Pond guarantees there will be a water reserve in the dry region of Gouves during the prolonged summer months. It will improve the areas' sustainability and it will provide a refuge for small animals and birds that suffer when the rivers of Peloponnese dry due to climate change.

Great change needs great people. Creating the Five Elements Ecological Pond is a great challenge, for Eumelia and its community. We need you to be the great people that will support our amazing project!

The budget of our project is high because the creation of a natural lake mostly costs until it is built. Then nature takes over and in approximately two years time, once the ecosystem is fully developed, minimum intervention is needed with small running cost. So this is a long term investment with absolutely sustainable benefits.

Eumelia will provide the space for the creation of the natural lake and it has already secured the relevant necessary permissions for the project. Eumelia is committed that no ticket in any form will ever be required for those who want to visit the lake. It has always been our vision to help humans reconcile with nature and this lake is our dream to bring more people and the local community closer to it. For the sake of transparency Eumelia intends to publish full financial progress of the project on its website at any given time.

By donating to our project not only you get to be part of a magnificent team of people who believe in progress in a way that brings balance back to our lives but also you will enjoy our amazing organic perks! All products that come as a gift to you from Eumelia for your support are made in the land of Laconia, prepared with love and with the most pure and traditional recipes. Try our lavender soap, our extra virgin olive oil, the limited edition rose wine we prepared just for you and of course the unique experience of staying at the Eumelia guesthouse to see for yourselves what you helped build.

The Five Elements Ecological Pond will make a great difference for the whole region. It will be the only water resource in the continental landscape of Laconia during the summer months providing a safe refuge for small animals and birds, reducing temperature and of course creating a natural fire safety zone. It will become a meeting point and a new day trip destination, increasing the regions' touristic capital. The Five Elements Ecological Pond will always be open to the local community and organizations that wish to visit and coexist with Eumelia, exactly like it has been happening up to now.

The farm and the guesthouse of Eumelia will apparently benefit from the creation of the Five Elements Ecological Pond, significally improving business prospects. But as seen from the above mentioned facts, this is only a small part of the benefits that will result from the introduction of water, the element of life, in the area. At any time, you can visit Eumelia and see for your selves how you helped a whole region flourish. 

Indiegogo allows you to donate less than 25$ or more than 5.000$, even though our amazing organic perks come with fixed amounts. We will be equally thankful for every singe donation and each donation takes us a step closer to our vision!

But please also share our project with your family and friends. Upload it on Facebook, Tweet about it, help us built a warm community of supporters around the ecological pond of Eumelia. Be there when great change happens, be part of the evolution of Eumelia.


[please note that 1 dollar equals approximately 0.74 euro which means that our perks value: 25 dollars ~ 18.51 euros / 50 dollars ~ 37.03 euros / 100 dollars ~ 74.06 euros / 200 dollars ~ 148.12 euros / 500 dollars ~ 370.29 euros / 1.000 dollars ~ 740.58 / 5.000 dollars ~ 3.702.88 euros You can always donate from 1 dollar to any amount. Thank you for your support!]

Then nature takes over and in approximately two years time, once the ecosystem is fully developed, minimum intervention is needed with small running cost. So this is a long term investment with absolutely sustainable benefits.
Eumelia will provide the space for the creation of the natural lake and it has already secured the relevant necessary permissions for the project. Eumelia is committed that no ticket in any form will ever be required for those who want to visit the lake. It has always been our vision to help humans reconcile with nature and this lake is our dream to bring more people and the local community closer to it. For the sake of transparency Eumelia intends to publish full financial progress of the project on its website at any given time.
By donating to our project not only you get to be part of a magnificent team of people who believe in progress in a way that brings balance back to our lives but also you will enjoy our amazing organic perks! All products that come as a gift to you from Eumelia for your support are made in the land of Laconia, prepared with love and with the most pure and traditional recipes. Try our lavender soap, our extra virgin olive oil, the limited edition rose wine we prepared just for you and of course the unique experience of staying at the Eumelia guesthouse to see for yourselves what you helped build.


The Five Elements Ecological Pond will make a great difference for the whole region. It will be the only water resource in the continental landscape of Laconia during the summer months providing a safe refuge for small animals and birds, reducing temperature and of course creating a natural fire safety zone. It will become a meeting point and a new day trip destination, increasing the regions' touristic capital. The Five Elements Ecological Pond will always be open to the local community and organizations that wish to visit and coexist with Eumelia, exactly like it has been happening up to now.

The farm and the guesthouse of Eumelia will apparently benefit from the creation of the Five Elements Ecological Pond, significally improving business prospects. But as seen from the above mentioned facts, this is only a small part of the benefits that will result from the introduction of water, the element of life, in the area. At any time, you can visit Eumelia and see for your selves how you helped a whole region flourish. 



Indiegogo allows you to donate less than 25$ or more than 5.000$, even though our amazing organic perks come with fixed amounts. We will be equally thankful for every singe donation and each donation takes us a step closer to our vision!
But please also share our project with your family and friends. Upload it on Facebook, Tweet about it, help us built a warm community of supporters around the ecological pond of Eumelia. Be there when great change happens, be part of the evolution of Eumelia.

[please note that 1 dollar equals approximately 0.74 euro which means that our perks value: 25 dollars ~ 18.51 euros / 50 dollars ~ 37.03 euros / 100 dollars ~ 74.06 euros / 200 dollars ~ 148.12 euros / 500 dollars ~ 370.29 euros / 1.000 dollars ~ 740.58 / 5.000 dollars ~ 3.702.88 euros You can always donate from 1 dollar to any amount. Thank you for your support!]

story:
Tar Sands Speakers Tour
For every donation of $5.00 or more, you help us share the first hand stories of the environmental and human costs of tar sands extraction.

National Geographic Photographer Garth Lenz and First Nations Activists Crystal Lameman and Eriel Deranger are traveling throughout New England to share their powerful stories


The Problem: The development of tar sands oil in Alberta, Canada is one of the most environmentally destructive energy extraction projects ever on our planet. The production, transportation and use of tar sands oil is unacceptable, due to direct environmental impacts on air, soil and water and overall public health. This risk is further amplified by the profound acceleration of climate change associated with this particular form of extreme energy.

(wikicommons)

This industrial undertaking has already displaced and harmed Aboriginal people. The Mikisew Cree, Beaver Lake Cree, and Athabasca Chipewyan First Nations are affected with either rising cancer rates as toxins enter their waters and land and/or finding traditional territories inaccessible because of tar sands development and spills.

(openculture)

The Tar Sands Speakers Tour offers a way to further educate and mobilize the general public around this significant threat by engaging participants experientially, via a conversation with individuals directly affected by tar sands development or working to stop it.  The power of these first hand storytellers moves the issue from the abstract to the concrete, and compels the audience to take action.

(extremeenergy)

Every dollar helps!  Please donate now.  Your support helps mitigate one of the world’s most environmentally destructive industrial projects ever known. Please join us for this exciting opportunity.

For more detailed information, please see our website for the tour. For our mailing address, please see our address at our maine site.

story:
Short Summary

As an award winning photographer and cameraman I have dived and worked in amazing places like South Africa, Egypt and South East Asia. One of the biggest concerns which is painfully evident in all these locations is the impact the travel, sporting and dive industry has on the fragile marine ecosystems they utilize to sustain and grow their businesses. 

The influx of tourists to previously pristine and untouched locations is greatly affected by a modern age where travel has become increasingly more affordable and accessible even to remote parts of the world. Most recreational sport divers pride themselves on being responsible ambassadors of the underwater world, but sadly damage is still being inflicted on fragile reefs and marine life throughout the worlds oceans in places where standards go unchecked and the sheer volume of people visiting a specific location inadvertently leaves a trail of devastation.

      

                  Plastic litters the shores of the legendary 'Blue Hole' in Dahab, Egypt


Looking at the picture as a whole, it is also important to understand how dive tourism can have a seemingly less direct impact, yet even more damaging than that which is inflicted by recreational water users. A location which in years past was nothing more than a secluded village, island, or at times so remote that no human had any reason to be there, when dive tourism puts a location like this 'on the map' it leads to further developments. This usually takes the form of restaurants, hotels, supermarkets and a whole host of other facilities which provide services to cater for visiting divers and tourists. This increase in human activity is inadvertently fueled by easier routes and means to access these places for tourists (flights, ferries, buses etc) as well as by locals flocking to a new tourist 'hot spot' in order to find work or establish businesses to gain from this new opportunity. Although this has great benefits for the country and its economy, the direct result in most of these locations (especially in underdeveloped countries) is a massive spike in the waste being produced and in most cases this ends up as pollution in the oceans they are surrounded by.

Freediver and Green Turtle - An increase in water users also has a huge impact on which marine life frequents these marine ecosystems. An example is Shark Observatory, Ras Mohammed National Park where in earlier years the site was named for the sharks congregating in the area. Today, due to the thousands of divers/snorkelers and high dive boat traffic in the area every year, the odds of seeing a shark is next to zero.

The Impact

With this project I aim to create a visual report of how this increase in tourist traffic to popular dive locations has affected the marine ecosystem by comparing some of the most visited recreational dive sites in the world (ex: Red Sea - Egypt, Thailand and Philippines) to much more remote and less frequented locations like those around the pristine Solomon Islands. Using both film and photographic images I intend to create a high impact, yet very simple side by side comparison for people to understand how irreversible the impact tourism has on our ever diminishing reefs and marine life. This will hopefully help drive the movement towards more Marine Protected Areas (MPA's) and better management and practices by all stakeholders in the dive industry.

In order to assure circulation and reach, the video will be made available through social media like Facebook, Vimeo and Youtube while a photographic project will be compiled and sent to various media outlets as well as being made available online.

Broken coral (seen scattered on the ground in this photo) has become common sight at 'easy' dive sites like this one in the Red Sea. A direct result of the high volume of inexperienced and neglectful divers visiting the Red Sea every day...

By Supporting This Project You Will Help By:

  • creating awareness on an international level
  • educating those who utilize our oceans for recreational purposes to make informed decisions and develop responsible in-water practices.
  • supporting the backing for marine protected areas and better management of our oceans resources.
  • helping to support better business practices and more responsible environmental management by businesses in these locations.  

Record Freediver Linda Paganelli near Dahab, Egypt.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of travel to planned locations is extremely high, especially more remote areas like the Solomon Islands. Planned locations are Thailand, South Africa, Philippines, Egypt (Sinai and Marsa Alam area), Bahamas and Solomon Islands. Flight tickets and luggage cost for camera equipment alone for the intend route is in excess of 8200 USD. In addition to this the insurance, accommodation, gear rental, dive operator expenses etc has been estimated to be around 8000 USD. For the use of this project one additional DSLR camera body will be purchased (2800 USD) along with some peripherals like additional storage media drives/cards, camera flight case etc. The cost of the whole project in terms of expenses was calculated to be an estimated 21 500 USD. The balance of 10000 USD was added to cover costs for editing, commission fees (ex: Paypal, Indiegogo) and to cover any unforeseen expenses.


The final project is scheduled to be completed by April 2014 but will keep running to address issues where possible.

Perks will include first access to the final project as well as vouchers and products from jdvos.com.

Should the entire goal not be reached, the project will still continue as planned over a longer timeframe and funds will be used to visit those locations which the available funding permits.

Tek Divers surrounds Record Freediver Lotta Ericon, Red Sea

Additional Information

As an award winning photographer and cameraman I specialize in underwater photography and video (all done while Freediving – on a single breath). I am also a certified Commercial Diver and Recreational scuba and Freediving Instructor.

                                

During filming for the Red Bull documentary of Freediver Annelie Pompe's world record attempt in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt.

My work is internationally recognized and my most recent achievements and projects are listed below:

  • Awarded 4th Place - Best Of Photography 2012 by Serbin, Sigma, Photographers Forum on November 2012
  • Awarded Wide Angle - Gold by Dive Resort & Travel Underwater Photographic Competition on July 2012
  • Awarded Gold by Our World Underwater on February 2012
  • Underwater Cameraman: Red Bull Documentary (2012 and 2013) - Annelie Pompe Freediving Record
  • Underwater Cameraman: BBC - To Bodly Go Episode 1
  • Canon Professional Network: Developed the first broadcast quality underwater camera system around the 5DmkIII.

More of my work can also be viewed at www.jdvos.com

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help with money, please let others know about this campaign and feel free to forward information on topics related to this issue. Thank you for your support in creating awareness!

story:
A Local Start to Global Change

We all know that we should recycle.  And we all know that millions of old computers, cell phones, and electronics still wind up in landfills around the word.  What makes this project unique is that – as computer professionals – we’ve identified the reasons, at the individual level, that recycling/reuse of electronics commonly does not happen. This project starts at our community level, but the proof of concept and lessons learned will be translated into information and a web presence that will self-enable people to recycle and reuse as a global practice.

 

The Plan:  A Local Seed to Grow a Global Vision

One part of the recycling/reuse problem is more simple – that people either don’t know they shouldn’t throw electronics in the trash or don’t know how to have the items properly recycled or reused.  For this part of our program we will provide a physical drop-off site for electronics, a processing lab, and educational materials for the community.

Now, the more complicated reason we’ve found that people don’t recycle or reuse is because of the concern for personal information on computers, laptops, tablets, cell phones, etc.  A simple erase of the device (even if people do know how to perform this action) does not securely remove data – it can be recovered without much effort.  In an age of identity theft and cyber-crime, this is an extremely valid concern.  We also address this in our program plan.  As part of our community service we will provide a high-security erase of all data on recyclable and reusable devices.  This is something existing recycling centers are clearly unable to provide, and a core reason why some people would either not recycle/reuse or – in the worst cases – would more likely throw something in the trash in the hopes it would be buried deep in a landfill vs. the possible data access that could come from taking equipment to a recycling center, etc.

We will securely erase all equipment and then prepare it for reuse or recycling in our eWaste lab.  Reusable equipment will be sent to eco-conscious reuse vendors we have build relationships with, and equipment that cannot be reused will be taken (by us personally) to our city electronics recycling depot.

When we address both of these individual barriers, in combination, as to why people do not recycle or reuse, we can truly begin to make an impact.

The overarching vision of this program is to begin something at the local community level, expand upon it, and translate it into education and practices that can then be applied at a global level.  One end result will be a a web presence to self-enable people to effectively and securely recycle – with information, tutorials on how to securely remove data, access to free security erase software, lookups for recycle and reuse services, and other environmental tips and best practices.

We ask for your support in starting a local community seed that can begin to change behaviors and grow into a global practice.

 

The Goal

Our goal is to initially raise $15,000.  The funding will provide for the following: Creation of a drop-off area for the public that will also have take-away and/or screen display information available on electronics recycling/reuse etc. and a number to call us for questions.  The materials, hotline, and advertizing for people to find the drop-off will also come from the funding.  A small tech lab will be created to perform the secure data erases for devices (hardware and software are part of this cost).  A very used, inexpensive, and humble pickup truck will be purchased to transport equipment to the appropriate reuse/recycle depots we have partnered with.  The rest of the funding goes to the global side – for organizing the information we’ve learned on best practices, creation of a web site to translate this information into actionable steps and self-enable people to effectively and security recycle – with information, tutorials on how to securely remove data, prepare devices for reuse or recycling, access to free open-source security-erase software, lookups for recycle and reuse services and centers, and other environmental tips and best practices.

 

We know there are many causes to support – but the Earth (and environment) is the very stage of life itself.  We must secure this first, and above all.  Thank you again for your support.

story:
Please visit www.mainewoodsnationalpark.com for more information, photographs and videos.

Imagine sitting nearly motionless in a camouflaged blind, waiting for wildlife to venture within unobstructed camera range while trying to keep from freezing in temperatures as low as minus twenty-four degrees Fahrenheit during the winter; and contending with the heat, humidity and throngs of ticks, mosquitoes, and marauding deer flies in the summer. Why would anyone do this? Thomas Mark Szelog does it to help preserve wildlife and their habitat through The Maine Woods National Park Photo-Documentation Project. His photographs are used to educate and inspire people to support the creation of the proposed 3.2 million acre Maine Woods National Park.

As part of his Project, Tom and his wife, Lee Ann, are in the process of producing the Maine Woods National Park Art Exhibit. Your funding will assist with making this art exhibit a reality, which will continue the momentum to garner attention for this urgent initiative.

The Maine Woods National Park Photo-Documentation Project is the vision of  conservationists and wildlife photographers, Thomas Mark Szelog and Lee Ann Szelog. Since 2007 they have logged over 30,000 miles, and spent countless hours photographing the splendor of the proposed Maine Woods National Park and its riches that deserve protection.

The Szelogs provide inspiration, education, and motivation, through photographs and words, to encourage society to work together to create the Maine Woods National Park for the benefit of nature, wildlife, our planet and all mankind through their website, social media and a multi-media presentation. This art exhibit will showcase the greatest undeveloped and unprotected region that remains in the lower 48 states, Maine’s Great North Woods, and put a face to the land and wildlife of the proposed Maine Woods National Park, the same forest that Henry David Thoreau explored 150 years ago.

“The forest inspires us and provides peace. We are a couple with simple means, but with complex and dedicated convictions. We are lone activists with monumental goals. Our vision is to use our photography and words to open the eyes of people to show how closely we live to nature and wildlife and stir the hearts and minds of mankind to conserve what remains of our landscape for the benefit of all species, human and wild,” states Tom Szelog.

The traveling art exhibit will contain 25 fine-art photographs that are being custom printed on Hahnemühle Bamboo paper, an environmentally friendly fine art paper, and matted and framed to museum standards, including museum glass. The print sizes range from 16” x 24” to an arresting 40” x 60”. The exhibit is being created to some of the highest standards in the art world with the full intention of garnering as much attention as possible for the creation of the proposed 3.2 million acre Maine Woods National Park.

Tom and Lee Ann need your assistance to create this moving exhibit. Your support will help defray the cost of printing and framing the photographs.

What’s in it for you?

  1. Play a vital role in helping to create America’s next great national park.

  2. Saving habitat, which will save lives, human and wild.

  3. The opportunity to receive a unique reward as thanks for your contribution.

About the Exhibit

Never before has there been a collection of photographs from deep within the Great North Woods of Maine, due to its wildness and inaccessibility. The exceptional imagery will enthrall the audience and allow them to explore the greatest undeveloped and unprotected region that remains in the lower 48 states, the 3.2 million acre heart of America’s Great North Woods in Maine. The proposed park will encompasses an area larger than Yellowstone and Yosemite National Parks combined. This fragile ecosystem is home to myriad species including moose, bear, brook trout, and migratory songbirds, along with several endangered and threatened species, including Canada lynx, Atlantic salmon, and wood turtle, among others.

All work displayed was created with the utmost reverence for nature and wildlife by exercising patience and perseverance; no animals were baited or stalked, and no decoys or animal calls were used to obtain the photographs. 

"The wildlife photographs I create are more than art; they are a journey into the life and the home of a wilderness forest. This exhibit provides a unique opportunity to experience nature’s abundant beauty from a rarely visited and truly magnificent and fragile wilderness that I have had the privilege of documenting and want to humbly share with others through this exhibit,"  states Tom Szelog.

Wild by Nature

Imagine having the opportunity to preserve one of the last great wilderness ecosystems that exists in the United States. To create adequate space and an environment for Canada Lynx, black bear, and moose to raise their families, thrive and survive.

Imagine a society of environmentalists, politicians, conservationists, foresters, hunters, sportsman, developers and citizens, young and old, working collaboratively to rescue an ecosystem on the verge of destruction by commercial exploitation. Preserving an ecosystem to help maintain clean air and water, protect plants, wildlife, and insects, create an environment where people can visit to escape chaos, safeguard our planet for future generations and still have ample space for commercial and recreational activities.

Imagine thinking and leading with our hearts rather than our wallets to do what’s right, because it’s the right thing to do.

Imagine having the power and resources of a national agency (National Park Service) to support the creation and ongoing maintenance and management of such an effort.

Imagine having this opportunity and not acting on it, thereby contributing to the possible extinction of species such moose, bear and Canada lynx, due to the loss of habitat, a reality that sadly came true for the woodland caribou, wolf and mountain lion that were lost within the past 100 years, here in Maine.

Imagine creating the 3.2 million acre Maine Woods National Park.

It’s difficult to imagine that such a place could even exist today, let alone the opportunity to protect it. Please join us on this journey. Time is running out – will Maine’s Great North Woods live or die at the hands of man and woman?

Thank you, deeply, for your kind consideration.

The Maine Woods National Park
Photo-Documentation Project is the vision of  conservationists and
 wildlife photographers, Thomas Mark Szelog and Lee Ann Szelog.
Since 2007 they have logged over 30,000 miles, and spent countless hours
photographing the splendor of the proposed Maine Woods National Park and its
riches that deserve protection. 
The Szelogs
provide inspiration, education, and motivation, through photographs and words,
to encourage society to work together to create the Maine Woods National Park
for the benefit of nature, wildlife, our planet and all mankind through their
website, social media and a multi-media presentation. This art exhibit will
showcase the greatest undeveloped and
unprotected region that remains in the lower 48 states, Maine’s Great North Woods,
and put a face to the land and wildlife of the proposed Maine Woods National
Park, the same forest that Henry David Thoreau explored 150 years ago.
“The forest inspires us and provides
peace. We are a couple with simple means, but with complex and dedicated
convictions. We are lone activists with monumental goals. Our vision is to use
our photography and words to open the eyes of people to show how closely we
live to nature and wildlife and stir the hearts and minds of mankind to
conserve what remains of our landscape for the benefit of all species, human
and wild,” states Tom Szelog.
The traveling art
exhibit will contain 25 fine-art photographs that are being custom printed on
Hahnemühle Bamboo paper, an environmentally friendly fine art paper, and matted
and framed to museum standards, including museum glass. The print sizes range
from 16” x 24” to an arresting 40” x 60”. The exhibit is being created to some
of the highest standards in the art world with the full intention of garnering
as much attention as possible for the creation of the proposed 3.2 million acre
Maine Woods National Park.
Tom and Lee Ann need your assistance to
create this moving exhibit. Your
support will help defray the cost of printing and framing the photographs. 


What’s
in it for you?

Play a vital role in helping to create
America’s next great national park.
Saving habitat, which will save
lives, human and wild.
The
opportunity to receive a unique reward as thanks for your contribution. 

About
the Exhibit
Never before has there been a
collection of photographs from deep within the Great North Woods
of Maine, due to its wildness and inaccessibility. The
exceptional imagery will enthrall the
audience and allow them to explore the greatest undeveloped
and unprotected region that remains in the lower 48 states, the 3.2 million
acre heart of America’s Great North Woods in Maine. The proposed park will encompasses an area larger than Yellowstone and Yosemite National Parks
combined. This fragile ecosystem is home to myriad species
including moose, bear, brook trout, and migratory songbirds, along with several
endangered and threatened species, including Canada lynx, Atlantic salmon, and
wood turtle, among others.
All work displayed was created with
the utmost reverence for nature and wildlife by exercising patience and
perseverance; no animals were baited or stalked, and no decoys or animal calls
were used to obtain the photographs.  "The
wildlife photographs I create are more than art; they are a journey into the
life and the home of a wilderness forest. This exhibit provides a unique opportunity to experience nature’s
abundant beauty from a rarely visited and truly magnificent and fragile
wilderness that I have had the privilege of documenting and want to humbly
share with others through this exhibit,"  states Tom Szelog.

Wild by Nature
Imagine
having the opportunity to preserve one of the last great wilderness ecosystems
that exists in the United States. To create adequate space and an environment for Canada Lynx, black
bear, and moose to raise their families, thrive and survive. 
Imagine a society of environmentalists,
politicians, conservationists, foresters, hunters, sportsman, developers and
citizens, young and old, working collaboratively to rescue an ecosystem on the
verge of destruction by commercial exploitation. Preserving an ecosystem to
help maintain clean air and water, protect plants, wildlife, and insects,
create an environment where people can visit to escape chaos, safeguard our
planet for future generations and still have ample space for commercial and
recreational activities. 
Imagine thinking and leading with our
hearts rather than our wallets to do what’s right, because it’s the right thing
to do. 
Imagine having the power and resources
of a national agency (National Park Service) to support the creation and
ongoing maintenance and management of such an effort.
Imagine having this opportunity
and not acting on it, thereby contributing to the possible extinction of
species such moose, bear and Canada lynx, due to the loss of habitat, a reality
that sadly came true for the woodland caribou, wolf and mountain lion that were
lost within the past 100 years, here in Maine.
Imagine creating the 3.2 million
acre Maine Woods National Park. 
It’s difficult to imagine that such a place could even exist
today, let alone the opportunity to protect it. Please join us on this journey.
Time is running out – will Maine’s Great North Woods live or die at the hands
of man and woman?
Thank you, deeply, for your kind consideration.

story:
When I first came to Tabasco, Mexico in August 2014 to do research on the socio-economic impact of small scale fish farming in rural communities, everyone wanted to talk to me about the 'pez diablo' or 'devil fish'. 

"It's ruined my livelihood, there's no longer any other fish," they would say.  Not having a clue as to what they were talking about, I began asking around at the university where I worked, seeing what could be done with this 'devil fish'.  I soon realized that it's a common aquarium fish!  

The 'devil fish', also known as the suckermouth or armored catfish in English, had first been found in Mexico about 15 years ago. Many estimates calculate that 70%-80% of the wild capture today is comprised of the suckermouth catfish. This has decimated the thousands of Mexican families that depend on fishing as their primary economic activity.  

Owing to its ugly appearance, in conjunction with the lack of information and stigma, people have generally refused to consume it, often believing it to be poisonous. However, the suckermouth is completely edible and is commonly consumed in its native Amazon region of Brazil, Colombia and Ecuador.  

To demystify this invader I began giving informal community presentations to share the information I had learned at the university.  After witnessing the success of these workshops I asked myself, "Well heck, what if we just change the name and start selling the fillet?"

We soon started working with local fishermen to process and fillet the fish and began marketing the fish as "Acarí".  Our friend Lupita Vidal began selling pez diablo burgers in her restaurant La Cevichería.  Today, through our relentless marketing we've managed to sell hundreds of pounds of armored catfish fillet across the country through our company also named Acarí.  It has become a reliable economic alternative for the group of fishermen we work with in the community of Simón Sarlat, Tabasco. 

Now we'd like your help to expand and elevate our game.  Demand for our products has risen sharply this summer and we need to expand production and start working with other fishing communities.  We've gone from hawking a few pounds per week to having to fill orders of 500+ pounds and we need to grow!  We'd also like to equip our processing facility with the equipment necessary to mass produce pez diablo products like fish croquettes with chaya and fish jerky. We'll sell these products in Mexico and in the U.S. as a healthy and sustainable alternative to things like fish sticks and beef jerky.  We've already been donating fillets and croquettes to immigrant shelters like La 72 in Mexico and will soon be working with migrant organizations to hire Central American refugees as we expand production throughout Southern Mexico.  We're calling this our quadruple bottom line - not only are we supporting local Mexican fishermen and the environment but also providing invaluable nutrition and employment opportunities to Central American migrants and refugees.  

So, will you join us in transforming the devil into an angel?

What We Need

To build our business we're looking for an investment of $12,500.  Our primary needs to make this happen are the following:

  • Purchase additional equipment like a dehydrator, additional refrigeration and packaging machines to produce our croquettes and fish jerky
  • Modify our production facility with things like air conditioning, proper drainage and washing stations to make it FDA compliant
  • Buy processing equipment to utilize the fish waste material and produce animal feed and/or fertilizer
  • Meet with distributors in Mexico and the U.S. and send samples 
  • Starting salaries for additional employees
  • Invest in packaging and marketing materials for the Acarí brand

Every contribution no matter the size will help us in our dream of achieving our "quadruple bottom line" business.  We want to vastly expand our sales to benefit the thousands of fishermen across the state and provide a steady source of income for their families.  We also dream of sending shipments of Acarí products to migrant shelters around Mexico from Tapachula to Tijuana.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate there's still plenty of ways to help! We'd love if you could put us in touch with any seafood distributors, chefs or restaurants that might be interested in purchasing our products.  

Also please share our campaign in your networks!

story:
Our Story

One of the challenges of 'Going Green' is that we don't often see and understanding how much waste we actually produce in our societies nor its impact on us and our environment. Disposable Permanence is a large scale art installation focused on this issue. It is being constructed out of bamboo, discarded plastic waste, LED lights and bicycle parts and powered by renewable energy. Disposable Permanence will be one of the main attracts at the Festival Village at the 1st Pure Grenada Music Festival (April 5th-10th) organized by non-profit organization, Music & Beyond. The booths, displays and art of the festival village at the big lawn at Port Louis, St. George, will be open to the public on Wed. 6th & Thurs 7th April, so many schools are planning field trips to get involved in activities about environmental sustainability. 

This educational art piece will be free standing tree sculptures (average 9ft tall) built from the bamboo, exploding from the inside, with plastic waste gathered from beaches, households, roadsides and events - symbolic of the volume and forms of waste we produce daily. 

Disposable Permanence is being created by Grenadian contemporary artist Malaika Brooks-Smith-Lowe with the help of bamboo craftsman, Terry Moore, and Mechanical Engineer,Earl Roberts. It is the first large scale, interactive art project of its kind to be created in Grenada. It expresses the spirit of the Green Charter of the Pure Grenada Music Festival, which recognizes that sustainable resolutions to environmental issues can be produced through culture. Your contribution will allow us to place the importance of our environment at the heart of one of Grenada's largest events of the year. 


What We Need 

We began this project almost 1 year ago and now we are in the last phase of production. Your support will cover the remaining costs:

  • Our renewable energy system - 2 solar panels, LED Lights,battery bank, wiring etc.
  • Interactive System - Building Materials for benches and additional supplies to allow people control the lighting by peddling.
  • Transport and installation of the trees at festival site. 
  • Additional funding will allow us to install individual trees at schools across island once the festival is over.

The Impact

We at Music & Beyond, the non-profit organization behind this 1st international festival in Grenada, know that when thousands of people come together to experience a music festival, the amount of trash generated and the overall ‘carbon footprint’ of such an event can be quite massive. We also know that the festival can be an effective platform for important issues like environmental consciousness. So, from the moment that we began conceptualizing this festival we made a commitment to being as 'Green' as possible, for example food vendors must use disposable food service items made from bio-based, renewable materials, from recycled content. No plastic cups, plates, cutlery allowed. Receptacles will be provided to keep trash and recyclables separated, and a ‘take-in take-out’ trash policy will also be encouraged. We are also collecting old sails to make a canopy in the festival village. This art project, Disposable Permanence, is a unique approach to this vision. 


Risks & Challenges

We are well underway and need your support to cover the final costs. Throughout the process we have had some challenges with access to necessary parts and materials but we have made adjustments to the design to suit.  We hope to give these trees an extended life by permanently installing them, individually, at schools but since we are completing construction on site at the festival we may have a challenge with transporting the completed trees (up to 10 ft tall and 7 ft wide w/ branches). Once we have done the final set up of the installation we will have a better sense of how to make transport as feasible as possible 


Other Ways You Can Help

Share! Share! Share! Spread the word to your friends and family! Also, come out to the Festival Village and interact with Disposable Permanence yourself!
