story:
After visiting Labuan Bajo in June 2012 and meeting the local grassroots organization 'Plasticman' and learning about the incredible work that they are trying to push forward I decided to start a small UK based NGO 'Support International', in order to support their work.

We are now working on several main projects in Labuan Bajo:

-To solve the big waste management problem.

-Develop sustanable farming methods.

- Teach students in the Marine and Tourism schools about the importance of the environment and empower them to look after their habitats.

-Set up a Locally Managed Marine Area (in collaboration with other non-govermental bodies).

-Improove teaching facilities and refurbish the Stella Maris Marine School.

 

To do this we need your help. We need to raise the funds for:

 

2 cows; in order to use for dairy products and as a bio-fuel. The rainforest is not fertile enough to grow food and so this will allow for sustainable farming. £300 (£150 each)

 

2 goat; they produce milk to drink, fertiliser for crops and lamb to take to market. £100  (£50 each)

  • Chickens -  £100

     

  • Seeds and tools for farming. £300

 

  • Tools for rebuilding the school. £200

 

  • Tools to build a project base for project volunteers to stay. £300

 

  •  Teaching resources for the Stella Maris Marine School & Tourism School. £400

 

  • Funding for the Waste Management Project. £300

 

  • A camera to photograph and film the work we are doing to raise awareness of these issues and attract more funding. £200

 

Please help us raise the funds to help the community and future of Labuan Bajo!!

You are welcome to choose what you would like us to put your money towards, whether it be the cow or the tools! Once we have finished the campaign we will keep you posted with our progress and will be documenting our work.

Help us spread to word to raise as much money as possible!

 

Thank you for your support,

 

Ruby and the S.I Volunteer Team.

story:
Help Bring Bioneers to Chicago!

WHEN:    November 2 through 4, 2012

WHERE:  University of Illinois at Chicago, Student Center East

This coming November, Chicago will become the largest city in the nation to host a Bioneers gathering! This three-day event will bring international, national and local innovators and visionaries together to tackle some of today's most pressing social and environmental problems. We'll be creating and talking about solutions that come about from looking into living systems to understand how nature operates, and to mimic “nature’s operating instructions” to serve human ends without harming the web of life. 

Bioneers (biological + pioneers) believe that if humans follow nature’s organizing principles of kinship, cooperation, diversity, symbiosis and continuous cycles of creation (without waste) we CAN solve our most pressing environmental and social challenges without harming our planet, and at the same time, foster equitable, just and democratic societies.

Our event is featuring Dr. Vandana Shiva: renowned scientist, philosopher, feminist, environmental activist, author and founder of Navdanya; John Edel: creator of The Plant, Chicago’s vertical farm and business incubator designed to close resource loops; Nina Simons: Co-Founder, National BIoneers; Starhawk:  author and voice of earth-based spirituality (confirmed participants); and Richard Heinberg:  author and educator on energy, economic, and ecological issues  But equally important are the grassroots innovators, not-for-profits,  scientists, permaculturalists and more that we are bringing together for a weekend of sharing, networking, collaborating and celebrating. Visit our website:  http://chicagobioneers.org to se who else is participating and what they are brining to the event!

But we need you to help us get the word out about this inaugural event! It costs money to fund an awareness campaign that uses print materials and paid media to successfully promote an event of this scale throughout Chicago.

What is Great Lakes Bioneers Chicago?   

Great Lakes Bioneers Chicago (GLBC) is a local, self-organized affiliate partner of the National Bioneers movement. 

Our theme is The Living City, using the body as a metaphor for the critical systems that are needed to keep Chicago alive, healthy and thriving. We'll explore solutions to some of the city’s most pressing challenges through interactive workshops, panels and skill shares; the arts (including performing arts); and tours of some of Chicago’s most forward-thinking projects of environmental sustainability and eco-justice.

Who Is Making this Happen?

Our November gathering is being hosted by Eco-Justice Collaborative, the University of Illinois at Chicago's Office of Sustainability and the Pierce Family Foundation. Our core planning committee is made up of a committed group of volunteers who believe that positive change is possible.

What’s In It for You?

Our inaugural event will function as an oasis of hope that sparks mass creativity and engagement! By helping us cover the cost of promotional materials, you will help us get the word out, sowing the seeds for a successful launch. 

Your contributions will help us link individuals and organizations together in order to foster connection, cross-pollination, and collaboration of people and ideas - all focused on positive change!  

Donate $50 and we'll send you our Bioneers t-shirt, so you can proudly proclaim your ground-level support!

Get Connected!

  • Subscribe to our email list and receive periodic updates.
  • Visit our website.
  • Link to us on Facebook.
  • Follow us on Twitter (@chibioneers)

story:
Thank you to all that contributed to our powEARTHful 2.0 campaign! We were able to not only raise awareness of BC and Canada's geothermal potential, but were able to raise a portion of the funds that will go towards our most recent report; "Geothermal Power: The Cost-Effective Alternative to Site C".


We've decided to continue our fundraising efforts and are offering the perks listed in the campaign. Use the 'Donate' button below to contribute and if you'd like to claim one of the perks, when prompted after you've contributed, enter in the perk you'd like. Please note that to claim a perk you must contribute, at minimum, the value of that perk.



We need you to engage your friends, family and colleagues, and have a conversation regarding Canada’s decision to switch to a truly clean and renewable energy alternative – geothermal energy. If you are looking to learn more about geothermal energy, JOIN US on December 18th for our Geothermal 101 Workshop featuring Craig Dunn from Borealis GeoPower.  CanGEA will also be in Vancouver hosting a Turn Up the Heat Breakfast on January 30, 2015 with Chair, Alison Thompson.


Campaign Update: 

Former Premier of Newfoundland and Labrador, Brian Peckford, has spoken out in favour of CanGEA’s recent report. He agrees with the recommendation that a moratorium be placed upon the Site C project, while alternatives such as geothermal energy are fully investigated. 

Mr. Peckford is often recognized for his instrumental role in the crafting of Newfoundland and Labrador’s successful energy sector. Amongst other positions, he served as the Minister of Mines and Energy and was also the Premier of the province from 1979 to 1989.

Read the letter here.

Looking for a cost-effective, clean and flexible source of energy? It is right under your feet.

“... a failure to pursue research over the last 30 years into B.C.’s geothermal resources has left BC Hydro without information about a resource that BC Hydro thinks may offer up to 700 megawatts of firm, economic power with low environmental costs.”
- Site C Joint Review Panel, 2014


powEARTHful 2.0


BC currently has the opportunity to choose between a conventional, mega-dam project and a truly clean, stable and cost-competitive energy source.

You can help the BC Government make an informed decision so that generations to come are left with a legacy that everyone can be proud of. In the past, the geothermal potential of Canada has largely been ignored. However, as the Site C decision draws closer, Canada has the chance to finally demonstrate the feasibility of geothermal power.

Kinbasket Lake, BC - Site of Canoe Reach Geothermal Project

What is geothermal energy?

Geothermal energy is a green source of reliable electricity and large scale direct use of (hot water) heat derived from the Earth.  It can help solve some of Canada’s greatest challenges, namely providing energy security, economic growth and reducing our CO2 emissions. Geothermal energy is also the cleanest source of electricity and heat, using less land and producing fewer emissions than any other energy form.

Surmountable policy barriers in Canada are holding back the development of this renewable energy source that is already deployed in 73 countries.

Canada is the only country in the Ring of Fire not currently advancing geothermal

Where will the funds go?

We are asking you today to fund "Geothermal Power: A Cost-Effective Alternative to Site C". This 10 Point Assessment of the True Value of Geothermal Energy finally sets the record straight, for British Columbia AND the rest of Canada.

While it has recently been demonstrated by CanGEA that BC has enough cost-competitive geothermal energy potential to power the province, those claims are being disputed by BC Hydro and the BC Government in favour of the Site C mega-dam.

powEARTHful 2.0 Campaign proceeds will be directed towards our engineered resource estimate, financial modelling consulting costs, and the follow up required to act upon the report . With the Site C decision expected in December, it is imperative that our assessment is widely distributed, including follow-up briefings, to decision-makers, stakeholders and community-members before then.


Ways you can help

  • Contribute to the powEARTHful 2.0 crowdfunding campaign and receive some awesome perks!
  • Share powEARTHful 2.0 with your community on Twitter and Facebook
  • Like us on Facebook!
  • Visit our website and learn about our numerous reports and publications


About CanGEA

As a non-profit association, CanGEA has been working diligently since 2007 to promote the potential of geothermal energy in Canada through awareness raising outreach, research, and policy work.

Since our last crowdfunding campaign, we have accomplished many of the goals we have set out to do, such as:

  • Hired a Policy Analyst that directly promotes geothermal power as a viable energy source to policy-makers and stakeholders
  • Produced numerous policy reports and publications, including the Direct Utilization of Geothermal Energy: Suitable Applications and Opportunities for Canada
  • Advanced our Industry Roadmap through Technology Transfer Workshops
  • Created the Canadian National Geothermal Database and Provincial Resource Estimate Map for British Columbia


Resources and Publications

BC Geothermal Favourability Maps

Alberta Geothermal Favourability Maps

Direct Utilization of Geothermal Energy: Suitable Applications and Opportunities for Canada

Canadian Geothermal Projects Overview 2013

Geothermal Technology Roadmap: Global Best Practices Summary - Exploration through Generation
Geothermal Power & Direct Use of Heat Sector Supply Chain
An Assessment of the Geothermal Energy Sector in Canada - Now and in the Future 

Geothermal Code for Public Reporting


Articles

DeSmog Blog, June 3, 2014
DeSmog Blog, October 7, 2014
Vancouver Sun, October 8, 2014
Energetic City, October 9, 2014
Globe and Mail, October 14, 2014
The Rocky Mountain Goat News, November 3, 2014
The Eco Report, November 6, 2014
UBC Clean Capital News, November 13, 2014
Vancouver Observer, November 18, 2014
Globe and Mail, November 25, 2014
Energetic City, November 25, 2014
DeSmog Blog, November 25, 2014
North Shore News, November 26, 2014
Kelowna Capital News, November 26, 2014
Gorilla Radio, November 26, 2014
Globe and Mail, November 30, 2014
The Eco Report, November 30, 2014
ReNew Canada, December 2, 2014
Hydrogen Fuel News, December 3, 2014
North Shore News, December 10, 2014
story_txt:
Thank you to all that contributed to our powEARTHful 2.0 campaign! We were able to not only raise awareness of BC and Canada's geothermal potential, but were able to raise a portion of the funds that will go towards our most recent report; "Geothermal Power: The Cost-Effective Alternative to Site C".

We've decided to continue our fundraising efforts and are offering the perks listed in the campaign. Use the 'Donate' button below to contribute and if you'd like to claim one of the perks, when prompted after you've contributed, enter in the perk you'd like. Please note that to claim a perk you must contribute, at minimum, the value of that perk.








We need you to engage your friends, family and colleagues, and have a conversation regarding Canada’s decision to switch to a truly clean and renewable energy alternative – geothermal energy. If you are looking to learn more about geothermal energy, JOIN US on December 18th for our Geothermal 101 Workshop featuring Craig Dunn from Borealis GeoPower.  CanGEA will also be in Vancouver hosting a Turn Up the Heat Breakfast on January 30, 2015 with Chair, Alison Thompson.

Campaign Update: 
Former Premier of Newfoundland and Labrador, Brian Peckford, has spoken out in favour of CanGEA’s recent report. He agrees with the recommendation that a moratorium be placed upon the Site C project, while alternatives such as geothermal energy are fully investigated. 

Mr. Peckford is often recognized for his instrumental role in the crafting of Newfoundland and Labrador’s successful energy sector. Amongst other positions, he served as the Minister of Mines and Energy and was also the Premier of the province from 1979 to 1989.
Read the letter here.Looking for a cost-effective, clean and flexible source of energy? It is right under your feet.

story:
Desplazar la pagina para abajo para leer esta información en español

Why the Campaign?

People in Argentina are concerned about fracking increasing in their country. They are aware of the impacts to people's health and the environment that oil and gas fracking has caused - spills, leaks and explosions; air and water pollution; nausea, headaches and other health problems from toxic exposure; destruction of forests and parklands; increased earthquake risks.

They want to know the truth from those who have lived and worked near oil and gas operations in the U.S. Argentina sin Fracking has invited Earthworks, FracTracker Alliance and Ecologic Institute to come to Argentina to tell the real story. 

Your contributions will make it possible for experts from these 3 American organizations to travel to Argentina, and share their experiences from the U.S. with fracking. We'll hold several workshops in Buenos Aires and other affected communities, such as the Vaca Muerta region, where fracking is already occurring, and visit others who face the potential dangers of fracking. With your help, we can help Argentina avoid making the mistakes that we've made in the U.S., and we can connect Argentinians to a new international network of environmental groups fighting fossil fuel development worldwide. 


Where does your money go?

All funds raised will be used to cover travel expenses from the U.S. to Argentina in November 2014, and for the costs associated with organizing the workshops, including producing educational materials. 

We will keep costs low by enjoying the hospitality of families and volunteers who have offered to feed us and give us a place to sleep. 

If we raise money above our goal, we will use the additional funds to strengthen our international partnerships and help protect communities vulnerable to oil and gas development.

If we do not reach our goal, we will bring a smaller delegation to Argentina and look to reduce the costs of the project.

The Impact

Signs point to exploration areas in the Vaca Muerta, or Dead Cow, a field in the Patagonian desert where Chevron is currently drilling fracking exploratory wells. (Photo by NY Times)

Argentina has some of the largest reserves of shale oil and gas in the world. The Argentinian government is providing incentives to attract international fossil fuel companies to come drill and frack in their country, claiming the investment will lead to jobs and tax revenue. 


100 foot flare in Wyoming, United States.

By sharing the U.S. experience with the people of Argentina, we hope to prevent the devastation to public health and the environment that oil and gas drilling, and fracking, causes. 

If this project is a success, we hope to expand our outreach to other countries who face expanded oil and gas development and fracking, like Mexico, Brazil and Australia. 

Open waste impoundment in West Virginia. Photo by Samantha Malone, FracTracker Alliance

Challenges

The oil and gas industry is one of the world's richest and most powerful. Governments often choose companies' false promises without considering the impacts on people's health, safety and well-being, or the long-term damage to the environment from extraction. The people living on the frontlines are often forgotten and their stories ignored.

With your help, we can stand in solidarity with the people of Argentina and help them to build a strong grassroots movement to stand up for the rights to clean water, clean air and a clean environment. 

A Little Something For YOU

With your support, not only are you investing in changing the future of communities in Argentina, but you will receive one or more of the following items:
FracTracker Alliance and Earthworks Stickers! - Who doesn't love stickers for their reusable water bottles?!

How about a custom map of drilling location around your community? - Courtesy of the FracTracker Alliance

 More neat stuff:
  • Baggie clips and solar flashlights
  • A Skype call with the entire team from Argentina
  • An artisanal gift from Argentina, chosen by the local team just for YOU!
  • The chance to go with us to Argentina, and see firsthand what is happening there. 

Other Ways You Can Help

For additional information, please visit our websites:

  • Earthworks - www.earthworksaction.org
  • FracTracker Alliance - www.fractracker.org
  • Ecologic Institute - www.ecologic.eu/institute-us
  • Argentina Sin Fracking - www.argentinasinfracking.org



¿Por Qué La Campaña?

Nuestros amigos en Argentina están preocupados que el fracturamiento hidráulico esta ocurriendo en su país. Son conscientes de los impactos del fracking a la salud publica y el medio ambiente, como los derrames, las fugas, las explosiones, la contaminación del aire y del agua, la náusea, los dolores de cabeza y otros problemas de salud, la destrucción de bosques y parques, y los riesgos de terremotos.

Quieren saber la verdad del fracking de personas que han vivido y trabajado cerca de las operaciones de gas y petróleo en los Estados Unidos. Argentina Sin Fracking ha invitado a Earthworks, a FracTracker Alliance, y a Ecologic Institute a viajar a Argentina para contar su historia.

Sus contribuciones harán posible que expertos de estas tres organizaciones estadounidenses puedan viajar a Argentina, y puedan compartir sus experiencias con el fracturamiento hidráulico. Vamos a tener varios talleres en Buenos Aires y otras comunidades afectadas, como la región de Vaca Muerta, y visitaremos otras comunidades que enfrentan los peligros potenciales del fracturamiento hidráulico. Con su ayuda, podemos ayudar a Argentina a evitar cometer los errores que hemos hecho en los Estados Unidos, y podemos conectar a los argentinos a una nueva red internacional de grupos ambientalistas luchando el desarrollo de combustibles fósiles en todo el mundo.

¿Adónde Va Su Dinero?

Todos los fondos recaudados serán utilizados para cubrir los gastos de viaje desde Estados Unidos a Argentina en noviembre del 2014, y los costos asociados con la organización de los talleres, incluyendo la producción de materiales educativos.

Los costos del viaje se mantendrán bajos gracias a la hospitalidad de las familias y voluntarios que han ofrecido alimentarnos y darnos un lugar para hospedarnos.

Si juntamos donaciones por encima de nuestro objetivo, utilizaremos los fondos para fortalecer nuestras alianzas internacionales, ayudando a proteger a comunidades vulnerables por todo el mundo del desarrollo de petróleo y gas.

Si no alcanzamos nuestro objetivo, trabajaremos para traer una delegación pequeña a Argentina, y buscaremos maneras de reducir los costos del proyecto.

El Impacto

Los indicios apuntan a las áreas de exploración en la región de Vaca Muerta, una región donde Chevron esta explotando petroleo por el fracking. (Foto de NY Times)

Argentina tiene una de las mayores reservas de gas y petróleo de esquisto en el mundo. El gobierno argentino está ofreciendo incentivos para atraer a las compañías de petróleo internacionales, alegando que la inversión trara con si puestos de trabajo y los ingresos de impuestos.

Al compartir la experiencia de los Estados Unidos con el pubico argentino, esperamos evitar la devastación a la salud pública y el medio ambiente que el desarrollo de gas y petróleo, y el fracturamiento hidráulico, causan. 

Si este proyecto es un éxito, esperamos expandir nuestro alcance a otros países que enfrentan el fracking de petróleo de gas, como México, Brasil y Australia. 


Embalse de residuos abierto en West Virginia. Foto de Samantha Malone, FracTracker Alliance

Desafíos

La industria petrolera y una de las mas poderosas en el mundo, controlando incalculables cantidades de dinero. Los gobiernos suelen elegir falsas promesas de estas empresas sin tomar en cuenta los impactos de la extracción petrolera a la salud, la seguridad y el bienestar publico, o el daño a largo plazo al medio ambiente. A menudo, se olvidan de las personas que viven cerca de la extracción, y sus historias son ignoradas.

Con su ayuda, podemos ser solidarios con el pueblo argentino y ayudarles a construir un movimiento fuerte para defender sus derechos a agua potable, el aire limpio, y un medio ambiente sano.

Unas Sorpresas Para Ustedes

Con su apoyo, no solo estará ayudando a cambiar las vidas de las comunidades en Argentina, pero también recibirá uno o mas de estos premios:

FracTracker Alliance and Earthworks Stickers! - A quién no le gusta los stickers para sus botellas de agua sostenibles?!

Que tal un mapa único de su comunidad demostrando los sitios de desarrollo de petróleo y gas? - Cortesia del FracTracker Alliance

 Más premios para ustedes:

  • Clip para bolsas y linternas solares
  • Una llamada por Skype con todo el grupo desde Argentina
  • Un regalo artisanal de Argentina, escojido especial para USTED por el grupo
  • La oportunidad de viajar con nosotros a Argentina.

Otras Maneras Que Usted Puede Ayudar

Hable con sus comunidades acerca de estos, y edúquese sobre los riesgos asociados con el fracturamiento hidráulico.

IndieGoGo tiene una variedad de maneras de compartir esta campaña a través de tus redes sociales. Ayúdanos a difundir la palabra a tantas personas como sea posible.

Para obtener información adicional, por favor visite nuestros sitios web:

  • Earthworks - www.earthworksaction.org
  • FracTracker Alliance - www.fractracker.org
  • Ecologic Institute - www.ecologic.eu/institute-us
  • Argentina Sin Fracking - www.argentinasinfracking.org

story:
Our Story

My name is Jessica Stitt and I am an intern with Cape Fear River Watch (CFRW). Let me tell you a little bit about the organization before I explain our Indiegogo campaign goals. The mission of Cape Fear River Watch, “to protect and improve the water quality of the Lower Cape Fear River Basin through education, advocacy, and action.”


Cape Fear River Watch is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that was founded in 1993 in Wilmington, North Carolina, by a group of people who wanted to share the beauty of the Cape Fear River with the public, and advocate for its conservation and protection. We have several education programs that we share with the public, which are very important to myself as well as CFRW because they reach many different children around the Cape Fear area. It teaches them the importance of conservation of the river and its resources.

Snags (Dead Trees) on the Cape Fear River


What we Need

Our goal is to raise $9,600.

This money will go towards three of our Environmental Education programs:

1. Raindrop Journey: This program was created to educate 4th grade students about watersheds and how best management practices (BMPs) keep them clean and about  how to clean up pollution. There are three parts to our Raindrop Journey program: pre-field trip classroom activities, field trip to Greenfield Lake, and post-field trip classroom activities. When the students get to the lake, we divide them into three groups. One group goes on a paddleboat ride in Greenfield Lake and records basic water quality observations.The second group is led by a CFRW biologist on a walking Eco-Tour where they learn about the history and ecology of the lake. The third group plays the Raindrop Journey Game, created by CFRW in which, a group of students are given the role of a raindrop, a pollutant, or a best management practice such as a rain garden. ($3,500)

We need funding for the participating schools’ travel costs to the field trip site at Greenfield Lake. This includes gas and bus drivers. $2,500

Materials, supplies and equipment.  $1000

 You would be helping these children with their education and allowing them to get out in the environment and out of the classroom for a day.  

Kids Playing the Raindrop Journey Game

Greenfield Lake, where the Raindrop Journey program takes place.


2. Summer Camp Programs: Cape Fear River Watch offers high quality environmental education camps for youth ages 9-13 regardless of their family’s income level and we need funds to provide scholarships to lower income children in underserved communities in the Lower Cape fear River Basin. We work to assure environmental justice is a key component in our summer camp program. ($3,850)

For a week of summer camp, each child is $190 for the whole week. Your funding will go towards sending a child whose family didn’t have the means to send their child to summer camp. 

We need scholarship funding for 15 children, which is $2,850

Supplies, Materials and equipment. $1000

2014 Summer Campers at the North Carolina Aquarium at Fort Fisher

2014 Summer Campers Paddle boating at Greenfield Lake 

3. Lock and Dam #1 Education Center: Cape Fear River Watch also has an Education Center at Lock and Dam #1 in Riegelwood, North Carolina. Lock and Dam #1 is one of three Lock and Dams in the Cape Fear River Basin. It was built in 1915 by the Army Corps of Engineers in order to provide drinking water to the City of Wilmington as well as allow ships to travel safely up and down the Cape Fear River. The dam impedes the migration of certain anadromous fish that live in the Cape Fear River. These fish include: the Atlantic Sturgeon (endangered), the Shortnose Sturgeon (endangered), the American Shad, and the Striped Bass. Since the Lock and Dams impede the migration of these fish, they cannot migrate from the ocean up to Lock and Dam #3 where they spawn and reproduce. In order to help with their migration upstream of Lock and Dam #1, CFRW advocated a Rock Arch Rapids fish passage which was built in 2013. ($2,250)

Lock and Dam # 1, located in Riegelwood, N.C.

At Lock and Dam #1 in Riegelwood, NC, CFRW recently completed the construction of a rain garden. A rain garden is a planted depression where storm water runoff from impervious areas, like parking lots can be absorbed and cleansed.

Rain Garden at Lock and Dam #1

Cape Fear River Watch plans to build an elevated boardwalk through a wetland adjacent to the rock arch rapids, which will be a key component to an interpretive nature trail. The plan has only been partially funded, and we need your help to make this vision become a reality.

Materials for the boardwalk.  $2,250

Thank You!


For more information about Cape Fear River Watch, contact 
Kay Lynn Hernandez at kaylynn@cfrw.us
story_txt:
Our Story
My name is Jessica Stitt and I am an intern with Cape Fear River Watch (CFRW). Let me tell you a little bit about the organization before I explain our Indiegogo campaign goals. The mission of Cape Fear River Watch, “to protect and improve the water quality of the Lower Cape Fear River Basin through education, advocacy, and action.” 


Cape Fear River Watch is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that was founded in 1993 in Wilmington, North Carolina, by a group of people who wanted to share the beauty of the Cape Fear River with the public, and advocate for its conservation and protection. We have several education programs that we share with the public, which are very important to myself as well as CFRW because they reach many different children around the Cape Fear area. It teaches them the importance of conservation of the river and its resources.

Snags (Dead Trees) on the Cape Fear RiverWhat we Need
Our goal is to raise $9,600.
This money will go towards three of our Environmental Education programs:

1. Raindrop Journey: This program was created to educate 4th grade students about watersheds and how best management practices (BMPs) keep them clean and about  how to clean up pollution. There are three parts to our Raindrop Journey program: pre-field trip classroom activities, field trip to Greenfield Lake, and post-field trip classroom activities. When the students get to the lake, we divide them into three groups. One group goes on a paddleboat ride in Greenfield Lake and records basic water quality observations.The second group is led by a CFRW biologist on a walking Eco-Tour where they learn about the history and ecology of the lake. The third group plays the Raindrop Journey Game, created by CFRW in which, a group of students are given the role of a raindrop, a pollutant, or a best management practice such as a rain garden. ($3,500)
We need funding for the participating schools’ travel costs to the field trip site at Greenfield Lake. This includes gas and bus drivers. $2,500
Materials, supplies and equipment.  $1000
 You would be helping these children with their education and allowing them to get out in the environment and out of the classroom for a day.  

Kids Playing the Raindrop Journey Game

Greenfield Lake, where the Raindrop Journey program takes place.
2. 2014 Summer Campers Paddle boating at Greenfield Lake

Lock and Dam # 1, located in Riegelwood, N.C.
At Lock and Dam #1 in Riegelwood, NC, CFRW recently completed the construction of a rain garden. A rain garden is a planted depression where storm water runoff from impervious areas, like parking lots can be absorbed and cleansed.

Rain Garden at Lock and Dam #1
Cape Fear River Watch plans to build an elevated boardwalk through a wetland adjacent to the rock arch rapids, which will be a key component to an interpretive nature trail. The plan has only been partially funded, and we need your help to make this vision become a reality.

story:
Together, We Can Make the World Greener

In a connected world where mobile technology has broken down distance barriers, shopping has undergone a transformation. While the convenience of ordering goods from the comfort of your home is plain for everyone to see, the benefits of mobile grocery shopping are yet to be fully exploited, until now. Groceaider's personalized grocery shopping is driven by the cornerstones of better health, a greener planet and a happier family. We solicit your contributions and support towards our campaign.

Our Story



The Impact

Cars account for 12% of total EU emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2), which is a major greenhouse gas responsible for the loss of ecosystems and harmful health effects. While door-to-door transportation has made lives easy, it has contributed to greater pollution. Groceaider wants to tackle this issue by delivering groceries only in zero-emission vehicles. Our first target is to acquire the e-NV200 electric van whose all-electric, battery-powered drive train ensures zero CO2. We want to do our bit for climate protection while offering modern-day grocery shopping convenience. We also hope to encourage businesses to add Eco-friendly vehicles to their fleet.


A Contribution Today for a Healthier Environment Tomorrow

We need to raise €25,000 for purchasing a Nissan e-NV200 electric van.

The zero-emission van is an ideal delivery vehicle for small businesses seeking a versatile and Eco-friendly ride in a single package. It will really help us kick-start operations smoothly while allowing us to meet our commitment to the environment.

Every contribution to our campaign counts.

Besides our gratitude, we offer you some delicious organic treats.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand you may not be able to make a cash contribution. But you can still help us in the following ways:

Spread awareness about our campaign through word-of-mouth, email or Indiegogo share tools. It costs nothing but means an awful lot to us.

Many people still think that it's the government's job to protect the environment. Educate them about how small changes from their side can make a big difference to the planet. After all, little drops of water make a mighty ocean. From using cloth bags to composting to remembering to turn off electric equipment when not in use, there are many ways to conserve energy and safeguard the environment. If you work for or own a company, consider or suggest switching to an electric van as a replacement for your current gasoline/diesel delivery vehicle.

Let us know if you can help us with more Eco-friendly ideas!

story:
When ORV Alguita was launched by Captain Charles Moore in Hobart in 1995  and sailed to Tasmania's rugged west coast on her first research voyage, no one knew that she would soon become the most pioneering, independent research vessel in the world. After completing 8 research expeditions, her job is far from complete... 




On June 29, 2014...

a research team of dynamic scientists led by Captain Charles Moore departed on ORV Alguita for its 9th research voyage to the center of what is now known as the “Great Pacific Garbage Patch."  

TRACK THEIR LOCATION IN LIVE TIME!

1) Charles Moore is a licensed captain with over a hundred thousand miles sampling plastic pollution in the Pacific Ocean from Tasmania, Australia to the Oregon/California border.  His published papers, interviews and lectures, as well as his award winning book, Plastic Ocean, have brought international attention to the "Plastic Plague" in the world ocean. He will receive the Peter Benchly "Hero of the Seas" award from the Blue Frontier Campaign in San Francisco at the end of May.

2) Dale Selvam is a licensed captain with over a hundred and fifty thousand miles of voyaging, much of which was with marine scientists doing research on plastic pollution.  He was the first to lead expeditions that sampled the South Atlantic and South Pacific Garbage Patches.

3) Cynthia Matzke is now finishing her Master of Advanced Studies program at the Center for Marine Biodiversity and Conservation at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. Cynthia specializes in underwater photography of difficult to film marine mammals. She has experience in broadcast journalism for environmental issues.

4) Laurie Harvey is a seabird ecologist and founder of Sutil Conservation Ecology.  Her main interest is the breeding biology and reproductive performance of seabirds. She specializes in project design and logistics to facilitate habitat restoration at remote island locations, and recently became a licensed captain.

5) Jesus Reyes is President of the Pacific Coast Environmental Conservancy. He studies impacts on endocrine systems of wild fishes from human generated waste.

6) Lorena M. Rios is  Assistant Professor of Chemistry at University of Wisconsin Superior. She focuses on persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in sediments, tissues, water, and plastic debris, especially microplastics ingested by fish.


While the team is living in the center of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch aboard ORV Alguita for 30 days, they are collecting samples to bring back to the lab for testing. 


Check out the video below sent from the team while out at sea!



MAKING HISTORY...

By utilizing an advanced drone and satellite aboard ORV Alguita, the team is able to take and send photos/blogs of their daily activities. 
While the team was traveling to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, they came across a large "plastic island." 

"For years I have been telling people that there is no such thing as a “plastic island” in the Pacific Gyre. I now have a map of one that has aspects of permanence, a metal anchor 40 feet deep, solid rope beaches, some of which you can walk on as if you were on land. A sad note is that the jagged metal below the island has snagged monofilament gill nets with fish caught in them that have decayed, which we named the mausoleum. There are also driftwood logs caught in ropes. As far as I know, this is the first pelagic plastic island found floating in the North Pacific Gyre, with features that mimic hills, rocky coastlines, coves, beaches and ponds. In total area, it is about the size of our Oceanographic Research Vessel Alguita," noted Captain Moore.


"YOU FOUND WHAT?!?" SAID THE MEDIA...
This "plastic island" quickly caught the attention of the media:
>>>Long Beach Press Telegram features Captain Moore and his crew's expedition!
>>>ABC7 Interview with Marieta Francis, Executive Director - Algalita
>>>The Weather Channel Interviews Captain Moore while at sea!

SO WHAT'S NEXT?

We need funding to run tests on all of the samples collected when the team returns to Long Beach, CA. The generosity of those who were able to donate to our cause in the previous Indiegogo campaign helped the team embark on this expedition and we are very grateful. But now we need real funding for real work... and we need your help to do it!

We have put together some really cool perks so that when you donate to our phenomenal 501 (c)3 non-profit, we give you something unique in return to show our appreciation! (Of course, there is always the great perk of your donation being tax deductible since you are donating to a 501(c)3!)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute right now, please support our research by doing the following:
  • Help us get the word out and tell your friends about Captain Moore's JULY/AUGUST 2014 EXPEDITION to "The Great Pacific Garbage Patch."
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word!

We have put together some really cool perks so that when you donate to our phenomenal 501 (c)3 non-profit, we give you something unique in return to show our appreciation! (Of course, there is always the great perk of your donation being tax deductible since you are donating to a 501(c)3!)



Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t contribute right now, please support our research by doing the following:
Help us get the word out and tell your friends about Captain Moore's JULY/AUGUST 2014 EXPEDITION to "The Great Pacific Garbage Patch."

story:
Short Summary

Greetings from MareCet!

We are a young local non-profit non-governmental organization that is dedicated to the research, education, awareness and conservation of marine mammals (whales, dolphins, porpoises, dugongs) in Malaysia. 

What We Need & What You Get

Sound science: To improve/increase our knowledge and understanding of marine mammals through strong scientific research and fundamentals.

Improving Management: To conserve and better manage marine mammals through policy advocacy.

Sharing knowledge: To promote the study, understanding and appreciation of marine mammals and the marine environment to people of all ages.

Building capacity: To build a home-grown team of young Malaysian marine biologists to study and care for the marine environment.

Risks & Challenges

URGENT APPEAL FOR DONATIONS: Yesterday (8 November 2014), while we were on our dolphin survey in Matang, we were hit by a big wave while we stopped for refuelling, which caused our boat to tip over and capsized. Thankfully, after many hours, our entire research team managed to get to the nearest village on land after trekking through mangrove forests and swimming across rivers. Unfortunately, we have lost most of our main research equipments including two DSLR cameras and zoom lens, binoculars, GPS and a multiparameter water sampler. The total cost of which amounts to approximately RM35,000. Therefore, we are appealing for public donations to assist us in replacing these equipment losses in order for us to continue our work in the near future. Donations may be made through this donation site, https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/dolphin-research-emergency-funding-for-continuity or for direct deposit to our MareCet account, please message us for the account number. Thank you in advance for your generosity. Once we are able to repurchase all equipment, we will post an update here.We need your help. These researchers are probably the nicest most dedicated people you will meet, they are out there on a daily basis doing their best to find a way to save our eco-system. Please lend them a hand. If your company has a CSR program I am appealing for some donation to help them continue their research. They have also lost their own personal belongings, but they will carry on.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can help please message us on facebook if you prefer to pay directly at 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Langkawi-Dolphin-Research/129739273751047?fref=ts 

Thank you so much !

story:
Please note that the crowdfunding project has now moved to the following site:

http://www.sponsume.com/project/voices-transition


Thank you all, Dear funders!


We made it to the goal this time! I’m very happy about that and am looking forward to complete the film very soon…

Still, there’s a lot of high expenses which will need urgent financing: paying the Parisian mixing studio a (relatively cheap) fee, the labour-intensive subtitling, the building of a “master” copy of the film, the edition of the DVD with graphic design works, the distribution of the film in festivals and other places, juridical advice… So I’ve decided to open a new crowdfunding website:


http://www.sponsume.com/project/voices-transition


Big hugs and best greetings to all of you!
Nils



Contents of the film

Climate change is a sad fact. Peak oil is another. Add economic instability to the picture and we are faced with food insecurity, probably the single most important threat to our civilization.

Voices of the Transition is a film about how to take on these challenges. Positively. The issue is not only mere survival, but rather the possibility of thriving and improving our quality of life!

These “voices of the Transition” tell us of a future society where our deserts will once again be living soil, where fields will be introduced into our cities, and where independence from oil will help us to live a richer, more fulfilling life.


Part I - France is at the forefront of research in agroforestry: Agronomists and peasants tell us of the return of the trees into our lifeless monoculture deserts, and about the immense advantages of a diverse farming system.

Part II - The English „Transition Town Initiatives“, founded in 2006, represent a whole new way of generating new visions of a more liveable future and of acquiring the collective means to make them become reality at a community level. This steadily growing movement offers extraordinary possibilities to prepare for future shocks, without having to wait for directional changes in big politics.

Part III – In Cuba in the 1990’s an entire nation suffered from the bitter consequences of an early „Peak Oil“. Thanks to their inventiveness and political openness to non-capitalist solutions, Cuba has now become the precursor in agro-ecology and urban agriculture.


Production

Voices of the Transition is an entirely self-produced, politically independent, non-commercial film project. It thus requires a lot of voluntary work. Our aim is to convey the solutions showcased in the film (ranging from permaculture and agro-ecology to the Transition Town movement) to a broader public. We hope to show the film in schools, public institutions and at festivals. Ideally, after recovering the costs, the film will be available for free web streaming. A DVD in 6 different languages will be produced (German, English, Spanish, French, Portuguese, Italian).



Your contribution

We will use the funds in our honorary project for the postproduction process: color correction, sound mix in professional conditions, subtitling of the film, editing of a DVD, and payment of rights for archive material. The great voice you hear in the trailer belongs to the Brasilian singer "Renata Rosa", whom we had to pay for the utilization of the song. 




“glossary of terms”
————————

- Peak Oil is the point in time when the maximum rate of global petroleum extraction is reached, after which the rate of production enters permanent decline.

- Permaculture is an approach to designing human settlements and agricultural systems that mimic the relationships found in natural ecosystems.

- Transition movement – A Transition Initiative is a self-organised, community-led response to the pressures of climate change, fossil fuel depletion and, increasingly, economic contraction. Priority lies in first raising awareness, and then moving on to self-organizing in groups, in order to actively build up sustainable living and resilience on a local level.

- Agroforestry – Agroforestry is an integrated approach of using the interactive benefits from combining trees and shrubs with crops and/or livestock. It combines agricultural and forestry technologies to design more diverse, productive, profitable, healthy and sustainable land-use systems.

- Food Sovereignty – The concept of Food sovereignty claims an international right that would guarantee countries to put in place best adapted agricultural policies – which would respond to the needs of their populations without being harmful to populations of other countries.

- Community-supported agriculture – A CSA consists of a community of individuals who pledge support to a farm operation where the growers and consumers share the risks and benefits of food production. CSAs usually consist of a system of weekly delivery or pick-up of vegetables and fruit in a vegetable box scheme, sometimes including dairy products and meat.



Many thousand thanks to those who already have generously contributed to this project!!


John Lee
Marian Weaver
Jean-luc Henry
Emmanuelle Laleu
Bruno Acloque
Thomas Ungricht
Rüdiger Rowold
Antonio Martinez
Gerd Wessling
Sabine Petersen
Cinzia Fenoglio
Florian Jesse
Gregor Lersch
Hannes Steinhilber
Dawn Baggaley
Dawn Bowles
Massimiliano Lanza
Gerhard Lienau
Maren Coldewey
Carolina Macedo Haddad
Mathilde Harvey
Emilio Luque
Stefanie Griesse
Energico
Andreas
Josue Dusoulier
Marianne Rambaud
Martin Zbinden
Pablo Blanco
Tobias Polzin
Manfred Trautwein
Guy Morvan
Ath en Transition
Andrea Philipp
Andreas Staempfli
Fabian Dortu


Not to forget all those who preferred not to reveal their identity!

Contents of the film

Climate change is a sad fact. Peak oil is another. Add economic instability to the
picture and we are faced with food
insecurity, probably the single most important threat to our civilization.
Voices of the Transition is a film about how to take on these challenges. Positively. The issue
is not only mere survival, but rather the possibility of thriving and improving
our quality of life!
These “voices of the Transition” tell us of a
future society where our deserts will once again be living soil, where fields
will be introduced into our cities, and where independence from oil will help
us to live a richer, more fulfilling life.

Part I - France is at the forefront of
research in agroforestry: Agronomists and peasants tell us of the return of the
trees into our lifeless monoculture deserts, and about the immense advantages
of a diverse farming system. 
Part II - The English
„Transition Town Initiatives“, founded in 2006, represent a whole new
way of generating new visions of a more liveable future and of acquiring the
collective means to make them become reality at a community level. This
steadily growing movement offers extraordinary possibilities to prepare for
future shocks, without having to wait for directional changes in big politics. 
Part III – In Cuba in the 1990’s an entire
nation suffered from the bitter consequences of an early „Peak Oil“. Thanks to
their inventiveness and political openness to non-capitalist solutions, Cuba
has now become the precursor in agro-ecology and urban agriculture. 

Production 


Voices of the Transition is an entirely self-produced, politically independent, non-commercial
film project. It thus requires a lot of voluntary work. Our aim is to convey
the solutions showcased in the film (ranging from permaculture and agro-ecology
to the Transition Town movement) to a broader public. We hope to show the film
in schools, public institutions and at festivals. Ideally, after recovering the
costs, the film will be available for free web streaming. A DVD in 6 different
languages will be produced (German, English, Spanish, French, Portuguese,
Italian).


Your contribution 
We will use the funds in our honorary project for the postproduction process: color correction, sound mix in professional conditions, subtitling of the film, editing of a DVD, and payment of rights for archive material. The great voice you hear in the trailer belongs to the Brasilian singer "Renata Rosa", whom we had to pay for the utilization of the song. 



“glossary of terms”————————
-
Peak Oil is the point in time when the maximum rate of
global petroleum extraction is reached, after which the rate of production
enters permanent decline.
-
Permaculture is an approach to designing human settlements
and agricultural systems that mimic the relationships found in natural
ecosystems.
-
Transition movement – A Transition Initiative is a self-organised,
community-led response to the pressures of climate change, fossil fuel
depletion and, increasingly, economic contraction. Priority lies in first
raising awareness, and then moving on to self-organizing in groups, in order to
actively build up sustainable living and resilience on a local level.
-
Agroforestry – Agroforestry is an integrated approach of
using the interactive benefits from combining trees and shrubs with crops
and/or livestock. It combines agricultural and forestry technologies to design
more diverse, productive, profitable, healthy and sustainable land-use systems.
-
Food Sovereignty – The concept of Food sovereignty claims an international right that would guarantee
countries to put in place best adapted agricultural policies – which would
respond to the needs of their populations without being harmful to populations
of other countries.
-
Community-supported agriculture
– A CSA consists of a community of individuals
who pledge support to a farm operation where the growers and consumers share
the risks and benefits of food production. CSAs usually consist of a system of
weekly delivery or pick-up of vegetables and fruit in a vegetable box scheme,
sometimes including dairy products and meat.


Many thousand thanks to those who already have generously contributed to this project!!
John LeeMarian WeaverJean-luc HenryEmmanuelle LaleuBruno AcloqueThomas UngrichtRüdiger RowoldAntonio MartinezGerd WesslingSabine PetersenCinzia FenoglioFlorian JesseGregor LerschHannes SteinhilberDawn BaggaleyDawn BowlesMassimiliano LanzaGerhard LienauMaren ColdeweyCarolina Macedo HaddadMathilde HarveyEmilio LuqueStefanie GriesseEnergicoAndreasJosue DusoulierMarianne RambaudMartin ZbindenPablo BlancoTobias PolzinManfred TrautweinGuy MorvanAth en TransitionAndrea PhilippAndreas StaempfliFabian DortuNot to forget all those who preferred not to reveal their identity!

story:
Short Summary

  • Could a toddler in your home slip out a door left open and fall into the pool?
  • Have you or the kids ever left the door open and all the heat or air conditioning rushed out the door?
  • Has your pet ever escaped out an open door and run into the street?
  • Do you rent and look for ways to save money and make more profit?
 
iAutoClose is the perfect answer for all of these questions.  It is a low-tech, low-cost, easily installed solution to automatically closing conventional swing & sliding doors behind you.
 
I am am inventor and when my mom got Alzheimer's and could not remember to close the door of our home....I invented iAutoClose!
 

What We Need & What You Get

So many people wanted iAutoClose in my neighborhood, we invested the $30,000 to build the molds and move from prototype to product. Now I need your help to get the product produced in quantities and get it to the market place.

We need $5,200 to get the parts made and assembled in packaging to sell online and in stores. We have a patent and trademark and when we get additional funds we will get the brand registered.

If, for some reason, we do not reach our goal we will limit our marketing to online.

Our online presence will not only market our product it will build a social network of the homes, children and pets we are protecting.  When you contribute at certain levels we will add your photos to our site and you can share your experiences with other iAutoClose users.  At the highest levels we will use a photo of your child or pet on our packaging!!! They will be the stars of our brand!

The Impact

  • iAutoClose saves lives: Kids aged 1-4 most often drown in home pools? 60% of all children’s deaths occur in swimming pools.
  • iAutoClose saves energy: consider the impact on the environment of doors left open and the heat and or air conditioning rushes out the door.
  • iAutoClose saves money: you will see the impact in your energy bill.  We have developers testing right now and they are gathering stats for us to add to our marketing.
  • iAutoClose is a geat investment:will sell for only $19.99 and the ROI for the home,condo, complex owner will be immediate.

Other Ways You Can Help;

Take a look at YouTube at how easily iAutoclose installs

Please help us get this wonderful product to market... invest your money, invest your enthusiasm and spread the word using IndieGoGo share tools!

This will be my legacy and my best invetion to date!

story:
DeSmog UK Need Your Help

  • DeSmog UK is a small investigative journalist team dedicated to uncovering corporate wrongdoing, climate denial networks and fossil fuel disinformation.
  • We are independent media. We don't take advertising and we don't have corporate donors. We rely on your support to continue our work.
  • By backing us you will allow us to continue to reveal the shadowy networks profiting from the climate crisis and pushing to prevent climate action.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are seeking to raise £20,000 to support our ongoing investigations.
  • We have some unique perks to thanks you for your support.
  • Your support is vital to enable our small team of dedicated journalists to carry on exposing the real story behind climate change.

Our Work

Over the past few years we've: 

  • Created a disinformation database tracking the people and organisations pushing covert corporate lies
  • Published a major investigation, Empire Oil, that exposed a shady neocolonial network of oil investments across Africa
  • Uncovered the dubious new surveillance techniques being used against peaceful environmental protestors
  • Revealed the environmentally disastrous transatlantic deals being brokered behind closed doors as Brexit looms 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are seriously skint maybe you can help us by sharing this campaign to your friends - follow us on Facebook and Twitter @DeSmogUK
  • Check out www.desmog.uk  and tell people how great we are!
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

Thanks!

We are independent media. We don't take advertising and we don't have corporate donors. We rely on your support to continue our work.
By backing us you will allow us to continue to reveal the shadowy networks profiting from the climate crisis and pushing to prevent climate action.

Your support is vital to enable our small team of dedicated journalists to carry on exposing the real story behind climate change.

Created a disinformation database tracking the people and organisations pushing covert corporate lies

Uncovered the dubious new surveillance techniques being used against peaceful environmental protestors

Check out www.desmog.uk  and tell people how great we are!
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Thanks!

story:
ORDER NOW AT: http://www.homebiogas.com

HomeBiogas is a family-sized affordable biogas system. It converts any organic waste into clean cooking gas and a high quality liquid fertilizer for the garden. Your kitchen leftovers can turn into 3 hours of cooking per day. You’ll be cooking dinner with the gas produced from lunch’s leftovers. Pretty amazing, right?


HomeBiogas maintains a closed-loop eco-cycle: organic waste turns into energy and a liquid fertilizer byproduct which enables us to produce more food thus maintaining the critical cycle of life. Know exactly where your energy is coming from and where it’s going.

Many of us have tried to reduce the damage being done to our planet, but without addressing the larger issues, it often feels like a drop in the bucket.

This is a small product with a big impact.

By significantly reducing the damage caused by untreated organic waste, including air pollution, water contamination and the use of fossil fuels for energy, HomeBiogas systems respond to some of our most pressing environmental challenges today.

Our vision is to make our biogas system accessible and affordable for everyone. 

Join us and help pave the way for sustainable waste management. We’re in this for the long run.


Dr. Thomas H. Cullhane, Urban Planner and Founder of Solar Cities.

Ron Gonen, Co-founder of the Closed Loop Fund, former deputy commissioner of Sanitation Recycling and Sustainability in NYC.

Reut Tutti, Environmentalist and activist.



Biogas is a renewable fuel that is produced by the decomposition of organic matter in an environment absent of oxygen. Biogas is made up of several gases, primarily methane (CH4 ) and carbon dioxide (CO2), which can be stored and directed for cooking. 



Up to 6 liters a day of any food waste, including meat and dairy

  • These amounts are the maximum per day, but even one third of the quantity is enough to produce your daily gas consumption. 





On average, 1 Kg / 2.2 pounds of food waste produces about 200 liters or 7 Cubic feet of gas, which generates around one hour of cooking over a high flame. Therefore, at 6 liters / in 1.58 gallons of food scraps, one can generate 1-3 hours of cooking gas each day - the perfect amount for three meals. 



Each year that you use HomeBiogas, you eliminate one ton of organic waste, and reduce harmful emissions equivalent to six tons of carbon dioxide (CO2).  

Using HomeBiogas can offset your car’s carbon emissions!

That means that each year you use HomeBiogas you are reversing the hazardous greenhouse gases that your car emits. 

1 HomeBiogas + 1 car = 0 carbon







The HomeBiogas kit comes all in one box. It's easy to assemble, and you can conveniently do it yourself in your yard in only 2-3 hours.

we do recommend hiring a licensed gas technician to connect the system’s gas pipe to your kitchen stove.

  • HomeBiogas is perfect for all sized families. It is not meant for industrial use such as hotels or big restaurants.
  • Eco-villages, community centers, and educational organizations. HomeBiogas is a great environmental educational tool. It's permaculture in action! 
  • Ideal for farms as well as centers with small-scale animal husbandry, animal breeders, and other animal owners.
  • HomeBiogas can also be used in an urban environment located on rooftops.


  • Warm climate: The system works optimally in places with average day/night temperatures above 17 °C (64 F). Under this temperature the system will decrease its productivity. Our system is not suited for cold or freezing temperatures.
  •  Outdoor availability: You will need to place the system outdoors, so no apartments(sorry about that). HomeBiogas is a revolutionary family sized affordable biogas system.


1. Save up to 40% off retail price

2. Be the first to own HomeBiogas; own the newest in pragmatic and disruptive sustainable innovation and technology.

3. Take back control of your environmental footprint by minimizing your family’s methane emissions, waste production, and fossil fuel consumption.

4. With your support, we will be able to streamline production, reducing the cost to make it accessible to households and communities everywhere.

5. You can also donate HomeBiogas systems to non-profit organizations who support meaningful development efforts in underserved communities.






NGO: Innovation Africa

Project: Buvundya Orphanage, Uganda

The Buvundya Orphanage in Uganda provides housing, education, and meals to 518 orphans. Currently meals are prepared over an open fire creating an unhealthy and hazardous environment for the students and staff.

Your HomeBiogas donation to the Buyundya Orphanage will:

1. Ensure students and staff a safe and healthy environment for preparing food.

2.Enable students to focus on schooling, recreation, and personal interests instead of spending hours locating, cutting, and carrying firewood.

3. Provide educational inspiration and hands-on experience with innovative clean technology.

“HomeBiogas would truly transform the lives of the children by enabling them to utilize their organic waste and turn it into biogas for cooking and into fertilizer to grow fruits and vegetables. HomeBiogas will allow the children to maintain the highest quality of health standards.” 

-Genna Brand, Innovation Africa.

Join our campaign and directly improve the lives and health of over 500 children living in the Buvundya Orphanage.

--

NGO: Arava Institute for Environmental Studies (AIES)

Project: Middle East Biogas initiative

Contribute to the HomeBioGas-Arava Institute partnership to support peace-building, social justice, and environmental leadership and research in the Middle East. 

Your donation provides HomeBiogas systems to schools and education centers among underserved bedouin communities. 

Your donation to the HomeBiogas-Arava Institute for Environmental Studies (AIES)  partnership provides HomeBiogas systems to Bedouin schools and education centers in the Middle East. Systems we have already installed (see video below) and continue to install in these communities divert animal waste away from valuable water sources; ensure safe and healthy cooking environments; and provide an inspiring communal resource for clean tech innovation for parents and students alike.

These communities currently have no waste management infrastructure, meaning that all animal waste gets either burned or dumped nearby valuable water sources transferring harmful pollutants and toxins for children/community.

The Arava Institute for Environmental Studies, named one of the top 100 environmental research organizations in the world, is dedicated to solving regional and global environmental challenges through international cooperation initiatives, trans-boundary research, and capacity-building projects. Students at the Arava Institute are comprised of Jordanians, Palestinians, Israelis, and others from all over the world.

NGO: The Peres Center for Peace
Watch as the Peres Center for Peace, together with the Palestinian Wildlife Society and the Rabayah Group at the Partnership for Peace project funded by the EU work together to bring renewable energy to underserved Palestinian communities.





Waste capacity: The system can process up to 6 liters a day of food waste or 15 liters a day of animal manure.

Output: Depending on the amount of waste, can go up to three hours of cooking and 5 to 10 liters of liquid fertilizer per day. 

Minimum Ambient  Average Day/Night Temperature (necessary for operation): 17°C (66F).

Nominal gas pressure: 15 milliBar.

Built-in filter: Removes H2S. 

Built in fertilizer chlorinator.

Weight: less than 40 kg (88lbs). 

Dimensions: 123H/165L/100W cm (48”x65”x39.4”).





Operation:

Q: Do I need electricity to operate Hombiogas?

A: No. The system is 100% off-grid.

Q: How long after putting organic waste into HomeBiogas will it produce gas?

A: After installation, HomeBiogas may take between 2-4 weeks to produce gas.

Q: Is biogas production continuous?

A: Yes. As long as you feed the system, it will continue to produce gas.

Q: What happens if I don’t feed the system for a while?

A: The system will digest all the waste inside the tank then stop producing gas.

Once you get back to feeding the system it will return to continuous biogas production.


Installation:

Q: How long does it take to install HomeBiogas?

A: It takes two people about 2 hours to install HomeBiogas.

Q: Can I install the system by myself?

A: Yes. Anyone can assemble the biogas unit. However, connecting HomeBiogas’s gas pipe to the stove should be done by a licensed gas technician. Detailed instructions are provided with the system.

Q: How much water do I fill HomeBiogas with?

A: Initially, fill the tank with water to its full capacity(about 650 liter). Once HomeBiogas is in operation, remember to add one liter of water for every liter of waste added.

Q: How do I activate HomeBiogas?

A: You can activate HomeBiogas one of two ways. The most effective method is to use animal manure (specifically any animal that chews its cud i.e. a cow). If you don’t have access to animal manure, biogas bacteria starter kits can easily be acquired. Detailed instructions are provided with the system.


Performance:

Q: How much waste can I feed HomeBiogas each day?

A: You can input up to 6 liters (6qt) of food waste or up to 15 liters (15qt) of animal manure into HomeBiogas each day. If you feed the system with less, the amount of gas produced will be smaller.

Q: How much gas can I produce with HomeBiogas?

A: Every liter of food waste produces about 200 liters of gas, the amount needed to cooking for one hour over a high flame. On average, HomeBiogas produces 2-3 hours of cooking gas each day - the perfect amount for three meals.

Q: For how long does a gas burner and barbecue grill run on a full HomeBiogas tank?

A: A full HomeBiogas tank (400 liters of biogas) can fuel a three-blade barbecue grill for 45 minutes, and a typical stove burner for about two hours.

Q: How many liters of fertilizer can I get from HomeBiogas each day?

A: HomeBiogas can provide between 5-10 liters of top quality natural fertilizer each day.


Maintenance:

Q: What type of maintenance is involved with HomeBiogas?

A: We recommend maintaining your HomeBiogas unit once a year by:

1. Replacing its gas filter (takes a minute to do and filter cost about $20).

2. Removing the sludge that accumulates at the bottom of the digestion tank via the outlet pipe.


Safety & Warranty:

Q: Is HomeBiogas safe?

A: Yes. HomeBioGas was tested and received the European Community CE stamp of approval for safety. We are starting the process of getting UL approval. HomeBiogas was also tested and approved for safety and health by the Israeli Ministry of Environmental Protection and Ministry Of Energy and Infrastructure.

Q: Does HomeBiogas come with a warranty?

A: Yes. HomeBiogas comes with a 12 month limited parts and materials warranty.


Additional Info:

We highly recommend connecting HomeBiogas to a separate burner placed on your counter-top (bought separately), so it is simple to use Biogas and/or your existing gas system.

Q: Will it work in any weather?

A: HomeBiogas performs well when the day/night 24-hour average temperature is 17°C (63°F) and above. Once the temperature drops lower than that the unit’s gas output is significantly reduced. On the other hand the system will work very effectively in high temperatures, either humid or arid.

Q: What about cold countries?

A: We are developing a cold weather solution. Since we do not provide the solution as of yet, we can't recommend installing the system in cold weather countries. To get notified once the solution will be available follow us on facebook.

Q: Can I connect HomeBiogas to the existing appliances in my house?

A: Yes, but your home appliance, including your stove, need to be modified to support biogas. A single burner cannot be shared and used both for biogas and conventional gas.

Q: How do I convert my stove into a biogas stove?

A: You have to take out the pressure reducing nozzle (contact us for more details).

Q: Can I purchase the biogas stove from you?

A: No. You’ll need to purchase the stove locally.

Q: Can I use HomeBiogas for water heating?

A: Yes, but since the amount of gas produced will be sufficient for a maximum of 45 minutes of heating or less, we recommend using the gas for cooking and the fertilizer for the garden. This way you can complete a natural food cycle in your own home.

Q: Can I install HomeBiogas indoors?

A: We recommend  the installation of HomeBiogas outdoors because once the gas tank is in its full capacity (400L) any excess gas generated  will be released to the atmosphere.

Q: Can I fill HomeBiogas with grey water?

A: Yes. The system is grey water compatible.

Q:  I have a composter, what is the added benefit of biogas?

A: Composters are mostly suitable to process lawn cuttings, leaves, grass wood shavings and vegetarian matter. For many reasons, composters are not truly suitable for kitchen leftovers like meat, fish, oil and fats. HomeBiogas is complementary to the composter since it digests the remains that the composter cannot process, and it also provides cooking gas and liquid fertilizer for immediate use.

Q: What happens to the excess gas I don’t use?

A: The built in tank stores 400 liters of gas. Any additional gas generated by the system is automatically released and dissipates into the atmosphere.

Q: Can I store gas for a later use?

A: Theoretically yes, but we do not provide a solution for accumulating gas for later use. Our system aims for direct use of the gas generated by your daily waste. 


Performance

  • Gas production depends on the waste content that is being fed in, and might be less than expected.

Climate/weather

  • Our system can operate in warm and hot regions. If in any given month, the average day/night (24 hour) temperature drops below 18 degrees Centigrade (66 degrees Fahrenheit), the biological activity drops significantly and gas production will decrease.
  • Once it is full with water, exposure to temperatures below freezing point can cause damage to the system

Product related

  • Do not drink the fertilizer – plants love it, but it is not fit for humans.
  • The unit needs to be installed in an open space or a well ventilated enclosure and may not be installed indoors.
