story:
Penan communities are known around the world for their traditionally nomadic hunting-gathering life style, and for their connection with their tropical forest home. As the rainforest of Borneo has been destroyed, these proud communities have been forced to settle, and to make their living as farmers. 

Education has become a vital tool to help these communities protect their land by filing for legal land rights, and to fight for a better — more sustainable—future.

Upon entering school, Penan children can neither read nor speak Malay, the national language, and are therefore faced with the daunting task of not only absorbing a second language, but at the same time learning how to read in it. This places them at a huge disadvantage compared to other students who already speak Malay.

While a mastery of written Malay is an essential tool for protecting themselves against unscrupulous outsiders, it can have the paradoxical effect of weakening their own culture. The written word has tremendous prestige, and a language with no literature of its own is readily viewed as worthless and primitive in mainstream Malaysian culture. The government and other outside forces constantly bombard the Penan with the message that their culture is inferior.

Of course, this is far from the truth. The Penan have an extremely rich culture, consisting of thousands of suket,or ancient stories, the verbal expression of history, custom, and moral wisdom. Tragically, these stories are rarely being told; only some elders still remember them. Penans stand on the brink of losing the bulk of their culture in a single generation.

The Borneo Project is working to address both of these crucial issues.We are working in partnership with anthropologist Ian Mackenzie to identify traditional Penan stories and local artists who can provide illustrations. We are publishing these stories in durable books, and handing them out for free—one book per family— in Penan villages.The first run will be printed in Penan only, to support the idea that Penan stories don’t need to be in another language in order to be legitimate. Where art by local artists is not available, we are working with the Beehive Collective in Machias, Maine, who are providing beautiful sketches of tropical wildlife.

 In order to distribute the books as widely as possible, we have partnered with Martin Jones and Libby O’Connor, educators who live in Brunei Darrusalam and have worked with many Penan communities since 2002.Martin and Libby have published and distributed more than forty short elementary readers aimed primarily at Penan preschoolers. We have also partnered with the Bruno Manser Fund, a Switzerland-based NGO with years of experience in the region, and connections to many Penan communities.

 We are currently working on two titles, with more titles to come:

1) A series of short stories of Penan Frog myths

2) The story of the Flying Dragon and Turtle

Here are some of the illustrations, by indigenous Penan artists and Emily Simon/Beehive Collective.

story:
Our Story

I am a junior at University of Puget Sound. I have wanted to study abroad since I graduated high school, but unfortunately on the educational track and financial restraints I am under, I decided my needs would best be suited by volunteering with G.I.V.E for 2 weeks this summer.


The Impact

Volunteer initiatives include a large scale fresh water project, as well as providing water filtration systems for a small town that does not have clean drinking water. We are also building secondary schools and teaching english and vocational skills to children, as well as funding teachers to educate students year round. We are building homes for families that have been displaced due to a devastating tsunami. We will be working with doctors promoting basic health education and providing medical supplies. We will be doing a crocodile catch-and-release program to allow the crocs to breed in captivity, and also collecting endangered Hawks Bill turtle eggs to help increase their chances of survival. We are also implementing sustainable gardening methods and building gardens. None of this is charity - we are teaching the people of this region to be able to help themselves and raise their standard of living.


Read more about the volunteer initiatives here: http://www.givevolunteers.org/volunteer-initiatives.html


The program, including flight costs and traveler's insurance (required) I'm estimating to be $2000. This is not a conservative estimate. I fear costs may exceed this number, so everything is appreciated. I have already submitted a $375 deposit, and if I do not raise the money, I do not get this money back. As a college student any wasted money, especially such a large amount, makes my life much more difficult.


What We Need & What You Get

The money I raise will go toward the overall program cost ($1875) as well as travel costs to and from Miami and from Miami to Nicaragua. Traveler's insurance is also required. If I do not meet my goal, I have some money in savings, but as a college student, using this money for anything other than my future would be a huge financial setback. I am attending a private university and paying for it all myself. This means taking out loans in my name (not my parents) and working as well as attending school full time.

I will be selling knit items! I know that come April people will not need gloves and hats and scarves (etc) as much as they need them now, but I assure you that they will be high quality and will serve you well for many years. I also have several other people who have offered to sew, crochet, and even do henna to help me raise money for this excursion. Contact me if you would like something made for you you don't see in the "perks" section. All prices are subject to negotiation or change depending on difficulty. If you see something you like or have an idea of something you want, let me know! I'm always up to try making something I haven't tried before.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell anyone who is interested in helping people in 3rd world countries. Not just for survival, but for promoting social equality and education and self-sustainability. Also tell anyone who loves local handmade crafts!

story:
The Mountain Loop Conservancy is a non-profit group of citizens dedicated to preserving the natural beauty and watersheds along the Mountain Loop Highway in Snohomish county Washington through education and advocacy. 

Why we need your help

For the last few years we've been embroiled in a fight to stop construction of a motocross track that has been proposed about four miles northeast of Granite Falls up the Mountain Loop Highway. Part of the 437-acre site will be clear-cut for construction of the tracks. The county approved a rezone of this area from forestry to commercial. The impacts to people and animals that live nearby, and recreational users who use the area, were not considered.

Site of the proposed motocross at entrance to The Mountain Loop

For many years, recreational opportunities in this scenic valley have included hiking, climbing, camping, picnicking, fishing, hunting, sledding, bird watching, kayaking, and skiing.  These non-motorized activities have a low impact on the environment.  The Mountain Loop Highway is designated as a National Forest Scenic Byway. This area is one of the most popular attractions in the county and the 400,000 people that visit annually help support the local economy.

The proposed site has many interesting characteristics. The area supports a wide variety of wildlife including bald eagles, spotted owls, deer, cougar, salmon, and trout. The threatened marbled murrelet, a small seabird, nests in the forests of the region. Rainfall varies from 100 to 130 or more inches per year and the mossy, forested habitat reflects this. The aquifer underlying the site is designated as a high sensitivity critical aquifer recharge area.Wooded mountains descend down to valleys crisscrossed with rivers and streams, accessed by hiking trails including the robe valley trail. The project area is part of a Mineral Resource Overlay (MRO) and development on this type of land is supposed to be limited. 

Lime Kiln Trail

Impacts on the environment

The permit for this project allows operations seven days a week, camping on-site, and regional motocross races with up to 800 people. They will have ATVs and snowmobiles on the tracks in the future.

The proposed project will cause significant impacts. Traffic problems, noise, dust and air pollution, water and drainage issues will result from this development. This rural area has very limited emergency services¾the fire department is a small all-volunteer force and law enforcement staff covers a huge region. Part of the site is designated as a high risk landslide area. People and wildlife using the area will suffer due to this project.

Visit mtloopconservancy.org  to learn more about The Mountain Loop and the proposed motocross project.

Playing in the South Fork Stillaguamish River

We need your support to pay for the legal defense of this site

This project has been in the review process for more than seven years now. The Mountain Loop Conservancy has been active in following the case but the developer seems to get breaks that other applicants are not getting.

The Mountain Loop Conservancy stepped up and demanded a hearing to appeal the county finding of Mitigated Determination of Non-Significance (MDNS). We hired a well-respected environmental lawyer and had a number of expert witnesses testify. After a week of hearings, more written work, and a month of deliberations we were very disappointed when the Hearing Examiner ruled in favor of the developer. But the fight isn't over quite yet. The hearing has been reopened to address issues we brought up after his finding.

Heather Lake

What We Need & What You Get

We have raised part of the money on our own but need at least $4,000 more to cover legal work through the final rounds of this battle. We are a non-profit 501(c)(3) volunteer organization - every penny you donate goes directly into the fight. 

We are offering a number of perks for different levels of contributions.

The Impact

If we can stop this track it will help preserve the beauty and serenity of a region well known for the many recreational opportunities it offers. People that live in nearby urban areas can continue to enjoy the peaceful beautiful Mountain Loop area. Children can learn about the wonders of the environment by experiencing it firsthand. Residents can enjoy the peace and quiet that attracted them to the area. Wildlife can continue to live their lives in a natural setting.

The Mountain Loop Conservancy would like to focus our time on educating people about the environment in the area. Please help us reach our goal by saving the Mountain Loop from this huge development.

Moonrise over Liberty Mt.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Spread the word and tell your friends (Facebook or otherwise) to visit this site.

story:
Jan 31, 2014 Update:

The campaign ended last night, and donations are still trickling in. I won't come close to the financial goal of this project, but I got everything I needed! People gave me energy, time and material offerings, all of which you can't put a monetary value on.

If you would still like to make a donation towards this worthwhile project, you can contact me via email. 

Thanks to everyone who shared a kind word and made donations during this process! Onward into the gardening season!

Jan 29, 2014 Update:

ONLY 2 MORE DAYS in this campaign! We are down to the final hours! I have received SO much from so many people, and I appreciate every word, every gesture, every share, every dollar. The Taos Seed Exchange will blossom in 2014, and you can be proud you helped! 

Please continue to share these ideas of helping Taos gardeners grow with seeds, plants, workshops and gardening info. I need your help to put great and necessary things into my community. When you share, I can share. The Taos Seed Exchange started on sharing, and it will continue to grow in an atmosphere of sharing. 

Thank you!

Jan 26, 2014 Update:

There are ONLY 4 MORE DAYS in this campaign! Great news, too! 

The Seed Exchange stations have been successfully taken care of! Please see the email updates for details. 

It's onward to the next project to get rolling, a Seed Swap. Your donations will help me rent the perfect venue and find the perfect food to serve!

Please donate towards this event and future events that help gardeners blossom! If all my friends and you and all your friends donated a mere $5, we could make a huge difference in the Taos gardening scene!

ONLY 4 MORE DAYS! It's down to the wire! 

I am blessed that so much has come my way. With your donations, I can pay it forward. Thank you!

Jan 25, 2014 Update:

Happy National Seed Swap Day! In honor of this day, I have set up a Seed Exchange station in a local food co-op, the Dixon Market!

There are boxes for seeds and envelopes for disbursing them. A how-to poster hangs above. It's a simple set-up, but serves an entire community 30 miles south of Taos. Dixon is considered a food desert, because it is so far from a large grocery store. A Seed Exchange station will help residents grow food and save seed.

Boxes are decorated with pictures from old seed catalogs. Seeds were donated by several non-GMO seed companies, and some of the seed was grown out locally last year. Instructions are clear with photos. People bring in their seed and trade it for something that's new to them! Happy seed swapping!

Thanks for your continued support!

Each station will have a retail seed rack for people who want to supplement what they find in the exchange or to buy as a trade item. I used the kickstarter money donated so far to buy this rack from Renee's Garden Seeds. It is a beautiful display, and the customers and staff in the store were excited to have my project there!

Kickstarter money also bought this countertop display of Renee's Garden Seeds at a consignment store called ReThreads, too! Thank you for your continued support! Donations are being used already! 

Jan 20, 2014 Update:

Happy Martin Luther King Jr Day! Get inspired fearlessly!

This campaign runs for only 10 MORE DAYS! 

Read the updates that I email out to see what we're doing and where we're going. We are getting lots of media exposure, and there is much more to come! 

Consider a Sponsorship as a way to advertise your business. I am also listing all donors on my website within the next couple of days. 

Thanks for your support! Scroll down for details about the Taos Seed Exchange, if this is your first visit!

Jan 16, 2014 Update:

Howdy, and thanks for visiting!

The campaign runs for only TWO MORE WEEKS! 

Please donate and spread the word to everyone you know! Encourage them to get involved with donations and sharing. Every penny that comes in will be put to good use to ensure that Taos gardeners have what they need, be it seed, plants or information.

I am getting very busy with seed orders and planting plans. It is going to be a prosperous year! Thank you so much for being part of it!

 Greetings!

My name is Nan Fischer, and I started the Taos Seed Exchange in Taos, New Mexico last winter. It is a free community service for home gardeners to swap seeds. It's very simple - gardeners bring seed to a Seed Exchange station and trade it for something they need or something they want to experiment with. Simple! 

I want to expand the number of stations in 2014 and add retail seed racks of organic and non-GMO seeds. This is what Taos gardeners have requested! I'd also like to provide nursery starts, drought tolerant plants that attract bees, gardening workshops, movies, and a spring seed swap.

With your generous donations, I'd like to raise $25,000 to help Taos County gardeners grow food! In return, you could receive a gift certificate good towards all products and services, non-GMO seeds, nursery starts grown without pesticides, CSA shares of starts and seeds delivered to you at planting time, or your business name prominently displayed at a station and in all the marketing materials!

What I Did in 2013

The Taos Seed Exchange was started with $200 of my own money and 200 of my spare-time hours. 

Hundreds of pounds of seed were donated by a few seed companies and many local seed-saving gardeners. I set up Seed Exchange stations in progressive businesses around the county.

I was not sure if this was going to work, but at the end of the season, 95% of the seed donated was traded by new and experienced gardeners! Seed got into the hands of people who needed it to feed their families.

I'd like to expand my operations in 2014 and offer things Taos County gardeners asked for: non-GMO and organic seed to buy, nursery starts, drought tolerant plants for water conservation, native plants to attract bees, and workshops. 

Detail of the Seed Exchange station at More Pieces, a consignment store:

What Taos Wants in 2014

In order to give local gardeners what they want, I would like to raise $25,000 for the 2014 season and beyond! These items are in order of importance: 

> Buy seed to put in the Seed Exchange stations. With the number of stations increasing, I need more seed than I can garner through donations. I already bought 50 packets of seed from Johnny's and Seed Savers Exchange, and I'd like to be able to buy more. 

> Buy seed for resale. Since the Taos Seed Exchange doesn't provide all the seed gardeners need, I want to offer seed for sale along with each Seed Exchange station. All seed would be non-GMO and open-pollinated for seed saving, and organic where possible.

> Hire someone to build stations, customized for each location. I already have 7 businesses committed to the 2014 growing season, and after the holidays I will be contacting more to expand further. My goal is 10 stations this year.

It will cost between $700-1500 per station to set them up. This is the biggest financial need I have - buying seed and building stations with all the supplies.

Once those expenses are taken care of, these are the next in line to be funded:

> Buy supplies for growing starts: 6-packs, 4" pots, trays, seed, soil, fertilizer and a cold frame. Ideally, I need a bigger greenhouse, but before I can build that, I need to drill a private well (I'm on a well-share). I also want to grow and sell native and drought tolerant shrubs and perennials.

> Sponsor a large seed swap in the spring with food, music, and gardening products for sale.

> Hire local gardeners to give workshops on starting seed, soil health, gardening for bees, seed saving, putting food up for winter and so on - all segments of a growing season.

> Sponsor food and gardening related movies at our independent local theater.

> Contract with local artisans to create planters, solar food dehydrators, small greenhouses and other products.

Please Donate and Spread the Word!

As Monsanto buys up small seed companies and threatens small farmers with extinction, we must share seeds! Neighbor-to-neighbor and gardener-to-gardener seed sharing is a hedge against Monsanto and increases our community's food security. It also contributes to our local food system.

In the name of educating new gardeners to get them started, helping experienced gardeners trade their huge seed stashes, and getting seeds and plants into the hands of people eager to take control of their food source, PLEASE HELP! In exchange for your donation, you can receive

> non-GMO seeds

> CSA shares of vegetable, flower and herb seeds and starts delivered at the right time to plant in your garden

> T-shirts

> Water bottles

> Gift certificates

> Good karma and the knowledge that you have helped someone grow their own food!

If you cannot make a monetary donation, please share this fundraiser with friends, family, co-workers, acquaintances and strangers! Use the share tools on this page - it's so easy!

If you believe it's important that home gardeners grow their own food, then please tell everyone you know to support the Taos Seed Exchange! 

THANK YOU!

Midsummer starts of chard, lettuce, broccoli, oregano - 2013:

About Me & Giving Back to the Community

I have been gardening and farming organically and landscaping with native plants for almost 40 years. I have a degree in plant science and a certificate in landscape design. I grow most of my own food and barter for the rest. My favorite thing about gardening, though, is starting plants from seed. This project lets me share that joy with my community as well as preserve the diversity of the plant world.

The most exciting part of the Seed Exchange is being able to offer seed and plants to other gardeners. I grew starts last year and donated several hundred dollars' worth to the Taos School of Integrated Arts (TISA). In 2014, I'll be donating to Vista Grande High School for their raised bed gardens, and to Not Forgotten Outreach, an organization that created the Taos Veterans Memorial Garden & Farming Project for disabled vets. 

About the Team

I have brought on board two extraordinary gardeners, Mona Makela and Marsha Webb. These women inspire me as we trade food, seeds and plants for the best eating experiences we can have! Both have supported me throughout this project. They help me overcome my doubts and push me farther than I would go on my own. Marsha is an accomplished musician donating her time at fundraisers, and Mona designed the logo with her exceptional graphic design skills. 

For More Information

Look through the gallery for photos of Seed Exchange stations and some of the plants Taos gardeners grew!

Check out the Media Page on the website for radio, magazine and newspaper interviews.

Read more about the Taos Seed Exchange on the website, sweetlyseeds.com, where you will find info about CSA shares and the Safe Seed Pledge. There is a free online seedbank you can participate in, you can subscribe to the newsletter and read the gardening blog! Like the Facebook page for garden and food news as well as updates about the Taos Seed Exchange and this fundraising campaign!

Taos gardeners thank you for your support!

Let's make 2014 the BEST gardening season EVER!
story_txt: Jan 31, 2014 Update:The campaign ended last night, and donations are still trickling in. I won't come close to the financial goal of this project, but I got everything I needed! People gave me energy, time and material offerings, all of which you can't put a monetary value on.If you would still like to make a donation towards this worthwhile project, you can contact me via email. Thanks to everyone who shared a kind word and made donations during this process! Onward into the gardening season!Jan 29, 2014 Update:ONLY 2 MORE DAYS in this campaign! We are down to the final hours! I have received SO much from so many people, and I appreciate every word, every gesture, every share, every dollar. The Taos Seed Exchange will blossom in 2014, and you can be proud you helped! Please continue to share these ideas of helping Taos gardeners grow with seeds, plants, workshops and gardening info. I need your help to put great and necessary things into my community. When you share, I can share. The Taos Seed Exchange started on sharing, and it will continue to grow in an atmosphere of sharing. Thank you!Jan 26, 2014 Update:There are ONLY 4 MORE DAYS in this campaign! Great news, too! The Seed Exchange stations have been successfully taken care of! Please see the email updates for details. It's onward to the next project to get rolling, a Seed Swap. Your donations will help me rent the perfect venue and find the perfect food to serve!Please donate towards this event and future events that help gardeners blossom! If all my friends and you and all your friends donated a mere $5, we could make a huge difference in the Taos gardening scene!ONLY 4 MORE DAYS! It's down to the wire! I am blessed that so much has come my way. With your donations, I can pay it forward. Thank you!Jan 25, 2014 Update:Happy National Seed Swap Day! In honor of this day, I have set up a Seed Exchange station in a local food co-op, the Dixon Market!There are boxes for seeds and envelopes for disbursing them. A how-to poster hangs above. It's a simple set-up, but serves an entire community 30 miles south of Taos. Dixon is considered a food desert, because it is so far from a large grocery store. A Seed Exchange station will help residents grow food and save seed.Boxes are decorated with pictures from old seed catalogs. Seeds were donated by several non-GMO seed companies, and some of the seed was grown out locally last year. Instructions are clear with photos. People bring in their seed and trade it for something that's new to them! Happy seed swapping!Thanks for your continued support!Each station will have a retail seed rack for people who want to supplement what they find in the exchange or to buy as a trade item. I used the kickstarter money donated so far to buy this rack from Renee's Garden Seeds. It is a beautiful display, and the customers and staff in the store were excited to have my project there!Kickstarter money also bought this countertop display of Renee's Garden Seeds at a consignment store called ReThreads, too! Thank you for your continued support! Donations are being used already! Jan 20, 2014 Update:Happy Martin Luther King Jr Day! Get inspired fearlessly!This campaign runs for only 10 MORE DAYS! Read the updates that I email out to see what we're doing and where we're going. We are getting lots of media exposure, and there is much more to come! Consider a Sponsorship as a way to advertise your business. I am also listing all donors on my website within the next couple of days. Thanks for your support! Scroll down for details about the Taos Seed Exchange, if this is your first visit!Jan 16, 2014 Update:Howdy, and thanks for visiting!The campaign runs for only TWO MORE WEEKS! Please donate and spread the word to everyone you know! Encourage them to get involved with donations and sharing. Every penny that comes in will be put to good use to ensure that Taos gardeners have what they need, be it seed, plants or information.I am getting very busy with seed orders and planting plans. It is going to be a prosperous year! Thank you so much for being part of it! Greetings!My name is Nan Fischer, and I started the Taos Seed Exchange in Taos, New Mexico last winter. It is a free community service for home gardeners to swap seeds. It's very simple - gardeners bring seed to a Seed Exchange station and trade it for something they need or something they want to experiment with. Simple! I want to expand the number of stations in 2014 and add retail seed racks of organic and non-GMO seeds. This is what Taos gardeners have requested! I'd also like to provide nursery starts, drought tolerant plants that attract bees, gardening workshops, movies, and a spring seed swap.With your generous donations, I'd like to raise $25,000 to help Taos County gardeners grow food! In return, you could receive a gift certificate good towards all products and services, non-GMO seeds, nursery starts grown without pesticides, CSA shares of starts and seeds delivered to you at planting time, or your business name prominently displayed at a station and in all the marketing materials!What I Did in 2013The Taos Seed Exchange was started with $200 of my own money and 200 of my spare-time hours. Hundreds of pounds of seed were donated by a few seed companies and many local seed-saving gardeners. I set up Seed Exchange stations in progressive businesses around the county.I was not sure if this was going to work, but at the end of the season, 95% of the seed donated was traded by new and experienced gardeners! Seed got into the hands of people who needed it to feed their families.I'd like to expand my operations in 2014 and offer things Taos County gardeners asked for: non-GMO and organic seed to buy, nursery starts, drought tolerant plants for water conservation, native plants to attract bees, and workshops. Detail of the Seed Exchange station at More Pieces, a consignment store:What Taos Wants in 2014In order to give local gardeners what they want, I would like to raise $25,000 for the 2014 season and beyond! These items are in order of importance: > Buy seed to put in the Seed Exchange stations. With the number of stations increasing, I need more seed than I can garner through donations. I already bought 50 packets of seed from Johnny's and Seed Savers Exchange, and I'd like to be able to buy more. > Buy seed for resale. Since the Taos Seed Exchange doesn't provide all the seed gardeners need, I want to offer seed for sale along with each Seed Exchange station. All seed would be non-GMO and open-pollinated for seed saving, and organic where possible.> Hire someone to build stations, customized for each location. I already have 7 businesses committed to the 2014 growing season, and after the holidays I will be contacting more to expand further. My goal is 10 stations this year.It will cost between $700-1500 per station to set them up. This is the biggest financial need I have - buying seed and building stations with all the supplies.Once those expenses are taken care of, these are the next in line to be funded:> Buy supplies for growing starts: 6-packs, 4" pots, trays, seed, soil, fertilizer and a cold frame. Ideally, I need a bigger greenhouse, but before I can build that, I need to drill a private well (I'm on a well-share). I also want to grow and sell native and drought tolerant shrubs and perennials.> Sponsor a large seed swap in the spring with food, music, and gardening products for sale.> Hire local gardeners to give workshops on starting seed, soil health, gardening for bees, seed saving, putting food up for winter and so on - all segments of a growing season.> Sponsor food and gardening related movies at our independent local theater.> Contract with local artisans to create planters, solar food dehydrators, small greenhouses and other products.Please Donate and Spread the Word!As Monsanto buys up small seed companies and threatens small farmers with extinction, we must share seeds! Neighbor-to-neighbor and gardener-to-gardener seed sharing is a hedge against Monsanto and increases our community's food security. It also contributes to our local food system.In the name of educating new gardeners to get them started, helping experienced gardeners trade their huge seed stashes, and getting seeds and plants into the hands of people eager to take control of their food source, PLEASE HELP! In exchange for your donation, you can receive> non-GMO seeds> CSA shares of vegetable, flower and herb seeds and starts delivered at the right time to plant in your garden> T-shirts> Water bottles> Gift certificates> Good karma and the knowledge that you have helped someone grow their own food!If you cannot make a monetary donation, please share this fundraiser with friends, family, co-workers, acquaintances and strangers! Use the share tools on this page - it's so easy!If you believe it's important that home gardeners grow their own food, then please tell everyone you know to support the Taos Seed Exchange! THANK YOU!Midsummer starts of chard, lettuce, broccoli, oregano - 2013:About Me & Giving Back to the CommunityI have been gardening and farming organically and landscaping with native plants for almost 40 years. I have a degree in plant science and a certificate in landscape design. I grow most of my own food and barter for the rest. My favorite thing about gardening, though, is starting plants from seed. This project lets me share that joy with my community as well as preserve the diversity of the plant world.The most exciting part of the Seed Exchange is being able to offer seed and plants to other gardeners. I grew starts last year and donated several hundred dollars' worth to the Taos School of Integrated Arts (TISA). In 2014, I'll be donating to Vista Grande High School for their raised bed gardens, and to Not Forgotten Outreach, an organization that created the Taos Veterans Memorial Garden & Farming Project for disabled vets. About the TeamI have brought on board two extraordinary gardeners, Mona Makela and Marsha Webb. These women inspire me as we trade food, seeds and plants for the best eating experiences we can have! Both have supported me throughout this project. They help me overcome my doubts and push me farther than I would go on my own. Marsha is an accomplished musician donating her time at fundraisers, and Mona designed the logo with her exceptional graphic design skills. For More InformationLook through the gallery for photos of Seed Exchange stations and some of the plants Taos gardeners grew!Check out the Media Page on the website for radio, magazine and newspaper interviews.Read more about the Taos Seed Exchange on the website, sweetlyseeds.com, where you will find info about CSA shares and the Safe Seed Pledge. There is a free online seedbank you can participate in, you can subscribe to the newsletter and read the gardening blog! Like the Facebook page for garden and food news as well as updates about the Taos Seed Exchange and this fundraising campaign!Taos gardeners thank you for your support!Let's make 2014 the BEST gardening season EVER!

story:
Short Summary

This is a Renewable Energy Project, a Zero Waste Environmental Project a South South Development Project, a Fair Trade Sustainable Island Business Project, and is Replicable on other islands. 

Pacific Aid Australia is a not for profit non governmental international environmental agency with Australian tax destructibility status. We are a member of the United Nations Environment Program's South South Exchange Mechanism. Our mission is to support the Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) of the Pacific Islands. ESD requires all of society to work together - business, civil sector, NGO's, government, individuals and grant bodies - to build and support sustainable economic activities that generate ongoing livelihoods for generations to come. We have partnered with Taste of Tonga to help fund a Biomass Generator because this island business is a shining example of ESD, Renewable Energy Use, Zero Waste, South South Exchange, Fair Trade and it is Up-scalable. Taste of Tonga is an unusual business based on the isolated South Pacific island of Vava’u, The Kingdom of Tonga. Our focus is on developing a process that maximises the value of a coconut with a goal of zero waste. Vava’u has many coconuts and most go to waste as there is no industry in Vava’u that uses coconuts. Our mission is to produce quality products from the coconuts for export, replace imported products with locally produced alternatives and provide over 300 Tongan families with a sustainable income.

Ian and Vanessa's Story:

When we  ( Ian and Vanessa Jones) decided to move to Vava’u we did so with a specific aim to add value to the local community. Our aim was to start a business that capitalises on unused capacity and lost assets of Vava’u. We quickly identified two opportunities, an abundant supply of coconuts and 300 plus idle vanilla plantations that had been overrun by the tropical jungle. Our vision was to reactivate these two industries and establish a zero waste, environmentally friendly, organic, export and import replacement business that engages the grass root Tongan families.

Many of the people in Tonga live below the poverty line. They have access to land, coconuts and vanilla but they have not been able to establish a market for their produce or access the capital to restore their plantations to productive capacity. It is from this foundation we began. We decided to put all our efforts into activating the lost assets of Vava’u and create a new sustainable income source for Tongan families.

The project commenced in September 2012. We established a proof of concept Virgin Coconut Oil (VCO) factory. The success of the factory then led to the commencement of the vanilla plantation restoration in 2013. With the assistance of Queen Fine Foods, (www.queen.com.au) we motivated almost 300 plantation owners to return to their vanilla plantations and recover the vanilla vines from the jungle and recommence production. Queen Fine Foods guaranteed the growers a market for their vanilla at a price substantially higher than the Fair Trade International guidelines. The farmers jumped at the opportunity to return to their vanilla with 98% participation.

In 2014 we scaled up the Virgin Coconut Oil factory to a level where we can produce 4,000 litres of oil each month. This requires us to process 60,000 coconuts every month and in turn deal with the waste from the coconut oil production.

By processing 60,000 coconuts to create  4,000 litres of VCO each month we end up with 63.9 ton of coconut husk, 13.8 ton of coconut shells, 10,115 litres of coconut water,11.7 ton of pressed coconut flakes and 1,445 litres of coconut protein. Disposing or the waste was a big problem and at the same time offered a ton of potential.

Many hours of research on Google and YouTube has brought us to a point where today. The project is near completion and the goal of zero waste is close to a reality.

The Zero Waste Process

Over the past two years we have gradually built a herd of almost 100 pigs and they all love coconuts. The pigs are the foundation of our waste utilisation plan.

However, we should start at the beginning, where a vanilla farmer collects and sells his coconuts to Taste of Tonga.

Our first step in the process is to remove the husk from the coconut. Once removed the husk is returned to the vanilla plantations and used as mulch for the vanilla vines. The vanilla vines are an orchid and they feed off decaying plant material and coconut husk is perfect nutrition for vanilla vines.

The hard coconut shell is then removed and put to the side and this is the subject of this promotion which we will come back to.

The water inside the coconut is collected and turned into coconut vinegar or added to the pig feed: the white flesh of the coconut is ground and pressed to acquire the coconut milk, the flesh (post press) goes into pig porridge. The coconut cream is fermented and we then extract the virgin coconut oil and filter it ready for export. We are now left with residual coconut protein that is added to the pig porridge or fed into a maggot farm. 

The maggots are 63% protein and are almost the perfect food for chickens and ducks, they just love a good feed on coconut fed maggots.

The chickens, ducks and pigs are mostly free ranging over 8 acres. They have a very natural life however are eventually cured in Tongan sea salt and smoked with coconut husk to create tasty hams and small goods.

From time to time some of the pigs go to a special pig resort where we collect their poop for a biogas plant that will produce methane gas to run the burners that heat the coconut oil where we make our taro and cassava chips. The taro and cassava peelings are added to the pig porridge.

The waste liquid from the bio gas digester is piped to the vegetable garden and used as liquid organic fertilizer. Surplus vegetables from the garden are fed to the chickens, ducks and pigs.

In the future, waste from the slaughter of the pigs, ducks and chickens will be fed into a mud crab farm. The mud crabs will be sold locally on the condition that the shells are returned so they may be ground up and added to the chicken and duck feed as a calcium supplement for egg shell production.

Feathers from the chickens and ducks will be ground up and added to the pig feed as a further protein supplement.

At this point we have achieved ZERO waste except for the coconut shells that have been put to the side. The shells will be turned into electricity using the biomass generator.

Our Products, the final result

The process detailed will deliver the following products that all directly or indirectly originate from a coconut;

·  Virgin coconut oil for export

·  Cured vanilla beans for export

·  Coconut shell powered electricity generation

·  Coconut cream and cheese

·  Coconut cakes

·  Coconut vinegar

·  Coconut oil soap infused with vanilla

·  Coconut mulch for the vanilla vines

·  Coconut based pig food

·  Coconut based maggot food for the chickens and ducks

·  Bio gas from the piggery and hen house

·  Pig and chicken poop fertiliser for the garden

·  Garden vegetables

·  Smoked ham, chicken and duck

·  Mud crabs

What We Need & What You Get

To fulfill our objective of ZERO waste and to provide added competitiveness we need to effectively utilise the 13.8 ton of coconut shells that have been put to the side each month.

The options could include turning the shells into charcoal and then into activated carbon for export however we decided that turning them into electricity would be more beneficial in our island community.

Electricity is expensive in Tonga due to the fact that it is made by large generators running off imported diesel; this is neither sustainable nor desirable.

By employing a gasifier it is possible to convert the shells into syngass which in turn runs an engine that drives a generator that can produce electricity. This is nothing new and has been around since the 1930’s. The gasifier will produce sufficient electricity to operate the VCO factory and the Vanilla Curing Facility. Surplus electricity will be fed onto the grid to further reduce the need for imported diesel.

The gasifier we wish to install is called a Power Pallet. It is produced in the USA by All Power Labs (http://www.gekgasifier.com). This unit in operational in many different countries around the world and is a perfect fit for small Pacific Islands.

The cost to establish an operational 20 kW gasifier in Vava’u is:

GasifierUSD$29,995

Grid tie equipment USD $9,990

Import Duties USD $6,000

Freight USD $2,200

Housing structure  USD $1,800

Contingency 10%

Total USD $54,983.50

To date we have invested almost USD $200,000 into this project and whilst we are selling virgin coconut oil and vanilla beans, production is not at a level where they can accumulate sufficient capital to complete our dream of a Zero Waste operation.

Expensive electricity and freight is keeping our operational costs high making our products more expensive against low cost producing countries like Indonesia and Phillippines with cheap labour, electricity and shipping. The gasifier will remove the energy cost and perhaps create a new income source thus leveling the playing field.

We are passionate about this project, its success will impact on the livelihood of over 300 Tongan subsistence farmers of which many live below the poverty line. We have come this far and need a little help to finish the project.

We are happy to receive any amount of contribution, and are happy to provide you with a few perks in recognition of your generous contribution and support.

The Impact

The Impact

The Taste of Tonga project is to educating people about developing sustainable businesses that have a minimal impact on the environment and at the same time maximise the utilisation of available renewable resources, as well as waste resources.

By establishing this centre we aim to transform the lives of many poverty stricken families by helping them to capitalise on the lost assets within their communities.

Once completed we will open our doors to anyone interested in learning the process. We will provide them with detailed instructions on how to achieve all or individual components of the project. We want Taste of Tonga to become a centre of learning, a place where people can see and understand the concept of sustainable business and waste utilisation.

Pacific Aid Australia will also publish the names of all donors on a dedicated webpage - with donor permission of course. And we will film the delivery, installation and operation of the Biomass Generator and post it on You Tube, our website, and other social media channels for all supporters to see the fruits of their support.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, that doesn't mean you can’t help. You can help by:

  • Asking your friends, your company, people you know how are passionate about environmental issues, islands, sustainable development etc to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Please use all the Indiegogo share tools on the social media sites you use
  • Please also spread the word about Pacific Aid Australia's supporting Islands to become sustainable. If an Island can become sustainable, so can the world!
  • Visit us at www.pacificaidaustralia.org
  • Follow the Campaign, Friend Us and Like Us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/Pacific.Aid.Australia
  • Follow us on Twitter: @pacific_aid_aus
  • Follow the Sustainable Tonga Campaign on Pinterest www.pinterest.com/pacificaidaus/
  • Watch our work in the Pacific on You Tube at: www.youtube.com/user/TheIHFA

AND THANK-YOU TO EVERYONE!

about developing sustainable businesses that have a minimal impact on the
environment and at the same time maximise the utilisation of available renewable resources, as well as waste resources.
By establishing this centre we aim to transform the
lives of many poverty stricken families by helping them to capitalise on the
lost assets within their communities.
Once completed we will open our doors to anyone
interested in learning the process. We will provide them with detailed
instructions on how to achieve all or individual components of the project. We
want Taste of Tonga to become a centre of learning, a place where people can
see and understand the concept of sustainable business and waste utilisation.Pacific Aid Australia will also publish the names of all donors on a dedicated webpage - with donor permission of course. And we will film the delivery, installation and operation of the Biomass Generator and post it on You Tube, our website, and other social media channels for all supporters to see the fruits of their support.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t contribute, that doesn't mean you can’t help. You can help by:
Asking your friends, your company, people you know how are passionate about environmental issues, islands, sustainable development etc to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Please use all the Indiegogo share tools on the social media sites you use
Please also spread the word about Pacific Aid Australia's supporting Islands to become sustainable. If an Island can become sustainable, so can the world!
Visit us at www.pacificaidaustralia.org

Follow the Campaign, Friend Us and Like Us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/Pacific.Aid.Australia

Follow us on Twitter: @pacific_aid_aus
Follow the Sustainable Tonga Campaign on Pinterest www.pinterest.com/pacificaidaus/

Watch our work in the Pacific on You Tube at: www.youtube.com/user/TheIHFA

AND THANK-YOU TO EVERYONE!

story:
Rediscovering the Country

We have a big, bold vision for Australia’s rural landscapes – one with less erosion, more beauty, plenty of native grass, trees and wildlife AND a way for people to earn an ‘environmentally friendly’ income. 

Help us spread that vision by supporting our film 'Rediscovering the Country'. 

The Ballarat Region Treegrowers (BRT) encourages a culture of custodianship and repair towards Australia’s land.  It is making this film to promote land restoration through reforestation, and in particular creation of biologically rich plantations (biorich plantations) that repair the land, clean water, create wildlife habitat and also provide an income for their owners, such as through wood production.  

The BRT wants this film to strengthen community support for the improved management of rural lands by increasing awareness within rural and urban communities of the way revegetation can help solve land management problems and contribute to rural communities.

The film is aimed at people interested in landscape rehabilitation through revegetation, and who want to learn more about how such projects can be made successful and deliver desired environmental and social benefits.These people may be farmers or city dwellers who rely on the benefits of rural landscapes for food, recreation and other natural resources.

We will examine several major community-led revegetation projects in southern Australia to see how they are working to improve the land, wildlife habitat and local human communities. These projects have locally developed objectives, such as returning rare animal species, helping local farmers, linking remnant vegetation, repairing degraded land, and they all were generated out of action by concerned and committed community groups or individuals. 

The film will also show how community activism in Sri Lanka modified traditional village gardens to create Analogue Forests that mimic the original forest structure to produce food, natural resources and an economic income for local people. 

The ‘Analogue Forest’ concept overlaps with our ‘Biorich Plantations’, so we will show how Analog Forestry has been successful in Sri Lanka.  We are being assisted by Sri Lanka’s Neosynthesis Research Centre, which helps rural communities establish analog forests/regenerative agriculture.  You can learn more about the centre's work by clicking here, here and here.

A few years ago, the BRT published ‘Recreating the Country’, a book explaining how to establish and manage biorich plantations that can produce wood for our use as well as be a rich habitat for wildlife.  Then we set up our own biorich plantation near Ballarat to show how it can be done.  Now, to spread the word further, we are again working with She Oaks Films, who made the ‘Recreating the Country’ video about our biorich plantation.  

We started filming earlier this year in Victoria’s Otway Ranges, and recently filmed Regenerative Agriculture/Analog Forestry sites in Sri Lanka.  This (Australian) spring, we will film reforestation projects in western and central Victoria as well as southern New South Wales. She Oaks Films will compile footage and prepare the music score over summer.  We plan to have a first cut in the early part of next year and release the film at a major launch during our Autumn. 

This is a community service project.  We aren’t out to make a profit.  The donations we receive will go to paying our film maker and covering the cost of making and launching the film.  The final film will be available as a creative commons project from the biorich plantation website. 

Look at our promo and other films to see the high standards that we and She Oaks Films aim to meet. 

We have over half our proposed budget, but are seeking another $10-15,000 to expand the length of film and increase its quality.  We have 60 days to raise this money, and with your help, we can make our vision a reality.

More about the BRT

The Ballarat Region Treegrowers is the local branch of Australian Forest Growers.  The BRT was formed in 1998 by a small group of farm forestry enthusiasts, and has since been promoting the benefits of integrating trees into our rural landscape for commercial and environmental benefits to landowners and the broader community.

We organised and convened the 2004 biennial conference of the Australian Forest Growers in Ballarat – ‘Integrating Forestry into Farms, Communities and Catchments’ with the objective of showing that trees were not incompatible with traditional agriculture, and could bring substantial financial, lifestyle and environmental rewards through repairing degraded land, growing timber, protecting stock and crops, and creating wildlife habitat.  We then followed up this very successful endeavour with a program of seminars and workshops under the same general theme.  This led to ‘Recreating the Country’ and our ‘Biorich Plantation’.

Our perks

Remember, our donation amounts are US dollars. So please donate now, while the exchange rate is good.

Recreating the Country Click to go to the publisher's website

Gariwerd Click to go to publisher's website



One of 3 framed 'Australia' prints:

"Ballaarat" by J.C. Armytage and J Saddler (This 'perk' now taken - only 2 prints left)

"Daylesford, Victoria" by J. Carr and J.C. Armytage

"Mount Arapiles" by N. Chevalier and S Bradshaw, 1872

story:
Help make a historic green map for the Royal Borough of Greenwich, and become a named supporter!

 

We’re creating a bold, beautiful London National Park City* Greenwich map featuring all the wonderful open and green spaces in the borough. Through the map we aim to connect people to nature and to improve awareness of the wealth of open and green spaces in South East London—from Cutty Sark to Thamesmead to Beckenham Place Park. The map draws attention to new, fun and creative ways to explore London, such as the Green Chain Walk or the Woolwich Ferry across the Thames. Packed with historic walks, cycle trails, and fun facts about Greenwich’s amazing outdoors, the Greenwich map will be a unique tool for residents and visitors to use to discover a historic part of London in a different way.

To fund the creation of the Greenwich map, we are offering advanced copies and beautiful original, limited edition prints of London. Greenwich will be the first borough-scale National Park City map and will connect locals and visitors to green opportunities for living, working and playing in Greenwich.

Like the London National Park City map that we created in 2017 to support London becoming the world’s first National Park City, the Greenwich map will be a large-format, folded paper map – printed by Dennis Maps. The borough-level map will be much more detailed, to highlight the richness of the area and connect residents and visitors to all that Greenwich and its surrounds have to offer. The map will be a beautiful, unique and custom-drawn map, highlighting places to explore such as parks, green roofs, the canals, places to work, relax and sport outdoors, city farms for children and much more! The reverse side of the map will be used to provide more information and key facts about Greenwich and London National Park City.

Our goal is to distribute well over 5,000 London National Park City* Greenwich maps, with maps in every school, recreation centre, doctor’s surgery and library in the borough, to reach as many people as possible!

The Greenwich map will launch in July to coincide with the London National Park City festival—20th-28th July.

We’re seeking £1,000 in crowdfunding to help match generous support from Berkeley Homes East Thames. Your support will allow us to print the map on the best map printing press in the United Kingdom. 

This map will be our first collaboration with Applied Wayfinding, a global leader in map design.

 

Rewards

You can buy a copy of the London National Park City* Greenwich map in advance, or even buy an extra copy for a friend! We will post them to you in July 2019. If you really want something special, you can buy one of our limited edition screen-prints, or giclee prints. You will receive a unique product for your home or office, and we will credit your name on the map as a super generous crowdfunder. It will support the non-profit campaign to give away more Greenwich maps.

If you are a community organisation or business and would like to discuss a more substantial contribution, please get in touch. We can make you a unique screen-print in a bespoke colour of your choice with your logo and/or name printed on it, and your organisation will become a partner!

FREE POSTAGE on all perks within the UK. Individual charges for EU and Rest of World, applied at checkout.

 

Basic

£7

1 X London National Park City* Greenwich map

Help us meet some production and print costs and have map posted to you for free before anyone else gets theirs. 

PLUS - Named on the back as a supporter.

 

Double

£10

2 X Greenwich maps

Why not also buy an extra copy for a friend or colleague? When you see the final map, you will want to share it with a friend, or possibly want to attach the reverse side on a wall alongside the frontside of the map.

PLUS - Named on the back as a supporter.

 

London Explorer

£10

1 X Greenwich map + 1 X London National Park City map

Collect the first two National Park City maps. In the future possibly, every London Borough will have one. Be inspired to explore the extent of London’s great outdoors beyond Greenwich!

PLUS - Named on the back as a supporter.

 

Poster Version

£33

A flat, poster version of the Greenwich map

Printed on the same press as Ordnance Survey maps, but with special Pantone spot inks. The large-format, wall ready print measures 952mm x 1270mm and won’t have any creases like the folded ones.

PLUS - Named on the back as a supporter.

Don’t forget to order a folded perk too if you’d like one to get out and about with you!

 

Bundle of Ten

£40

Maps for everyone! Snag a bargain of 10 Greenwich maps to hand out to all your friends

PLUS - Named on the back as a supporter.

 

A2 Giclee “London’s Great Outdoors” Print

£65

1 X A2 print

2 X Greenwich maps

A brightly coloured fine art print of the original proposal map drawn by Charlie Peel. This has been re-worked and re-coloured for giclee printing with vivid colours and excellent print quality on Xativa matt coated paper. Printed locally in London by the amazing Printer of Dreams.

PLUS - we will send you two copies of the folded Greenwich map.

PLUS - Named on the back as a Special Supporter.

 

“Buildings & Water” Copper Print

£250

1 X Copper handmade screen print of London

10 X Greenwich maps 

Our favourite reward: a limited-edition handmade print of 200 with London's waterways in copper pigment - impossible to achieve from any ordinary printer. Hand printed on oversized, archival A0 paper, unframed and posted securely in a roll tube. 

PLUS - we will send you 10 copies of the folded Greenwich map.

PLUS - Named on the back as a special supporter.

 

Greenwich Community Group Supporter (80 maps)

£250

For local not-for-profit, community interest and charity organisations

80 X Greenwich maps to distribute for free (8 X Bundle of Ten)

1 X Logo, strapline and URL on the back of the map

Have your logo featured on the back of the London National Park City* Greenwich map, be listed as Community Supporter.

 

CSR Business Supporter

£1,000

For businesses

240 X maps for your employees and to give away free.

1 X Logo, strapline and URL on the back of the map

Have your logo featured on the back of the London National Park City* Greenwich map, be listed as a Business Supporter. Your strapline has to be something you (as a business) pledge to contribute to London National Park City.

 

Local Authority

£1,000

For Royal Borough of Greenwich only

480 X maps.

1 X front cover "Partnership Logo"

Get a front cover Partnership logo and show your support. You will fund copies for all employees and the copies sent to every school, health practice and hospital waiting room in the Borough. Imagine that!

 

About the London National Park City

nationalparkcity.london

Launching in July 2019, the London National Park City is a place, a vision and a movement to improve life in London. We’re doing this by enjoying being outdoor more and helping to make our city greener, healthier and wilder.

 

About Urban Good

urbangood.org

Urban Good CIC is a social enterprise working to improve the urban environment. We make maps to empower citizens to get more from their cities. We are urban sociologists and designers and when we are not colouring in, we provide advice, research and document production for architects, planners, developers, local authorities and community projects to help inform decision making, and ultimately make material improvements to cities.

 

About Berkeley East Thames

berkeleygroup.co.uk

To make the project possible, the design and research has has generously been funded by the team at Berkeley who are creating new parks and neighbourhoods at Woolwich Arsenal and Kidbrooke Village. Designed for life.
