story:
My name is John Beaudry. I am raising money to create a film that will give voice to the Achuar people of Ecuador. The Achuar are a group of indigenous peoples in the Amazon, with a rich, ancient culture. They are working to preserve their environment and community.Their territory encompasses 5 million acres of pristine tropical rainforest. Until the 1970’s, they lived untouched by the modern world. 

"This is not just about one battle in one corner of the Amazon. This is about drawing a line in the sand for indigenous people and rainforests everywhere. It's about ensuring that indigenous people can fulfill the role they see for themselves as protectors of the natural world in partnership with all of us."
- Bill Twist, CEO of The Pachamama Alliance, partner organization of Fundación Pachamama in the US.

Five Million Acres of Rainforest are at Risk for New Oil Development in 2012.

These five million acres of pristine rainforest are now at critical risk. This land is home to six different indigenous nations who have not been informed nor given their consent. The land in question is sandwiched between two of the largest ecological and human rights disasters in recent history.

Just 100 miles away, in Ecuador’s northern Amazon basin, oil exploitation conducted by Chevron/Texaco and Ecuador’s state-owned oil company devastated the forest ecology and the indigenous societies of the rainforest.

Though their home may seem remote, the forests in which they have lived for thousands of years are the lungs of our planet. And we cannot live without them. The Achuar people are taking a stand for the natural world on the behalf of all of us to save the lives of all people who rely on the lungs of the world.

This is a call for our time.

With the support of a global community, the Achuar have successfully defended their land for 15 years—in spite of intense pressure from an array of international oil companies.

Listen to the story here.

http://vimeo.com/33753861

About Me

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Designing-the-Bungalow-Garden/124956310926240?ref=hl

I believe in a world where everyone’s needs are met.

I believe that ancient ways of life can intersect with the techno-industrial world in a way that will benefit Everyone. That’s a capitol E for Everyone, meaning all people.

I believe that you and I, as individuals, are greater than we can ever imagine.

I am a horticulturist, garden designer, landscape contractor, author, and global activist who loves life, nature, his husband, and his dog. And I love people.

I am writing a book on garden design called Designing the Bungalow Garden: How to Create Gardens and Lives Rooted in Spirit.10% of the proceeds from the book go to the Pachamama Alliance. The book is based on the Arts and Crafts Movement that was, in part, a rebellion in response to the industrial revolution. Early founders of the movement advocated for a better life for factory workers. Lured by the promise of steady work and pay, the industrial revolution pulled individuals away from their agrarian lives. Their new lives in factories lacked, among many other things, a relationship with nature—a life in harmony with the rhythms of nature. It is in the rhythms of the natural world, where we find the connection to our own true nature.

One hundred and Fifty years after the industrial revolution we are still seeking a better life. We are still facing drastic change and discontent. The long hours of the factories may be over, but the cubicle has taken the its place, along with our time. Like the founders of the Arts and Crafts Movement, I advocate on the behalf of the indigenous peoples of the earth—for all of us. I advocate that their relationship to the natural world be upheld, and in so doing, that they might help all of us find our own relationship with nature and thereby, shift our consciousness to create a new shared dream for our human family.

I trust in the Alliance that is the Pachamama Alliance. I trust that their partnership with the indigenous people of the Amazon Rainforest will help to empower indigenous people of the Amazon rainforest to preserve their lands and culture and, using insights gained from that work, educate and inspire individuals everywhere to bring forth a thriving, just and sustainable world.

Please join me in supporting this project. Our very survival counts on your support.  

WHAT’S SO RIGHT NOW

The Achuar have partnered with their northern allies to create The Pachamama Alliance. Their ancestral lands—nearly 5 million acres in all—straddle the modern borders of Ecuador and Peru, a remote area that has allowed them to preserve their way of life with little outside influence or colonization. The Achuar people are taking a stand for the natural world on the behalf of all of us. This is a call for our time.

The Achuar’s land may seem like the middle of nowhere, yet it is the heart of everywhere.

Rainforests are essential to our survival. They are the Lungs of our Planet. Rainforests are in service to the planet, continuously recycling carbon dioxide into oxygen.

More than half of the world's estimated 10 million species of plants, animals and insects live in the tropical rainforests. One-fifth of the world's fresh water is in the Amazon Basin. 25 percent of modern pharmaceuticals are derived from rainforest ingredients, yet less than 1 percent of these trees and plants have been tested by scientists. The U.S. National Cancer Institute has identified 3000 plants that are active against cancer cells. 70 percent of these plants are found in the rainforest. 25 percent of the active ingredients in today's cancer-fighting drugs come from organisms found only in the rainforest.

At least 80 percent of the developed world's diet originated in the tropical rainforest. Rainforests offer over 3000 varieties of fruits. Of these, only 200 are now in use in the Western World. By comparison, the Indians of the rainforest use over 2,000 of these fruits.

THE FORSEEABLE FUTURE

We are losing Earth's greatest biological treasures and much of this loss is due to human intervention. Rainforests once covered 14 percent of the earth's land surface, now they cover a mere 6 percent. Half of our ancient forests are gone forever.

Experts estimate that without systematic change, the last remaining rainforests will be consumed in less than 40 years. The potential for new medicines to cure diseases, foods that could end starvation, and oxygen for our planet will all be lost forever.

YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE

Technology has connected us—all of us—like never before on earth. We are meeting each other globally, and in this meeting, we have a clash of worldviews. The Achuar people are transforming this clash of worldviews into a merger so that the technological genius of the modern world proceeds in recognition of the interconnected nature of all things. They are working to protect their ancient way of life and to preserve the natural world for all of humanity. We may find the keys to resolving the problems of our immediate future by listening to the voices of our ancient past.

The Pachamama Alliance was born out of an invitation from the Achuar people to work in partnership with them to preserve their land and culture while bringing forth a new worldview that honors and sustains life.

The Achuar people want to “change the dream of the North”. They want us to work within our own modern culture, shifting it from wasteful consumerism to a less destructive, more sustainable paradigm.

This film will articulate the Achuar’s vision of transforming how people see and relate to the world and the possibilities they see for our future.

Learn more about the Origin Story of the Achuar people and the Pachamama Alliance

The Pachamama Alliance was born out of an invitation from the Achuar people to work in partnership with them to preserve their land and culture while bringing forth a new worldview that honors and sustains life. Read more: http://www.pachamama.org/about/origin-story

MAKING THE FILM

The film will be created by a team that has worked with the Pachamama Alliance and the Achuar people for many years. The video below is an example of their work. The new film will highlight the urgent nature of the current situation.

http://vimeo.com/17068946

Risks and Challenges

I am not a filmmaker, but the Pachamama Alliance has a professional team that creates their films. As you can see from their website, they do a very nice job. Some of the challenges they face in creating this film include time and travel to the Ecuadorian Amazon for film footage.

Time is of the essence as international oil interests clamber for control of the Achuar’s homeland. All of the filming equipment needs to be flown into remote areas on small planes. This equipment is heavy and the cost of freight on these small planes is great. Filming in the Amazon has the obvious challenges: no electricity, rain, mud, but also the challenge of capturing the essence of the Achuar culture in a way that translates to our culture.

Truth be told, without this funding, this film may never be made. The idea for this film evolved out of my own desire to make a real difference in the world. I hope that you will join me in support.
story_txt:
My name is John Beaudry. I am raising money to create a film that will give voice to the Achuar people of Ecuador. The Achuar are a group of indigenous peoples in the Amazon, with a rich, ancient culture. They are working to preserve their environment and community.Their territory encompasses 5 million acres of pristine tropical rainforest. Until the 1970’s, they lived untouched by the modern world. 
"This is not just about one battle in one corner of the Amazon. This is about drawing a line in the sand for indigenous people and rainforests everywhere. It's about ensuring that indigenous people can fulfill the role they see for themselves as protectors of the natural world in partnership with all of us."- Bill Twist, CEO of The Pachamama Alliance, partner organization of Fundación Pachamama in the US.

Five Million Acres of Rainforest are at Risk for New Oil Development in 2012.
These five million acres of pristine rainforest are now at critical risk. This land is home to six different indigenous nations who have not been informed nor given their consent. The land in question is sandwiched between two of the largest ecological and human rights disasters in recent history.
Just 100 miles away, in Ecuador’s northern Amazon basin, oil exploitation conducted by Chevron/Texaco and Ecuador’s state-owned oil company devastated the forest ecology and the indigenous societies of the rainforest.
Though their home may seem remote, the forests in which they have lived for thousands of years are the lungs of our planet. And we cannot live without them. The Achuar people are taking a stand for the natural world on the behalf of all of us to save the lives of all people who rely on the lungs of the world.
This is a call for our time.
With the support of a global community, the Achuar have successfully defended their land for 15 years—in spite of intense pressure from an array of international oil companies.
Listen to the story here.
http://vimeo.com/33753861
About Me
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Designing-the-Bungalow-Garden/124956310926240?ref=hl
I believe in a world where everyone’s needs are met.
I believe that ancient ways of life can intersect with the techno-industrial world in a way that will benefit Everyone. That’s a capitol E for Everyone, meaning all people.
I believe that you and I, as individuals, are greater than we can ever imagine.
I am a horticulturist, garden designer, landscape contractor, author, and global activist who loves life, nature, his husband, and his dog. And I love people.
I am writing a book on garden design called Designing the Bungalow Garden: How to Create Gardens and Lives Rooted in Spirit.10% of the proceeds from the book go to the Pachamama Alliance. The book is based on the Arts and Crafts Movement that was, in part, a rebellion in response to the industrial revolution. Early founders of the movement advocated for a better life for factory workers. Lured by the promise of steady work and pay, the industrial revolution pulled individuals away from their agrarian lives. Their new lives in factories lacked, among many other things, a relationship with nature—a life in harmony with the rhythms of nature. It is in the rhythms of the natural world, where we find the connection to our own true nature.
One hundred and Fifty years after the industrial revolution we are still seeking a better life. We are still facing drastic change and discontent. The long hours of the factories may be over, but the cubicle has taken the its place, along with our time. Like the founders of the Arts and Crafts Movement, I advocate on the behalf of the indigenous peoples of the earth—for all of us. I advocate that their relationship to the natural world be upheld, and in so doing, that they might help all of us find our own relationship with nature and thereby, shift our consciousness to create a new shared dream for our human family.
I trust in the Alliance that is the Pachamama Alliance. I trust that their partnership with the indigenous people of the Amazon Rainforest will help to empower indigenous people of the Amazon rainforest to preserve their lands and culture and, using insights gained from that work, educate and inspire individuals everywhere to bring forth a thriving, just and sustainable world.
Please join me in supporting this project. Our very survival counts on your support.  
WHAT’S SO RIGHT NOW
The Achuar have partnered with their northern allies to create The Pachamama Alliance. Their ancestral lands—nearly 5 million acres in all—straddle the modern borders of Ecuador and Peru, a remote area that has allowed them to preserve their way of life with little outside influence or colonization. The Achuar people are taking a stand for the natural world on the behalf of all of us. This is a call for our time.
The Achuar’s land may seem like the middle of nowhere, yet it is the heart of everywhere.
Rainforests are essential to our survival. They are the Lungs of our Planet. Rainforests are in service to the planet, continuously recycling carbon dioxide into oxygen.
More than half of the world's estimated 10 million species of plants, animals and insects live in the tropical rainforests. One-fifth of the world's fresh water is in the Amazon Basin. 25 percent of modern pharmaceuticals are derived from rainforest ingredients, yet less than 1 percent of these trees and plants have been tested by scientists. The U.S. National Cancer Institute has identified 3000 plants that are active against cancer cells. 70 percent of these plants are found in the rainforest. 25 percent of the active ingredients in today's cancer-fighting drugs come from organisms found only in the rainforest.
At least 80 percent of the developed world's diet originated in the tropical rainforest. Rainforests offer over 3000 varieties of fruits. Of these, only 200 are now in use in the Western World. By comparison, the Indians of the rainforest use over 2,000 of these fruits.
THE FORSEEABLE FUTURE
We are losing Earth's greatest biological treasures and much of this loss is due to human intervention. Rainforests once covered 14 percent of the earth's land surface, now they cover a mere 6 percent. Half of our ancient forests are gone forever.
Experts estimate that without systematic change, the last remaining rainforests will be consumed in less than 40 years. The potential for new medicines to cure diseases, foods that could end starvation, and oxygen for our planet will all be lost forever.
YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE
Technology has connected us—all of us—like never before on earth. We are meeting each other globally, and in this meeting, we have a clash of worldviews. The Achuar people are transforming this clash of worldviews into a merger so that the technological genius of the modern world proceeds in recognition of the interconnected nature of all things. They are working to protect their ancient way of life and to preserve the natural world for all of humanity. We may find the keys to resolving the problems of our immediate future by listening to the voices of our ancient past.
The Pachamama Alliance was born out of an invitation from the Achuar people to work in partnership with them to preserve their land and culture while bringing forth a new worldview that honors and sustains life.
The Achuar people want to “change the dream of the North”. They want us to work within our own modern culture, shifting it from wasteful consumerism to a less destructive, more sustainable paradigm.
This film will articulate the Achuar’s vision of transforming how people see and relate to the world and the possibilities they see for our future.
Learn more about the Origin Story of the Achuar people and the Pachamama Alliance
The Pachamama Alliance was born out of an invitation from the Achuar people to work in partnership with them to preserve their land and culture while bringing forth a new worldview that honors and sustains life. Read more: http://www.pachamama.org/about/origin-story
MAKING THE FILM
The film will be created by a team that has worked with the Pachamama Alliance and the Achuar people for many years. The video below is an example of their work. The new film will highlight the urgent nature of the current situation.
http://vimeo.com/17068946
Risks and Challenges
I am not a filmmaker, but the Pachamama Alliance has a professional team that creates their films. As you can see from their website, they do a very nice job. Some of the challenges they face in creating this film include time and travel to the Ecuadorian Amazon for film footage.
Time is of the essence as international oil interests clamber for control of the Achuar’s homeland. All of the filming equipment needs to be flown into remote areas on small planes. This equipment is heavy and the cost of freight on these small planes is great. Filming in the Amazon has the obvious challenges: no electricity, rain, mud, but also the challenge of capturing the essence of the Achuar culture in a way that translates to our culture.
Truth be told, without this funding, this film may never be made. The idea for this film evolved out of my own desire to make a real difference in the world. I hope that you will join me in support.

story:
The Sangre de Cristo Arts & Culture Concert Series is our first effort to give Santa Fe  a taste of things to come.  The long term vision of SCAC is to launch an arts center that will be a safe gathering place to connect, learn and express creativity.  We have been overjoyed as we sought a venue for our weekly  concerts to have the popular "Santa Fe Baking Company and Cafe" open up to us for our summer events. 

The foundation of SCAC is to live out a Biblical worldview by being a caring community that presents beauty and truth to our city.  The longterm vision will be to have our own facility that will house an art gallery, coffee shop, performance space, learning opportunities and a variety of helps projects.  SCAC's concert series gives opportunity for artists to bless others with their talents while offering a fun and wholesome atmosphere to those who attend.  As we are in the middle of our concert series as we launch this fundraising campaign, we have already observed how those attending are drinking in the welcoming atmosphere as they enjoy the various musicians as they learn more about people though the cultural celebrations. 

There is no charge to attend one of our concerts.  We accept donations,  but those have not met all of our expenses of renting  a local restaurant for our programs and sharing financially with our artists.

We are praying that people will not only contribute to help us finish off this summer series, but will want to be part of our team of volunteers who share the vision of having an art center where we can all gather to talk, create, participate in worthwhile projects  and enjoy the beauty of art and culture.   We believe the fruit of this will be a since of friendship, community, emotional healing, belonging.  In short... a great knowledge of how much God loves them. 

The financial goal of $2000 will help us meet all our expenses to get through the summer and may even provide some start up funds for our next events. 

For those who can embrace this vision but cannot give financially right now, we invite you to serve as a volunteer, come enjoy our concerts, share about SCAC with others and pray for us.

story:
Introducing... our team and our project 

We are a team of twenty university students hailing from Singapore. Despite living in an intensely urban environment, all of us are passionate about helping the environment in some way, whether it is switching off the lights when we leave the room or doggedly using metal over plastic straws. We got together to take this passion one step further, into the wild of Aek Godang, North Sumatra. 

Sumatra boasts a distinct and diverse ecology found nowhere else in the world. Like any other ecology, it is fragile and needs to be protected. This is where we - and you - come in. Your help will be invaluable in helping us achieve our goals of planting 20,000 saplings (and more if we can manage) and improving the standard of care afforded to rescued gibbons currently undergoing rehabilitation. 

 

So you may ask, what about sustainability? 

Aek Godang in Northern Sumatra is a vast area of more than 600 hectares. Our team will help to provide essential manpower and resources such as seeds in the reforestation project. In terms of sustainability, one of the purposes of building improved gibbon enclosures is to leave behind construction blueprints as well as set up infrastructure such as resource supply lines. These blueprints and resource infrastructure will be accessible to local wildlife sanctuaries that might not necessarily have access to appropriate information and resources, allowing this project to be ultimately, locally sustained. 

Given the fact that our team will only be able to work on the project in May, monitoring the progress of our efforts beyond our stay is definitely a pertinent issue. Therefore, we will depend on the locals to update us as well as carry out up-keep works, to ensure the saplings successfully develop into trees and the new enclosures built are well-maintained.  On another note, as we send a team of students overseas annually to participate in community involvement projects, we are ourselves a resource that can be tapped into to ensure that this project is more than a one-off. 

 

What We Need 

We are hoping to raise at least 1000 dollars. All proceeds will go towards covering project material costs such as the purchase of seeds, digging equipment and cement for the gibbon enclosure. It will also help members to offset transportation costs, as Aek Godang is in a remote and inaccessible location about 10 hours drive away from Kuala Namo International Airport (Medan City) where we will be landing. Our project costs total more than 20,000 dollars, 70% of which is borne by the members themselves. Therefore, we are deeply grateful for any small donation you make. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by donating, or by spreading the word to family and friends - let them know about our project, and how they can help! Every effort we put into raising awareness of, and taking concrete steps to protect the fragile ecosystems that are home to some of the most vulnerable beings on the planet counts. We hope you can provide us with the support we need, financial or otherwise, to give back to the planet we call home.

story:
Eating our forests

Do you enjoy eating gourmet mushrooms like shiitake or oyster varieties? Have you ever been curious as to how those mushrooms are grown? The answer is: on wood logged from forests - often illegally.

The role of mushrooms in nature - and fungi in general - is to break down biomass fibre, metabolizing it into energy. Industrial mushroom growers therefore innoculate logs or sawdust with mushroom spores and their derivatives. Unfortunately it takes four tons of wood on average to produce just one ton of mushroom. Can you imagine how many trees are cut down? How many acres of forest are disappearing every year to support 10 millon tonnes of mushroom production globally each year? This is particularly the case in Asia where more than 60% of the world's mushrooms are produced and consumed. In East Asia citizens are known to consume an average of 17kgs of mushroom per annum. 



Our story

Since he was a young boy, our founder Terence Chia, loved eating all varieties of mushrooms - he ate them at least 5 times a week! However when he saw the massive deforestation caused by the agricultural cultivation of mushrooms he was devastated: deforestation leads to the release of greenhouse gases, reduces biodiversity, increases soil erosion and disrupts water cycles. It is one of the main contributors of climate change. 

After researching the industry, Terence and his team decided something had to be done to change these unsustainable practices, founding Blue Impact with the aim of putting an end to the logging of forests in Asia and around the world. Blue Impact's solution: growing high quality mushrooms at industrial scales using only feedstocks from agricultural waste, thereby upcycling biomass and preventing it from entering landfills. 

There are billions of tons of agricultural waste generated around the world each year, the majority is disposed of and sent to landfill where it decomposes anaerobically or is simply burned, either way releasing huge amounts of carbon emissions into the atmosphere.


Turning waste into food

After spending four years in R&D, carrying out countless experiments, and much trial and error, Blue Impact has finally proven the feasibility of the idea. Technical issues have been solved, Standard Operating Principles have been developed, and our crop yields are competitive with the industry average. 

This new technology is ready to replace the use of sawdust and logs completely to cultivate certain species of mushrooms, thus reducing the pressure on forests, carbon emissions, while providing a sustainable (and delicious!) source of protein. 



How can you help?

Now we need your help to implement these solutions at scale - initially ten times our current operation, and eventually big enough to significantly influence and finally force a change in the industry in Asia and around the world! 

With your support for this campaign we hope our delicious mushrooms will reach you and your community soon!



The Impact

For every ton of mushrooms we produce:

- 4 tons of trees remain in the forests.

- 4 tons of agricultural byproduct is recycled (rather than landfilled or burned).

- 2 tons of carbon emissions are avoided as trees are not logged and the vegetative root of the mushroom sequesters carbon as it grows.

Currently, we are producing more than 100kg of mushrooms a day, which translates to 400kg of trees that are saved each day because of our operation, while 200kg of carbon emission are avoided a day.

The success of this project, can help tens of millions of trees and forests around the world every year. A financial contribution from you will make this a reality sooner, and in the near future, you will be able to protect forests just by purchasing our mushrooms! How great would that be? 


Thank you for your support, let's do this together!

story:
20 Second Story:

Water is a fundamental necessity for all living things, and yet it passes through our lives via faucets, sprinklers, and drains without us ever thinking about the precariousness of this precious resource. We decided to create a political action committee (SuperPAC) in order to help save our most prized resource from misuse and contamination and preserve its integrity for future generations. We will raise money for our PAC and donate the money to various water political interest groups that align with our mission statement.  

2013 was one of the driest year recorded in the state of California. Governor Brown declared state of drought emergency. The drought has caused and increased fire threat that has prompted the fire departments to begin their wildfire season earlier than usual. Further, 1/3 of US Agriculture is grown is California and the limited water places huge economic concerns on a $44 Billion Dollar industry.  

Mission Statement: 

To protect and conserve California’s precious water resources through political activism, with the goal of representing public interest and furthering sustainable progress.

                       Where is the money going?

We will be donating the money to various water interests groups and 501(c)s such as Clean Water Action, Don't Frack California, Save the Bay, Food and Water Watch. 

Meet Us: 

Two high school seniors from the Bay Area who want to make environmental and political impacts as their Senior Project.

Co-Treasuers Andrew and Brandon at Iguazu Falls in Argentina.

story:
I was selected as an eXXpedition crew member aboard the S/V Sea Dragon to sail from Brazil to Guyana this December to bring awareness of the issue of plastics in our environment, our bodies, and to ignite public support among those who are concerned with this issue, to inspire others to take action, and to promote women in science.

My goal is to raise seven thousand dollars by the end of August 2015, to cover the costs of the expedition fees. If I raise more than my goal, I will donate all extra proceeds to Sylvia Earle Alliance Mission Blue, the ocean conservation nonprofit I work for who is working to create Hope Spots, a network of marine protected areas around the world, that will help protect our oceans, the blue heart of the planet.

About eXXpedition

Mission
Our mission is to explore the issue of plastics, chemicals, endocrine disruptors and carcinogens in our personal and global environment that can cause disease. Our aim is to engage women in scientific narratives relating to the consumer choices they make, and their long-term health impacts on themselves and our environment.

Along an eXXpedition voyage the crew sample the Ocean for plastics and pollutants, feeding in these samples to wider studies investigating the impacts of toxics and plastics pollutants and linking this sampling to narratives of ecosystem health, personal health and the products we consume.

Why This? Why Now?
Innovation: We explore the alternatives to toxics while inspiring entrepreneurs and industry to create innovations that are ‘benign by design’.

Awareness: We are ambassadors for science, for early diagnostics and a proactive approach to health monitoring.

Inspiration: We inspire young women to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering and enterprise while understanding the links between ecosystem health and human health.

Education: We development of engaging digital education materials on ocean science, ecology, environmental science and toxics developed in reference to the UK national curriculum and developed to be open source in collaboration with Education platform ‘Digital Explorer’ and ‘Skype in the Classroom’.
story_txt: I was selected as an eXXpedition crew member aboard the S/V Sea Dragon to sail from Brazil to Guyana this December to bring awareness of the issue of plastics in our environment, our bodies, and to ignite public support among those who are concerned with this issue, to inspire others to take action, and to promote women in science.My goal is to raise seven thousand dollars by the end of August 2015, to cover the costs of the expedition fees. If I raise more than my goal, I will donate all extra proceeds to Sylvia Earle Alliance Mission Blue, the ocean conservation nonprofit I work for who is working to create Hope Spots, a network of marine protected areas around the world, that will help protect our oceans, the blue heart of the planet.About eXXpedition MissionOur mission is to explore the issue of plastics, chemicals, endocrine disruptors and carcinogens in our personal and global environment that can cause disease. Our aim is to engage women in scientific narratives relating to the consumer choices they make, and their long-term health impacts on themselves and our environment.Along an eXXpedition voyage the crew sample the Ocean for plastics and pollutants, feeding in these samples to wider studies investigating the impacts of toxics and plastics pollutants and linking this sampling to narratives of ecosystem health, personal health and the products we consume.Why This? Why Now?Innovation: We explore the alternatives to toxics while inspiring entrepreneurs and industry to create innovations that are ‘benign by design’.Awareness: We are ambassadors for science, for early diagnostics and a proactive approach to health monitoring.Inspiration: We inspire young women to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering and enterprise while understanding the links between ecosystem health and human health.Education: We development of engaging digital education materials on ocean science, ecology, environmental science and toxics developed in reference to the UK national curriculum and developed to be open source in collaboration with Education platform ‘Digital Explorer’ and ‘Skype in the Classroom’.

story:
Short Summary

We are raising money to improve our local neighborhood (5th and Mission) by replacing damaged trees. Our urban neighborhood has 5 trees that need to be replaced, which would not only make our neighborhood prettier, but provide cleaner air for the pedestrian traffic. We are working with Friends of the Urban Forest (FUF), a non-profit organization based in San Francisco. FUF helps individuals and neighborhood groups plant and care for street trees and sidewalk gardens. This "green infrastructure" improves the city by beautifying neighborhoods, cleaning the air, raising property values and reducing polluted storm-water runoff. Since 1981, FUF has planted more than 49,000 trees, totaling 47% of the city's street tree canopy.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We only need $1,000 in monies! This will replace 5 trees.
  • We have a stretch goal of an additional $1,000 to help San Francisco School District purchase trees for school yards.
  • If we do not reach our goal, all funds will go directly to FUF to be applied to low-income neighborhoods that require trees or tree care services.


Perks!!

  • $5 Facebook shout-out
  • $15 FUF Pin
  • $30 (for individuals) Facebook shout-out from FUF and Pin 
  • $50 FUF Shirt
  • $100 (for business/group) Facebook shout-out from FUF
The Impact

Typically, to sign up for a tree or replacement tree services through FUF, neighbors come together and complete a tree plant request form. Once a neighborhood has at least 30 trees requested, a tree planting date is scheduled. Plantings are community events that include neighborhood residents, volunteers and FUF staff. Most of FUF's tree planting costs are covered by grants and donations; only a small copayment is made by property owners. Since the 5th and Mission is an urban, lower-income, and commercial neighborhood, there are challenges to get property owners to come together. As many of us call this neighborhood work or it's part of our commute, it's up to us to change the appearance, improve the quality of air and build a green community. 

Trees produce oxygen, clean the air and reduce global warming

  • Trees release oxygen as a product of photosynthesis.  Two medium-sized, healthy trees can supply the oxygen required for a single person for a year. 
  • Trees clean the air by absorbing greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming; they store carbon dioxide, the primary greenhouse gas, in their stems and leaves. 
  • Trees capture airborne particles such as dirt, dust and soot; a mature tree can absorb 120-240 lbs of particulate pollution each year.
  •  A 2008 study by researchers at Columbia University found that more trees in urban neighborhoods correlate with a lower incidence of asthma.

And more benefits… 

                                                                                               

  •  Street trees and sidewalk gardens create a physical and mental barrier between the street and the sidewalk, keeping pedestrians, children and pets out of harm’s way.
  • Street trees and sidewalk gardens provide a natural habitat for birds and insects.
  • Street trees absorb traffic noise and increase privacy.
  • Street trees and sidewalk gardens build neighborhood and civic pride.
  • Neighborhood planting events strengthen communities and bring neighbors together.

Benefits of working with Friends of the Urban Forest

  • Thanks to more than three decades of experience, FUF are the experts in the selection, planting and care of street trees and sidewalk gardens in every neighborhood in San Francisco.
  • They work with property owners to ensure they get the trees and sidewalk gardens most suitable for them.
  • They manage every step in the process, from site inspection to species selection to planting and follow-up care.
  • Their group planting events bring neighbors together to transform their block.

Risks & Challenges

IGG will not touch any contributions, instead all funds will directly go to the Friends of the Urban Forest.

Other Ways You Can Help

if you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share our campaign on Social Media and with all of your friends! (just click any of the share buttons right down here)
  • Volunteer to help us plant the trees! Strong bodies are always needed. All of the labor is being donated, and your help appreciated. Volunteer at FUF  http://www.fuf.net/get-involved/

story:
Hello, my name is Bob Voyles and I hail from Minnesota, which is known as the "Breadbasket of Invention."  I'm a Christian, a family man, a husband, father and grandfather, and a former soldier, coast-to-coast trucker and state corrections officer...now trying my hand at inventing.  I took mechanical drawing courses in the past, and I worked with guns extensively as a unit armorer while in the US Army, taking them apart, cleaning and maintaining them, and putting them back together...M-14's,M-16's, M-60's, Colt .45's and Remington 12-guage shotguns.  I also worked on an automated dairy farm when I was younger, and I've always performed most of the maintenance work on my own cars over the years.  I have a degree in Criminal/Social Justice.

Several years ago, I challenged myself to come up with a better, more useful wind turbine, and now I've got a patent (11/22/11) for a brand new kind of bladeless wind turbine I want to unleash on our environment, in order to help people and our planet.  The new device is called the "Millennium," and it has no whirling blades, which makes it so unique.

The wheel is double enclosed.  The turbine, or wheel, is not seen.  This new vertical-axis wind turbine goes on building tops anywhere in a good wind zone.  I believe this is both futuristic and disruptive technology that will forever change the way we  look at renewable wind energy.  Can you imagine wind turbines that don't even need towers?  My new design can reduce or even completely eliminate electricity distribution costs, which can be close to the cost of electricity generation itself--in other words, half of your electric bill.  But most importantly, with the Millennium, wind can be used to safely power buildings, on-site, anywhere there is a good wind, for a greener future.  That's my goal.

I'm looking for environmentally-minded people to share my realistic dream of more and better wind turbine use, by donating to this fund that will help me obtain a professional-quality working prototype of my new design.   If I don't reach anything close to my goal, I will instead use whatever funds I've raised for animation work to show how the Millennium works--a worthy secondary cause that can serve almost the same purpose of a prototype, just not quite as well.  Anything received over my goal will go toward an even larger prototype, the bigger the better!

 

I've already checked into various local Twin Cities area prototype building services.  A lot is available, but generally quite costly.  In order that contributors would be able to see the progress and results of my campaign-- and feel that they are involved with how the campaign is doing, I plan to keep everyone abreast of what's happening by uploading photos and current information to my website, and I will provide to anyone who asks, exactly where any and all donated money is spent for either prototyping or for animation, whichever it ends up being.

 

 

 

The bottom line is that I promise that any money I raise here will be spent for furthering the publicity of the new turbine, whether for a prototype if I raise anywhere close to my goal, or for animation services if I don't raise enough even for a smaller prototype.  It is my sincere belief that your donation can end up making a huge impact on saving the environment and slowing global warming if my new wind turbine technology ends up reaching the far corners of the earth.  I'm excited that the technology could also help bring water to the water-needy in certain parts of the world.

 

 

I started out trying to invent a better, more useful wind turbine--for building tops, and I believe I have succeeded.  But as it has turned out so far, that was the easy part.  The hard part is showing people what I came up with.  "Seeing is believing" seems to be key, so a valid working prototype also seems to be crucial in the process--or at least a very good animation.  In what I'm attempting to do here, I promise I'll try my best to make this "real" to you in such a way as to build trust, as my goal is to help people and Earth with my new wind turbine technology, not to take advantage of anyone.

If you can't donate money, perhaps you'll consider helping with your time by telling others about this effort.  Any help at all will be greatly appreciated...even your prayers!  And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools as I strive to develop social media connections.  I set up a special website to showcase my new invention and talk about it, and I can be reached by email through the site if anyone has any questions or any good ideas to help me in this Indiegogo crowdsourcing effort.

 

www.hallmarkemporium.com

And that’s it, as we hope for a better environmental future.  Thanks for your vision and for your contributions!

 

- Bob Voyles, from the "Breadbasket of Invention," MN

story:
My name is Miruna Soiu and I am from Transilvania, Romania. I have been living in Canada for the past 12 years, however, my heart has never left Romania. Two years ago I got involved in the 'Save Rosia Montana' campaign. What is this all about? Rosia Montana is a beautiful historical place in the mountains of Transilvania where Gabriel Resurces of Canada wants to open the largest open pit gold mine in Europe. Environmentalist and activists have been fighting this project for over 13 years; the project is destructive for the following reasons:

-Over 13.000 tons of cyanide would be used each year to leach the gold.

-Four mountains will be cut open and thus destroyed.

-Rosia Montana is the oldest documented settlement in Romania, containing important historical vestiges from the Roman Empire time. Everything will be lost.

-The Romanian state will make 6% of the profit from the gold and silver and 0% of the profit from the precious metals, which some experts say could have more value than the gold. 

- The Romanian state will be responsible with maintaining the huge dam containing cyanide and other chemical residues that would be released from the exploration, forever. A similar dam at Baie Mare, also in Romainia, collapsed in 2000 and caused the largest environmental disaster in history next to Chernobyl, only now eclipsed by Fukishima.

-People will be forced off their land to make room for the mine

Sadly, it is extremely difficult to fight against a large well-funded corporation. In the past two years, Gabriel resources has led the most aggressive advertising campaigns in the history of Romania, and has managed to get on their side the key politicians involved in giving the permits for the mine, including the president and the prime minister. The president is now proposing a change in the constitution that would allow foreign companies to expropriate private property to serve their needs. Thusly the Romanian people are outraged at this, and have taken to the streets in the tens of thousands, with the following demands.

1.Rosia Montana be included in the UNESCO World Heritage Site

2 Romanian government and parliament make a bill that bans the use of cyanide in mining in Romania.

3. All the corrupt politicians involved in this case resign, including the prime-minister.


This fundraiser would allow me to fly back to Romania and participate in the protests. This is the most important moment in the history of Romania since the fall of communism in 1989. My heart is there with these wonderful people that want to put an end to the extremely corrupt political class. My biggest desire is to join them physically. Your contribution would allow me to take part in the most important event of my life      (other than the birth of my daughter and my wedding day)

story:
Hola everyone!

 

 

We are Rio Muchacho Organic Farm and Eco-lodge, a family-owned social enterprise located near the northern coast of Ecuador. The farm and lodge is internationally known and recognized by National Geographic for our work in eco-tourism along with numerous projects in education and community outreach. Since 1989, we have been working to create a sustainable working farm that supports the local community and provides opportunities for visitors and volunteers from around the world to learn about permaculture and reforestation.

 

On April 16th, 2016, a devastating 7.8 Richter earthquake hit Provincia Manabi. At least 673 people lost their lives along the coast. Here at the farm, we lost 8 cabins and our remaining infrastructure needs repairs. Our Canoa office, which was also home to our and eco-papel workshop, was totally flattened and all records & photos destroyed. It was a heart wrenching loss that continues to affect our ability to operate.

 

We are committed to rebuilding—but we need your help! Recovering from the earthquake is key to returning our focus back to the community and the education work that defines so much of what we do.

 

Moving forward and changing lives

 

Since 1989 owners Darío Proaño-Leroux and Nicola Mears have pioneered to practice responsible agricultural activity. We have also made Rio Muchacho a center for the dissemination and practice of the principles of sustainability, agro-ecology, permaculture, and ecotourism. Every day, we lead through by example: Rio Muchacho has zero waste and is focused on biodiversity, feeding the soil, sustainable construction and the principles of organic agriculture.

 

In 2014, we began working to transform Rio Muchacho into an Eco-farm Park.  Our goal is to create a family-friendly, hands-on experience in which individuals can explore, observe and experiment with nature at a low cost. We hope to offer Ecuadorians as well as our international visitors an accessible experience. This project has been delayed by the devastation created by the earthquake.

 

Work has also been stalled in our efforts to create an Information Centre focused on alternative agriculture and sustainability. Plans also include an Interactive Learning Centre: a learning-through-play space that creates an opportunity for young visitors to practice agriculture. There will be models, tools, equipment, plants, seeds, pots, agricultural games, and a 3-D model of the farm made of recycled materials.

 

Continual progress and looking forward

 

Since the earthquake, progress to reconstruct buildings here at Rio Muchacho has been postponed as we’ve focused on supporting our neighbors. After the earthquake, we held two bamboo construction workshops for people involved in reconstruction, bringing to light the beauty and strength of bamboo, as well as its incredible utility in creating resilient homes and structures. We’ve also been supporting infrastructure projects in our community to help keep everyone moving forward. Despite this big setback, Río Muchacho continues to be a leader in change, modeling resiliency and finding creative solutions.

 

We can no longer delay repairing and rebuilding our own structures. We have dismantled the remnants of the main house that was our center for activities, kitchen, and housed many beds in its four stories. Our ability to offer workshops and host volunteers and visitors has been significantly reduced.

 

Our most important work, educating children and families, has been affected with the delay of our Information and Interactive Learning Centres. Every donation helps us get closer to focusing again on this essential work.

 

 

Our current goal is to balence reconstruction work with the ongoing demands of maintaining the farm, all the while continuing our important work in sustainable education. But we need your help!

 

Money donated will support rebuilding structures at Rio Muchacho, including our Community Store, farm kitchen, and lodging for volunteers and visitors. As always, we plan to use mostly natural materials that grow in the lowlands. Demand for these materials as more and more people become aware of their utility means that prices have risen, as has labor costs for the experts knowledgeable in working with the bamboo.

 

Thank You!!

As you can probably imagine, the cost for reconstruction is daunting. Total reconstruction expenses will exceed $100,000 (USD), not to mention hundreds of hours of volunteer time. We are asking our worldwide community of supporters, volunteers, and visitors to help us raise $50,000.  We also invite you to visit the farm to volunteer—or simply to enjoy the natural beauty and learn about what we do!

 

We are very grateful for any help you can give! Even a donation of $10 or $20 helps!

 

While we grieve the losses from the earthquake, we continue to work hard to create a beautiful learning space. Our mission is to create a sustainable environment that is ecologically sound, economically viable, and that cherishes the intrinsic worth of every living thing. 

 

Thank you again for your support. We hope to see you in the future!

 

Un abrazo a todos,

Nicola, Dario, Raphael, Florence, and The Río Muchacho Team.

As always, we plan to use mostly natural materials that grow in the lowlands. Demand for these materials as more and more people become aware of their utility means that prices have risen, as has labor costs for the experts knowledgeable in working with the bamboo.
 
Thank You!! 
As you can probably imagine, the cost for reconstruction is daunting. Total reconstruction expenses will exceed $100,000 (USD), not to mention hundreds of hours of volunteer time. We are asking our worldwide community of supporters, volunteers, and visitors to help us raise $50,000.  We also invite you to visit the farm to volunteer—or simply to enjoy the natural beauty and learn about what we do!
 
We are very grateful for any help you can give! Even a donation of $10 or $20 helps! 
 
While we grieve the losses from the earthquake, we continue to work hard to create a beautiful learning space. Our mission is to create a sustainable environment that is ecologically sound, economically viable, and that cherishes the intrinsic worth of every living thing. 
 
Thank you again for your support. We hope to see you in the future!
 
Un abrazo a todos,
Nicola, Dario, Raphael, Florence, and The Río Muchacho Team.

story:
Be part of history! Both the making of history and the preserving of it.

The people of Southwest Michigan are some of the kindest you will find on the planet. It was and is one of the most wonderful things about growing up on a farm there. Everyone shared their bounty - whether you were a neighbor or a friend or someone who happened to visit our farm for a day, you were treated with respect and fed - fed beautiful, locally grown and processed, organic food. 

Underlying that beautiful giving spirit are statistics that may sadden you. 

  • Michigan ranks as the fifth most overweight and obese state in the nation.
  • 69 percent of the adults in Allegan County are overweight or obese.
  • Most adults in the community eat few fruits and vegetables.
  • Yet, Allegan County ranks as the highest agricultural producer in the state.
  •  Michigan unemployment is higher than the national average at 9.4 percent.
  • This rate is higher for developmentally disabled adults
  • Nearly a quarter of all high school students in Michigan don't graduate.

What could WE do to make a difference? What can YOU do to help? We asked ourselves those questions and came up with this:

Turn our farm into a sustainable farm and learning center that produces beautiful, organic food to the community (both for sale and to those in need); while generating jobs for the community.

Our motto:
Honoring the past, healing the present, nurturing the future

Our goal - to marry the best of the old - the skills, that spirit, that generosity - with the latest in best practices both in farming and environmental stewardship.

We set out to create a learning center where people can learn farm skills, do meaningful work, grow beautiful food they can eat, where we can model the pillars of sustainability - like our grandparents did of old.

We have been painting, plowing, planting and invite you to a work party... check out our website at www.honorhealnurture.com

We have more to do. It will take investments by lots of people of time and money to get where we have a thriving compost and garden business that employs local disadvantaged youth and developmentally disabled adults; a commercial kitchen that serves as a classroom and meeting center; a fully renovated barn that houses community gatherings and serves as a solar energy generating charging station for electric vehicles.

We WANT to raise:

$14,400 to repair the beams and roof in the barn to save the structure
$10,000 to repair the roof of the old farmhouse
$25,100 for complete barn repairs
$30,100 to add solar to the barn to generate electricity that can be sold back to the electric company

In return - you ARE invited to an amazing barn dance and celebration right in the barn!

We have beautiful organic t-shirts that capture the essence of our motto: honoring the past, healing the present, nurturing the future. We have blocks that you can put the name of a farm hero on. We have bricks, the requisite bricks, except ours were taken from an old, unused chimney on the farm. We have caps and cards. All sorts of wonderful things. We just need you.

So, donate today. Get a perk or volunteer to come out and work. Do it for the future. Do it for the fun. Do it because you care. We know you do.

Thank you for your love and support,

the Rudy and Ann Palenick Family

story:
Love The Earth Summit but can't make it this year? Want to make sure The Earth Summit exists to attend in a future year?

This year has been an incredibly difficult fundraising year, with corporate sponsors, Columbia, and individuals all slashing budgets. And yet in only our second year, we have more than doubled our fundraising to $19500 $22700, and quadrupled our programming!

Yet we just have a little more to fundraise. 2/3 of our budget is just the venue (space and A/V equipment)!

Help us make our targets by contributing and making the case to future sponsors that this is an event with wide reach worth sustaining. 

Thanks for your help!

The 2nd Columbia University Earth Summit Team

 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

This year, The Columbia University Earth Summit is focused on Driving Collaborative Solutions across sectors. Our world is rapidly changing, requiring leaders who can engage stakeholders, inspire partnerships, and challenge barriers. 

Join us on March 29 in welcoming Jeffrey Sachs, Jason Bordoff, His Excellency Stuart Beck, Nils Bruzelius, Carrie Norton, and Karl Giberson, among many other inspiring speakers. Watch undergraduates battle it out in the Resolution Social Venture Challenge, be inspired by Columbia early-stage entrepreneurs at our Idea Lab, and network during our working lunches and reception.

While the question of climate change is still being discussed, for the vast majority of the population living in rapidly changing circumstances, the debate is over. Climate change is real, and it is here to stay. Climate, along with equally important drivers—such as overpopulation and economic growth—force us to confront an uncomfortable question: are we prepared for the challenge?

Throughout the morning, we will look at the effects of a changing environment on the economy, public health, security and justice, and education. In each session, we will debate ways of engaging new stakeholders, discuss what still needs to be done, and identify the roadblocks. In the afternoon, we will look specifically at finance, policy, and technological solutions to these questions. 

Register now. Together, we can find the solutions that make our world a better place for future generations.

If you have questions or would like to present at the Idea Lab, please e-mail us. Click here for more information on registering for the Social Venture Challenge (undergraduates only). Follow us on Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn.

story:
-------------

Take action against Climate Change!

DJs Against Climate Change is entering it's 5th year of helping DJs offset the environmentally damaging carbon emissions produced from their airplane travel.  With the rise in popularity of Electronic Dance Music, more artists than ever are traversing the globe in order to play for live audiences.  These flights contribute millions of tons of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, but are unavoidable in order for DJs to perform.  As participants in DJACC, we recognize this negative aspect in our line of work and use our cultural influence to show how everyone can take responsibility for their impact on Climate Change.

Last year we banded together to offset 457,000 Lbs of CO2, equivalent to over one million miles worth of air travel.  Let's do even better in 2012!

Your contributions will go to myclimate and fund climate conscious development around the world.

myclimate is a Swiss non-profit organization which provides carbon offsets; funding towards projects that reduce climate-impacting emissions.  Whether providing methane reducing biodigesters in India, energy efficient stoves in Kenya or similar efforts around the world, myclimate funds serve the additional impact of fostering sustainable development in the project regions. To learn more about myclimate and their specific initiatives, visit their website.

Did You know? You can write-off your carbon offset contribution as a business expense on your 2012 taxes.

How can I participate? 

Custom Calculation

Send us your home city and tour dates for 2012 using the  Submission Form and we'll calculate your unique carbon emissions from airline travel for the year . You can then choose to offset the entire amount, or anything in between. If you'd like a hands on approach, do it yourself using the MyClimate calculator.

Flat rate 

If you don't need to know your exact emissions, use the suggested contributions to offset a carbon level that matches your amount of travel or what you can afford to give.

 

Support the Cause

if you're a DJ who doesn't fly a lot, or even if you're just a fan of DJs and this cause, please consider giving.  There is no way we can offset the carbon emissions from all the DJs in our community, so every little bit helps increase the money we send towards offset projects around the world!

 

Please participate in DJs Against Climate Change at whatever level you can.  The more people get involved, the more we raise awareness.

Questions? email djaccinfo@gmail.com

 

@DJACCinfo / @SammyBananas

Past Participants Include: 

A-Trak, Anna Lunoe, Apt One, Chris Devlin, Cosmo Baker, Cousin Cole, Dave Nada, DJ Ayres, DJ Day, DJ Benny C, Mike the 2600 King, Morse Code, Pete Emes, The Hood Internet, thee Mike B, Treasure Fingers, Sammy Bananas, Skinny Friedman, Skratch Bastid, Star Eyes, Tittsworth, Willy Joy

 

Press

story:
Our Plan:

We are a small alliance of natural builders/designers who call ourselves Ecotecture International. We want to change how the typical house currently deals with its water usage on an urban scale.

Retrofitting our existing infrastructure is as important (if not more so) as building new. Our society has overly invested in poor mechanisms for long-term sustainability. To make a change from our current system we must prove that there is a working alternative. 

Our project will take a typical urban house and attempt to remove it from the municipal water system by installing a series of filters and pumps. The house will become its own watercatchment and supply source. We hope it will be simple enough for others to replicate.

These systems are known to work on earthship designs but they have not been tested on retrofits for typical construction houses. 

 

What We Need:

Anticipated Costs:

Shurflo Pump                        $200

Sediment Filters                    $240

Ceramic Filter w/ housing        $190

30/50 pressure switch             $20                                        

Pressure Gauge                     $10

Pressure Tank                       $220

OGWM Pipes and fitting          $140

1,700 gallon tank                  $1,600

Tank fittings and pipe            $150

Roofing materials                  $1,300 

Total Material Costs:             $4,070

If we are unable to reach the full goal the money will go towards making a smaller demonstration version that can be taken and displayed at different events for people to see and replicate. 

The Impact

 

  • It has been said that the wars of the future will be fought not over oil, but for water. If we can secure our water now then we could be preventing wars for the future.
  • We have helped poor communities around the world by building schoolhouses, meditation centers, and communal kitchens.  Now let's help ourselves right here in our own country by learning how to free ourselves from contaminated water supplies and unnecessary utility bills.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not be able contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hello! I'm Taylor.

I need about 4 thousand dollars to make it from Orlando, Florida to San Francisco, California. I am a free spirit and I've figured out that I need to travel to be happy.

I made it from Maine to Florida, now it's time for a new scene. I'll be graduating college in March, 2013 with my Entertainment Business (BS) degree, so California seems like the logical place to go in order to be successful in my field.

The only problem is that I struggle financially at the moment. With my school only providing off-campus living, I pay rent and bills every month, as well as other expenses. I do have a job at my school making a little bit of money through the Work-Study Program, and my parents povide what they can to help me - but that only gets me so far. I do not have any extra money to start a legitimate savings going.

All I ask is for any contribution to help me live out my young dreams. Anything helps! 

 

{I know the campaign only goes until October 8th, 2012, but that's because it maxes out at 120 days. I do plan on saving/continuing to fundraise until I graduate college}
