story:
Sun, 12 May - No more contributions are needed. The City of Berkeley is FINALLY stepping in to offer the home owner guidance on this decommissioning...

About Me 

I am a renewable energy engineer with a background in renewable energy, systems engineering, sustainable development, and IT systems analysis and administration. I am currently providing my services at no charge/volunteering to the Wysinger Family in Berkeley, CA, USA who requires assistance decommissioning this freewheeling [non-electricity generating] Aero Power SL 1500 small wind turbine. This wind turbine was installed on their property back in December 1981, and commissioned in January 1982.

About the Project

NB: 5/9/13 - The campaign's aim now is to raise at least $600 to tie down the rotor/blades as a temporary fix.

Generating energy closer to where it will be used just makes sense. However, when a small wind turbine is poorly sited, the results can be worthless – and worse. It can become a safety hazard for the community. But decommissioning such a turbine would be a valuable lesson for future residential wind power, when aging wind turbines will have to be decommissioned, and provide valuable information in developing future residential wind turbines. Want to be a part of wind power history?

Case in point, the Aero Power SL1500 that was installed in December 1981 and commissioned January 1982 at 3228 Idaho Street in Berkeley, CA. Check out the digitized 8mm video of the installation, and click here to read the 25 March 1982 Berkeley Gazette article about this installation. 

NB: There is no sound to the video. 

You can fast-forward the 12:15 YouTube video to these time stamps of interest:

2:05 Base of tower/mast installed
3:30 Second section of the tower/mast installed
3:55 Third section of the tower/mast installed
5:15 Fourth section of the tower/mast installed
5:50 Wind turbine generator and tail hoisted to top of tower/mast
8:20 Shot of VERY DATED Phasor/Inverter
9:00 Wind turbine rotor blades hoisted and attached to generator and tail sections
10:04 Aero Power SL 1500 wind turbine spinning

Sadly, in just a couple of months the family realized the wind turbine would not generate the amount of electricity the developer had promised. So they decided to decommission it. However, they just did not have the financial means to do that -- especially after the $12,000 they’d dropped on the installation.

Fast forward to 2005…

One day early in 2005, I happened to turned down Idaho Street on my bike, and discovered the wind turbine. I was inspired to see this machine in a densely populated, major metropolitan area – so inspired, in fact, that I returned to grad school to study small wind turbines in the built/urban environment. What I mostly learned there was how NOT to install a small wind turbine in the built/urban environment and composed a presentation you can read, Installing a Small WTG in the Built Environment - What not to do...

NB: This presentation includes information about the specifications about the wind turbine and its performance.

Fast forward to 2012…

Upon my return to the Bay Area, I asked the Wysinger family about the history of their wind turbine. I learned that it had well exceeded a typical life expectancy of 20 years without a catastrophic failure. The blades on the rotor and other parts of the generator have not sheared off as projectiles -- yet. This is a testimony to the turbine’s robust design by Mario Agnello. 

Why we need to do this

What is particularly unfortunate about this wind turbine is that it's been freewheeling (spinning without generating electricity) for over ten years, because someone accidentally severed the brake cable, nor was this wind machine the recipient of any maintenance over all this time -- making this machine derelict and dangerous. Several small wind energy experts have told me that this turbine needs to come down post-haste before there is loss of life or property.

Decommissioning the turbine will be historic. Decommissioning a wind turbine in an urban environment is not an everyday occurrence. The Wysingers wind turbine is one of a few decommissioned in the urban environment in the USA. And to the best of my knowledge, the only one (?) in the SF Bay Area, but to the best of my knowledge, the first one in Berkeley.

Why we need your help and how we’ll use your contributions

I plan on bringing this story full circle. I will invite the local Channel 5 news team who was on site back in 1981 to return and follow up on the situation, bringing attention to the issue and helping raise funds. That’s important because if we don’t reach our full funding goal it will be difficult to bring this project to completion, and everyone will be sad -- and people and/or property could get hurt/damaged.

Your contributions will cover the costs of permits, fees, and experts. This will help the Wysinger family, since they don’t have the funds to cover these costs.

And the project will help others, too. What we learn in this decommissioning will benefit other communities who may need to do this in the future. I also hope the report I am in the process of writing will be the beginning of an exacting standard for the small wind turbine industry. The costs of number of permits, fees and experts need to be covered, and the Wysinger family lacks the financial means to do fund this endeavor. That's where I require your assistance…

Risks and Challenges 

This is unknown or new territory for everyone involved: me, the Wysinger Family, the City of Berkeley, my wind energy experts and other contractors who will be on the job. But I will take every precaution to mitigate risks. 

Safety is my biggest concern. Only when the asbestos abatement survey is completed can we get permits for the demolition and encroachment from the City of Berkeley. After that, we can begin the actual decommissioning. 

Small wind energy expert Ian Woofenden, along with California Licensed C10 Electricians and demolition experts, have offered to help me. We’ll work together to get the turbine down safely from atop the 60-foot pole, so no one is hurt and no property is damaged.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand it's a difficult time financially for a lot of folks--but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • You can help us get the word out by sharing information about this project on social media networks like Twitter, Reddit or Facebook. 
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

FAQ

Why does it cost so much to decommission this wind turbine?

Yes, it surprisingly costs a great deal to decommission this small wind turbine. This is due to the fact that it was installed in a location that would not be allowable by today's standards. It is in very close proximity to electrical power lines and housing structures, making this decommissioning very chanllenging. A breakdown of the costs follows:

  • Planning [includes an asbestos survey and report, miscellaneous City of Berkeley paperwork, wind expert consultations] - $2,262.00
  • Wind turbine expert - $3,300.00
  • PG&E [budget for Utility Clearance an to de-energize circuits--this is an estimate; it could end up being $3,000 more!] - $5,000.00
  • City of Berkeley permits [electrical, demolition, zoning, encroachment] - $3,045.00
  • Crane [includes the crane rental, operator, rigger] - $2,800.00
  • Incidentals - $2,500.00
  • Electrician - $1,500.00
  • Tree climber [to assist the wind turbine expert] - $250.00
  • Hauling [for mast to the recycler] - $160.00

TOTAL: $20,817.00

How does the cost of this decommissioning compare to the cost of other wind turbines decommissioned?

Yes, $20,000+ is a great deal of money for a single, residential wind turbine. However, this is several times less to the costs for decommissioning utility scale wind turbines. This citation is from an April 2011 article – Unused wind farm raises decommissioning issues

[snip]
…the costs for removing the turbines have been prohibitively high,…

…costs would approach $1 million, and while the parts could be sold for scrap metal he said that would net only about $300,000…

…the estimated cost of taking down a present-day turbine, when that time comes, will be $100,000 in today’s dollars…

Where can I find out more about the wind turbine's technical specifications?

Unfortunately, there is no formal, historical print documentation available for this machine. Information about this wind turbine's technical specifications can be located in the Installing a Small WTG in the Built Environment - What not to do... presentation.

Why did the family want to decommission the turbine when it was still generating power, even though they weren’t getting as much power as promised? 

Based on their PG&E bill, the family realized after a short period of time, this machine was not going to come close in affording them the promised payback by the developer within the predicted timeframe.

If the turbine has been freewheeling for so long with no damage, why is it urgent to take it down now? 

At 30 years and 5 months, this wind turbine has never received any maintenance, and far exceeded its life expectancy of 20 years. Like the moving parts in an automobile, machines eventually fail, fall apart, break. Most utility scale wind turbines are subject to a preventative maintenance check of '40 hours per year.'    Parts of this machine and it's tower/mast/pole could shear off/'shed-off' projectiles and land on a person(s) or adjacent property.

What are your credentials? 

I studied hybrid renewable energy systems and small wind turbines at the Centre for Renewable Energy Systems Technology (CREST) at Loughborough [pronounced 'Lufbra'] University in the UK. One of only a handful of universities offering a graduate/post-graduate engineering credential in the world offering solar, wind, biomass and hydrokinetic/water renewable energy systems technologies course work. I have also been applying my knowledge in the renewable energy realm since 2004. I additionally hold a certificate in Wind Power And Turbine Technology by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers [ASME].

Which small wind energy experts have you consulted? 

I’ve consulted these following top small wind energy experts in the USA: 

  • Paul Gipe, Wind-Works 
  • Mick Sagrillo, Sagrillo Power & Light
  • Ian Woofenden, renewablereality.net, Editor for Home Power Magazine since 1998
  • Scott Jackson [Retired] of Power Shacks, Chico, CA, USA

All these experts agree this machine needs to come down post haste before there is loss of life or property.
story_txt:
Sun, 12 May - No more contributions are needed. The City of Berkeley is FINALLY stepping in to offer the home owner guidance on this decommissioning... 
About Me 
I am a renewable energy engineer with a background in renewable energy, systems engineering, sustainable development, and IT systems analysis and administration. I am currently providing my services at no charge/volunteering to the Wysinger Family in Berkeley, CA, USA who requires assistance decommissioning this freewheeling [non-electricity generating] Aero Power SL 1500 small wind turbine. This wind turbine was installed on their property back in December 1981, and commissioned in January 1982.
About the Project
NB: 5/9/13 - The campaign's aim now is to raise at least $600 to tie down the rotor/blades as a temporary fix.
Generating energy closer to where it will be used just makes sense. However, when a small wind turbine is poorly sited, the results can be worthless – and worse. It can become a safety hazard for the community. But decommissioning such a turbine would be a valuable lesson for future residential wind power, when aging wind turbines will have to be decommissioned, and provide valuable information in developing future residential wind turbines. Want to be a part of wind power history?
Case in point, the Aero Power SL1500 that was installed in December 1981 and commissioned January 1982 at 3228 Idaho Street in Berkeley, CA. Check out the digitized 8mm video of the installation, and click here to read the 25 March 1982 Berkeley Gazette article about this installation. 
NB: There is no sound to the video. You can fast-forward the 12:15 YouTube video to these time stamps of interest:
2:05 Base of tower/mast installed 3:30 Second section of the tower/mast installed 3:55 Third section of the tower/mast installed 5:15 Fourth section of the tower/mast installed 5:50 Wind turbine generator and tail hoisted to top of tower/mast 8:20 Shot of VERY DATED Phasor/Inverter 9:00 Wind turbine rotor blades hoisted and attached to generator and tail sections 10:04 Aero Power SL 1500 wind turbine spinning
Sadly, in just a couple of months the family realized the wind turbine would not generate the amount of electricity the developer had promised. So they decided to decommission it. However, they just did not have the financial means to do that -- especially after the $12,000 they’d dropped on the installation.
Fast forward to 2005…
One day early in 2005, I happened to turned down Idaho Street on my bike, and discovered the wind turbine. I was inspired to see this machine in a densely populated, major metropolitan area – so inspired, in fact, that I returned to grad school to study small wind turbines in the built/urban environment. What I mostly learned there was how NOT to install a small wind turbine in the built/urban environment and composed a presentation you can read, Installing a Small WTG in the Built Environment - What not to do... 
NB: This presentation includes information about the specifications about the wind turbine and its performance. 
Fast forward to 2012…
Upon my return to the Bay Area, I asked the Wysinger family about the history of their wind turbine. I learned that it had well exceeded a typical life expectancy of 20 years without a catastrophic failure. The blades on the rotor and other parts of the generator have not sheared off as projectiles -- yet. This is a testimony to the turbine’s robust design by Mario Agnello. 
Why we need to do this
What is particularly unfortunate about this wind turbine is that it's been freewheeling (spinning without generating electricity) for over ten years, because someone accidentally severed the brake cable, nor was this wind machine the recipient of any maintenance over all this time -- making this machine derelict and dangerous. Several small wind energy experts have told me that this turbine needs to come down post-haste before there is loss of life or property.
Decommissioning the turbine will be historic. Decommissioning a wind turbine in an urban environment is not an everyday occurrence. The Wysingers wind turbine is one of a few decommissioned in the urban environment in the USA. And to the best of my knowledge, the only one (?) in the SF Bay Area, but to the best of my knowledge, the first one in Berkeley.
Why we need your help and how we’ll use your contributions
I plan on bringing this story full circle. I will invite the local Channel 5 news team who was on site back in 1981 to return and follow up on the situation, bringing attention to the issue and helping raise funds. That’s important because if we don’t reach our full funding goal it will be difficult to bring this project to completion, and everyone will be sad -- and people and/or property could get hurt/damaged.
Your contributions will cover the costs of permits, fees, and experts. This will help the Wysinger family, since they don’t have the funds to cover these costs.
And the project will help others, too. What we learn in this decommissioning will benefit other communities who may need to do this in the future. I also hope the report I am in the process of writing will be the beginning of an exacting standard for the small wind turbine industry. The costs of number of permits, fees and experts need to be covered, and the Wysinger family lacks the financial means to do fund this endeavor. That's where I require your assistance…

Risks and Challenges 
This is unknown or new territory for everyone involved: me, the Wysinger Family, the City of Berkeley, my wind energy experts and other contractors who will be on the job. But I will take every precaution to mitigate risks. 
Safety is my biggest concern. Only when the asbestos abatement survey is completed can we get permits for the demolition and encroachment from the City of Berkeley. After that, we can begin the actual decommissioning. 
Small wind energy expert Ian Woofenden, along with California Licensed C10 Electricians and demolition experts, have offered to help me. We’ll work together to get the turbine down safely from atop the 60-foot pole, so no one is hurt and no property is damaged.
Other Ways You Can Help
I understand it's a difficult time financially for a lot of folks--but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

You can help us get the word out by sharing information about this project on social media networks like Twitter, Reddit or Facebook. 
You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!
FAQ
Why does it cost so much to decommission this wind turbine?
Yes, it surprisingly costs a great deal to decommission this small wind turbine. This is due to the fact that it was installed in a location that would not be allowable by today's standards. It is in very close proximity to electrical power lines and housing structures, making this decommissioning very chanllenging. A breakdown of the costs follows:

Planning [includes an asbestos survey and report, miscellaneous City of Berkeley paperwork, wind expert consultations] - $2,262.00
Wind turbine expert - $3,300.00
PG&E [budget for Utility Clearance an to de-energize circuits--this is an estimate; it could end up being $3,000 more!] - $5,000.00
City of Berkeley permits [electrical, demolition, zoning, encroachment] - $3,045.00
Crane [includes the crane rental, operator, rigger] - $2,800.00
Incidentals - $2,500.00
Electrician - $1,500.00
Tree climber [to assist the wind turbine expert] - $250.00
Hauling [for mast to the recycler] - $160.00
TOTAL: $20,817.00
How does the cost of this decommissioning compare to the cost of other wind turbines decommissioned? 
Yes, $20,000+ is a great deal of money for a single, residential wind turbine. However, this is several times less to the costs for decommissioning utility scale wind turbines. This citation is from an April 2011 article – Unused wind farm raises decommissioning issues
[snip] …the costs for removing the turbines have been prohibitively high,…
…costs would approach $1 million, and while the parts could be sold for scrap metal he said that would net only about $300,000…
…the estimated cost of taking down a present-day turbine, when that time comes, will be $100,000 in today’s dollars…
Where can I find out more about the wind turbine's technical specifications? Unfortunately, there is no formal, historical print documentation available for this machine. Information about this wind turbine's technical specifications can be located in the Installing a Small WTG in the Built Environment - What not to do... presentation.
Why did the family want to decommission the turbine when it was still generating power, even though they weren’t getting as much power as promised? 
Based on their PG&E bill, the family realized after a short period of time, this machine was not going to come close in affording them the promised payback by the developer within the predicted timeframe.
If the turbine has been freewheeling for so long with no damage, why is it urgent to take it down now? 
At 30 years and 5 months, this wind turbine has never received any maintenance, and far exceeded its life expectancy of 20 years. Like the moving parts in an automobile, machines eventually fail, fall apart, break. Most utility scale wind turbines are subject to a preventative maintenance check of '40 hours per year.'    Parts of this machine and it's tower/mast/pole could shear off/'shed-off' projectiles and land on a person(s) or adjacent property.
What are your credentials? 
I studied hybrid renewable energy systems and small wind turbines at the Centre for Renewable Energy Systems Technology (CREST) at Loughborough [pronounced 'Lufbra'] University in the UK. One of only a handful of universities offering a graduate/post-graduate engineering credential in the world offering solar, wind, biomass and hydrokinetic/water renewable energy systems technologies course work. I have also been applying my knowledge in the renewable energy realm since 2004. I additionally hold a certificate in Wind Power And Turbine Technology by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers [ASME].
Which small wind energy experts have you consulted? 
I’ve consulted these following top small wind energy experts in the USA: 

Paul Gipe, Wind-Works 
Mick Sagrillo, Sagrillo Power & Light 

Ian Woofenden, renewablereality.net, Editor for Home Power Magazine since 1998
Scott Jackson [Retired] of Power Shacks, Chico, CA, USA
All these experts agree this machine needs to come down post haste before there is loss of life or property.

story:
Our beautiful blue planet needs our help!

If you take a walk along any beach in the world you will find plastic amongst the sand or stones.  This is because 10% of all plastic trash ends up in the sea.  

Plastic pollution is a huge, and growing, problem.  There are an estimated 46,000 pieces in every square mile of ocean.   Every year plastic kills more than 100,000 marine mammals like seals, sea lions, dolphins and whales, and a million seabirds like the Laysan Albatross (http://www.midwayfilm.com/).  Plastic particles attract toxins and enter the food chain and finally, us.  Babies are now born with chemicals in their bodies that are only used in the manufacture of plastic. 


Please do NOT make a financial contribution to this campaign.  Your contribution is to STOP using plastic.

story:
What is Mission 31?

Hello, I am Fabien Cousteau. The name should ring a bell - I am Jacques Cousteau's grandson. Like my oceanographer grandfather, I have a love of the deep sea and a desire to explore - for science, education, our collective future and health.

Therefore, in the spring 2014 I will undertake a ground breaking project, called Mission 31. My team of scientists, ocean explorers and filmmakers will embark on a 31-day mission in Aquarius, the only underwater marine habitat and lab in the world located 63 feet beneath the sea off the coast of the Florida Keys.

Our team will test new technologies; conduct research on the effects of climate change on corals, sponges and sea life, map the seafloor, and study the physiological and psychological impacts of long-term submerging such as living in a high-pressure environment as well as living without sun exposure for prolonged periods. 

Using the latest camera technology, we will be able to show the world every moment of Mission 31 in unedited, real-time!  Thousands of school children will be able to chat with the aquanauts as they share in what they are seeing and studying, instilling a sense of love and wonder for the marine environment. 

We have explored less than five percent of our ocean realms - there's so much more to be discovered.

Professors of Marine Science from Northeastern University's Urban Coastal Sustainability Initiative and the University of Delaware CSHEL Laboratory make up the science advisory team for Mission 31, providing us with sophisticated instrumentation, including underwater robots, sensor arrays, and imaging devices.

Why Support Mission 31?

Because we want you to take part in this groundbreaking, sea-loving project. And because we hope that you too believe in our mission...

  • To provide children and young adults with both a chance to dream and to experience the excitement of discovery, exploration and scientific endeavors.
  • To conduct meaningful and important scientific experiments that can be run most effectively when truly saturated under the sea for 31 days.
  • To push the limits of human potential when living in inhospitable conditions.

Mission 31 is a very expensive endeavor. We have some financial sponsors, but need more money, and we want it coming from the crowd.  We're trying to make every aspect of Mission 31 accessible to all.

Our Partners:

  • You, via this Indiegogo campaign!
  • Skype in the classroom - Skype in the classroom has teamed up with Fabien Cousteau's record breaking Mission 31expedition to present Exploring Oceans, a month-long celebration of our oceans offering free educational talks and live experiences, delivered via Skype, with the world's leading marine experts. The aim is to inspire students around the world to think differently about our oceans.
  • The Weather Channel - You can join the dive from home by watching our underwater "peep show" on the Weather Channel.
  • Ocean Elders
  • DOXA
  • Town & Country Magazine
  • Wheelabrator Technologies
  • Turks & Caicos Reef Fund

What We Need & What You Get

This project is costing over a million dollars, but we are hoping to crowdfund a minimum of $100,000.  If more comes in, we'll be able to reach more classrooms and students around the world to teach stewardship of our seas, and turn our footage into a 3-D IMAX film.

In return for your your much appreciated dollars, we have lots of cool and unique perks for you:

Beautiful underwater shots, T-Shirt (design to be announced soon),

Fabien Cousteau's book

Limited edition DOXA watch,

Skype video calls from Aquarius

Join Mission 31 at Aquarius,

Diving with Fabien Cousteau anywhere in the world, and much more. Just check out the right of the screen.

Other Ways You Can Help - The Ambassadors Program Referral Contest

Remember, even $1 helps. But in addition to money, we would greatly appreciate more exposure. Post about this campaign on Facebook, tweet, blog, email and whatever else you can think up.

We also invite you to join our Ambassador Team. If we reach our goal, the top three folks who bring in the most money by sharing our campaign via social media, using Indiegogo's share tools above will win the exclusive opportunity to go diving with me or to potentially join us during Mission 31!  It's not just about money - influence goes a long way! For more information, contact me at fund.Mission31@gmail.com, or follow these instructions:

* Referrals to the M31 campaign (http://igg.me/at/mission31) will get you points. When you refer, you MUST use the social buttons on our campaign page and be logged in. This is how we track it.

* You will be ranked based on the amount of money raised from those referrals.

* The top 3 referrers will have the opportunity to join Mission 31 for a day, or another dive with Fabien. (you are responsible for your own travel, and must be SCUBA-certified to dive, otherwise you can visit the site above water.)

To participate, just follow these simple steps:

1. Log into Indiegogo with your username and password.

2. Go to our campaign page http://igg.me/at/mission31

3. Find the share buttons just below the video.

4. Use the Share This Campaign URL code or social buttons to share via your favorite networks.

This contest continues until the end of the campaign.  Here's the thing though - this offer is valid ONLY IF we reach our goal, so you are dependent on each other to reach as many people as possible!  On your mark, get set, go! - and share away.

If your company wants to be involved as a financial sponsor or to offer perks, be in touch as well!

Check out some of our media attention:

http://www.cnn.com/video/?/video/tech/2013/08/03/living-in-the-sea.cnn

http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/jacques-cousteau-grandson-plans-deep-sea-dive-article-1.1409766

http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/30/usa-cousteau-idUSL2N0F40WU20130630

http://www.weather.com/sports-rec/weather-ventures/fabien-cousteau-takes-grandfathers-legacy-new-depths

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2345400/Aquanaut-grandson-Jacques-Cousteau-spend-31-days-living-underwater-Florida-coast-lab-size-school-bus.html

http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/10/tech/cousteau-why-im-going-to-live-in-an-underwater-village

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l7oytGfPQw4

http://video.msnbc.msn.com/thomas-roberts/53085823#53085823

http://www.today.com/video/today/53040031#53040031

http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887323639704579016781600558404

story:
Short Summary

I am Sammy Muraya, the chairman of Vijanaa Youth Group. I currently work with a team of 16 registered members where with whom we are running an environmental project. Why environment? We chose to carry out environmental projects simply because environment habors anything needed for life. It’s through the interaction of living and non-living things that life exists. Just imagine an environment without air which is non living. How would humans and animals survive? And how would plants grow? It is against this background that we choose to collect garbage. Garbage which make breeding nests for vectors causing diseases to humans and animals. Garbage which slowly decomposes thus releasing greenhouse gases hence causing global warming among other things.

Since my city harbors slums which are not only the largest polluters in the city but also the biggest victims of diseases arising from poor waste handling, we want to restore the lost glory (aesthetic value) of our city and save lives at the same time. We definitely need your hand in this.

What we need

We have estimated the whole project to cost like $ 5000. This money will cater for the following items:

  • Gloves
  • Gas masks
  • Hire of tools such as Rakes, spades, wheelbarrows,
  • Gumboots
  • Overalls  
  • Hire of a track to ferry the wastes to designated dumping sites
  • Processing of brochures and posters
  • Preparation of certificates of participation
  •  Lunch for the participants etc

What will you get in return for your contribution? A big thank you in our native language; Swahili. Just in case we do not meet our $5000 target, we shall use the little amount that we shall manage to get.

The impact

Through the program, we are aiming at collecting the garbage and educating the local communities on the importance of living in a clean environment. It has been the desire of everyone in the world to live in an environment that is free from Malaria, cholera, diarrhea which are mainly as a result of living in a dirty environment. By carrying out this project to completion, we believe we shall have helped the global village; the world to move towards attaining its goal.

Other ways to help

Not everyone can be in a position to help financially. But is that a reason enough to mean that you can’t contribute? NO! of course you can contribute in many other ways. You can help spread the word to others and that way, you will have played your role. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to reach out others who can help. Thank you very much as you purpose to partner with us. Thanks!

story:
In a world of monstrous mountains of trash, Julio and his son confront their ultimate fight for survival as they seek refuge and redemption from war and hunger. Together, they navigate territorial rivalries and intense desperation among scavengers, surviving—and finding love—despite horrific living conditions. Julio, involved in a murder incident, must prove his innocence to avoid his family’s banishment and ultimate starvation.

A story of triumph over unusual circumstances, “The Mountain Thief” reveals the unimaginable realities of people living in extreme poverty, and what happens when their tenuous hold on hope and survival is threatened.

ABOUT THE FILM:
The Mountain Thief is the first narrative feature film that was shot in the garbage-collecting town of Promised Land and Urban, Payatas in the Philippines where the living conditions are possibly the most horrific in the world. It was also the first film that was made with a cast culled from the scavengers of a garbage-collecting town, from the graduates of the town’s only acting workshop. The Director instituted the workshop in December of 2004.

It captures a town amid mountains of trash extending as far as the eye can see, the images of children doing their best to make it, the evocative ending that is both shocking and at the same time grounded in reality. Above all, the memorable stories of the actors—all real life scavengers—desperate to survive shows us brave men, women and children who were able to dig deep in their beings and tell the film’s story—a story that hasn’t been told.

Visit www.mountainthief.com and Q&A section for more info and the director’s personal goals for the film.

AN OFFICIAL SELECTION OF THE PRESTIGIOUS 2008 IFP NARRATIVE ROUGH CUT LAB.
story_txt:
In a world of monstrous mountains of trash, Julio and his son confront their ultimate fight for survival as they seek refuge and redemption from war and hunger. Together, they navigate territorial rivalries and intense desperation among scavengers, surviving—and finding love—despite horrific living conditions. Julio, involved in a murder incident, must prove his innocence to avoid his family’s banishment and ultimate starvation.
A story of triumph over unusual circumstances, “The Mountain Thief” reveals the unimaginable realities of people living in extreme poverty, and what happens when their tenuous hold on hope and survival is threatened.
ABOUT THE FILM:
The Mountain Thief is the first narrative feature film that was shot in the garbage-collecting town of Promised Land and Urban, Payatas in the Philippines where the living conditions are possibly the most horrific in the world. It was also the first film that was made with a cast culled from the scavengers of a garbage-collecting town, from the graduates of the town’s only acting workshop. The Director instituted the workshop in December of 2004.
It captures a town amid mountains of trash extending as far as the eye can see, the images of children doing their best to make it, the evocative ending that is both shocking and at the same time grounded in reality. Above all, the memorable stories of the actors—all real life scavengers—desperate to survive shows us brave men, women and children who were able to dig deep in their beings and tell the film’s story—a story that hasn’t been told.
Visit www.mountainthief.com and Q&A section for more info and the director’s personal goals for the film.
AN OFFICIAL SELECTION OF THE PRESTIGIOUS 2008 IFP NARRATIVE ROUGH CUT LAB.

story:
Hello my name is Kevin Pile, cofounder of Ecotrain Media Group, LLC. Ecotrain is a Portland, OR based start-up consultancy company providing services to various green workforce initiatives. These initiatives address environmental and social crisis' while putting people to work and creating new jobs. Recently, Oregon released their "2011-2019 Green Job Growth Plan." The challenges ahead are tremendous, but the first steps have been made. The barriers have been identified, and the recommendations have been laid forth. Now that we have a map, it is up to us, you and I, the collective workforce to turn crisis' into opportunities. Ecotrain would lke to present to you our 5 minute 45 day solution.

 

Campaign Objective: Raise $50,000 to distribute 1523 Ecotrain Green Career Guide Almanacs to the 6 state agencies involved in the Green Job Growth Plan in all 533 locations across the state of Oregon within 45 days to help jumpstart the state's "2011-2019 Green Job Growth Plan."  

 

In 2009, Oregon legisture passed house bill 3300 calling for the creation of green career initiatives and pathways. In October, 2010, the Oregon's Office of the Governor and Green Job Council released the 2011-2019 Green Jobs Growth Plan.

 

Ecotrain believes our Ecotrain Green Career Guide Almanac needs to be in the hands of the 6 governing agencies involved in the "Green Jobs Growth Plan". Here is our chance to provide 17 years of green workforce research to libaries, schools, and career centers for job seekers, educators, students, entrepreneurs, and communities to use. Our almanac has over 223 pages full of information and reference links to sustainable industries, employers, staffing firms, job boards, schools, associations, investors, and more. Our publication provides an immediate and tangible solution to several of Oregon's "Green Job Growth Plan" recommendations.

 

Ecotrain wants to show our appreciation to Oregon by raising $50,000 to distribute 1523 Ecotrain Green Career Guide Almanacs to every high school, community college, independant and state university, every human services self sufficiency program, employment department, economic development office,and workforce investment board in all 533 locations across Oregon. Oregon is poised for something really big. Lets jumpstart Oregon's "2011-2019 Green Job Growth Plan" by strategically distributing our Ecotrain Green Career Guide Almanac today.

 

We need your help to make this a reality. You are essentially purchasing green career resrouces that will be donated to Oregon's public services while supporting a grassroots campain. Within 45 days, more than 400,000 people will have access to our almanac that will inspire hope and opportunity. With your help, we promise to pay it forward by donating 10% to the World Forestry Center and to an Oregon Green Education Scholarship Fund. Remember all almanacs are printed on 100% recycled paper, and certified by the FSC and Rainforest Alliance.

 

Thank you for listening, please dont forget to tell your friends about our cause. Be part of our story with us, Hop on board the Ecotrain. Our 5 minute 45 day solution would not be possible without all of your support in sharing our story through your own social networks, email, and word of mouth. If we do not reach our goal, I can assure you that we will continue impacting positive change one book, one school, one individual at a time. We want to provide exponential impact, so please utilize Indiegogo share tools provided for your convenience.

 

With your help, you will receive great Product Perks.

story:
Hello everyone.

I have a simple proposition for you...  help me make rent and I will volunteer to make a difference in Hawaii. 

Here's how it works:  You (so kindly) donate to my rent jar and for every $20 received I will donate one hour of my time to various organizations around Hawaii that help the community and the environment.  My rent is $800 including utilities (the cheapest I could find with a 12 y/o dog).  By successfully helping me accomplish this goal, I will give a total of 40 hours to Hawaii's people and plants.  Every weekend I will volunteer at least 4 hours, which amounts to 10 fabulous weeks of volunteering.  When you donate, you can choose which category of volunteering is your favorite... and I'll do it!      

Here's why it needs to work:  Studying botany in Hawaii is one of the best opportunities I could have asked for.  Yet, it is one of the most expensive places I could have chosen.  I work two on-campus jobs (research assistant in plant pathology and editorial assistant for JNRPR) and receive financial aid...but I work the maximum hours allowed and am unable to receive additional aid.  This semester I have class/work/independent research from 9-6 Monday-Friday, therefore, I either need to find a weekend job that pays $30/hour or I need to volunteer my time for Hawaii!  The second option seems like the best/only option. This is my last year of school and I need to graduate...I am running out of money, and need your help!      


See the Change You Wish to Be in the World  

I know you would love to volunteer in Hawaii if you could, but I will be your hands and heart!  Every Sunday evening I will add stories and photos my new blog, http://meagankaymarie.wordpress.com,  for all to see updates of the volunteer work accomplished that weekend, who was impacted, and the change you (we) have made in the community.  I will also post a shortened version to the updates section of this site.  It will be a spectacular show!


You might notice the organizations I will be volunteering with all have a common theme...plants.  That's because I study plants and feel passionate about making a difference in the world through them.  This can mean conservation of native species, restoration of native land use systems, teaching children nutrition and environmental stewardship through gardening, preserving herbarium specimens, promoting sustainable agriculture, maintaining ethnobotanical gardens, preventing invasive species, or increasing seed conservation. 

 

Together We Can Make a Difference!!

THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF MY HEART!!!!!!!!!  

Meagan

story:
Short Summary

Oasis Armada is sailing for a better world. We are supporting many diverse causes, from the environmental, social, political and economic realms. We aim to sail from the Baltic Sea in Scandinavia, out of the fjord where the village of Ytterjärna lies, and head south. Along the way we will be visiting and working with many people, projects and places, sharing our skills and telling their stories.

Currently we are preparing for departure at our base in Ytterjärna, with a team of 6 sailors in the making. We have all been living and learning here together for the past 10 months at The International Youth Initiative Program (YIP). We've recently finished our studies and are now ready to get back out into the world, and onto it's oceans!

We believe that life is about the journey, rather than the destination. Therefore, while we have many ideas, resources and a large network of people and projects to visit, we are still joining the dots together, and will continue to do so along the way, hopefully with your help! (See below for more details).

We have many jobs to do, as well as many things to buy, repair and service before we leave, so both time and our bank balance are against us. We certainly have a busy month ahead in order to make our departure date, but are motivated and determined to be ready to go! We are deeply grateful for your support in helping us achieve our goal of DEPARTURE ON: SEPTEMBER 1st 2012!!!

Where are we sailing towards?

Oasis Armada envisions a world where all things on earth co-exist in harmony - where we as humans have sustainable relationships with our environment, and with each other. We are aligned with the permaculture principles of Earth Care, People Care, and Fair Share. Finally we see that we can act as a catalyst towards reaching this vision by practicing what we preach, and by sharing our experiences and skills in order to awaken, inspire and empower others.

Our Finances

As we sail, we will be relying on gift economy. That is, we will be asking for those that believe in the work we are doing, to help support our minimal financial needs via our website. We will also be offering our services to individuals, businesses and organizations along the way, in exchange for a gift which they feel represents the value of what we have provided to them. 

As stated above however, in order to be able to depart and do the important work we intend to, we need your help. Below is a list of our current financial needs, and we will be updating our website with both financial and non-financial needs as they arise.

Our Gifts

What can we offer: we have a diverse range of skills, which we plan to grow along the way. Currently in our crew we have individuals with skills in website design, short film production, business consultation, community empowerment games and experiences (such as Oasis Games), and more.

 

 

What We Need & How You Can Help

Our Financial Needs as they currently stand (prices are approximate and in US$):

- Tender/Dingy (350)

- Engine Repairs (500)

- Service & Update Life Raft (150)

- Repair AutoHelm (100-150)

- Updating EPIRB (170)

- 50 Ltr. Additional Water Tanks (30)

- Fishing Gear (50)

- Sextant (50)

- Sailing Books (50)

- Self-Steering Windvane (500)

Our Non-Financial Needs as they currently stand

- Inform us of people, places and organisations where good things are happening, or where people are wanting to do good things but need some help.

- Inform us of people or organisations who may want to support the work we are doing (financially or otherwise).

- Tell everyone you know about what we are doing. Share our videos, blogs and photos as they come out.

- If you like what we are doing and want to get involved, or need some advice on where to start, etc. please contact us. We love to hear from you!

 

Voyage Details

Departure

As stated above, we plan to leave from Ytterjärna, Sweden, on the 1st September 2012, and sail south through the Baltic Sea, continuing south around the European Continent.

Route

Our first port of call will be Gotland, where we will be supporting the Ojnareskogan campaign to stop Nordkalk from building a limestone quarry in a unique area for biodiversity in Europe. The campagns aim is to secure the fresh water reserve and natural habitat for endangered species.

Our exact course will be a constant work in progress, as we hear about people, places and organisations along the way. However, our progress will be constantly updated on our website, which will include a graphic so you can see where we are in real time, on a map.

Our Ship

We are sailing on a swedish built and registered 27′ Albin Vega, built in 1970.

The Crew

Who are we and what are we doing?

As a team we have been swimming, sailing and training together on and off for the last few months. We have also been working individually on different areas and projects. Below is a short introduction to our crew. Please view their personal profiles and our website to learn more about their personal motivations for joining the voyage.

Onja ~ From Germany, Onja is the boat Owner & Captain. Onja has been spending all his spare time working on his boat, repairing it and building new features.With his accurate and able touch, we  are in great hands.

Thomas ~ From New Zealand, Thomas is our most experienced sailor. Thomas crossed the Atlantic in January 2006 on Zeferin, a beautiful, home-designed and made 42′ sloop from New Zealand. He will also be helping with practical tasks to get the boat ready.

Noemi ~ Noemie, an American and Israeli citizen. Noemi and Thomas spent their first two weeks of free time after YIP working for Stuart Pledger, CEO at Sustainable Leadership Laboratory, developing prototypes for eco-village income sources. For this work, they were able to provide US$1000 worth of much needed equipment for the voyage.

AJ ~ A citizen of the world, AJ cycled with the project P.E.D.A.L. from London to Istanbul in 2011. He is currently networking with local sailors, sailing when possible, and working on a biodynamic farm in the area. AJ will also be making short films to document the voyage, as well as maintaining our website.

Alex ~ Alaska Grown, Alex has been working remotely from the states on fundraising and networking, and will be joining the journey in early November, due to visa issues.

Pieter: From Belgium, and joining the voyage from the beginning for around 6 weeks. Pieter is going to be working locally to help fund the trip, as well as getting involved in the practical aspects of preparation in his spare time.

 

Our Friends:

We are currently collaborating with WeSea, BERAS, YIP, GO.NETwork.ACTogether, as well as many more individuals who have been assisting us in different ways.

Links:

A quick introduction to Oasis Games.

Short Film of an Oasis Game - hosted by Thomas and Alex in Nepal, March 2012.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Hello, My name is Leyla Spositto and I am currently an 8th grader at the Greenwood School in Mill Valley, California. I have an upcoming science project, which needs support!  I have chosen to test sushi in order to find out whether what the menu says we are eating is accurate or not. I was shocked to discover that whales and many other endangered fish species are being used as meat in our own sushi! This fact motivated me to investigate local restaurants in my area and find out the truth about what we are eating.

 

For this project I would like to raise $1,200. I will use most of the money for the DNA testing of the fish, I will use another good amount for supplies and shipping, and lastly, I will use the rest to buy the sushi. Through extensive research I have carefully selected the lab where the fish will be tested, the type of fish I am going test, and the local restaurants through which I will receive the fish. The goal of my project is to bring awareness to my local community about how one meal of sushi is affecting the earth and whether or not they are eating what they think they are eating! Ultimately, I hope to minimize the use of endangered fish for consumption.

 

I would greatly appreciate any small contribution towards my project, and if you can’t donate you can still help! Spread the word about my project and have friends or family check it out!

Thank you in advance for your support.

Passionately,

Leyla Spositto
